Cloves and citrus nose. Golden orange appearance. Raiseny and malt molasses at start with biscuit finish.
Tasty. Aroma was of fruit, spice and a little funky. Nice color with an amber tint. Full and smooth palate. Flavors were fruity, caramel and slightly hoppy with a sour hint.

Slightly hazy, golden reddish amber in color. Kind of a weak, quickly dissipating head. Aroma of sour apples, clove and coriander. Nice effervescence on the tongue which leads to a well balanced mix of sour, spice, and crisp fruit, notes of bubble gum and lots of banana peel. Excellent.
Goose island no falla. Q buena birria. No es mi estilo las belgas pero esta sobresale
Pours an Amber color with a caramel malt aroma. Taste is sweet, and a light spice. The alcohol flavor is hidden well, with a sugar and malt aftertaste.
Pours a deep orange amber with a good sized just off white head. Aroma of Belgian yeast, citrus and caramel. Taste is pretty much the same but it’s a good combo that works well.
12 oz. bottle. Pours hazy with foamy off white diminishing head. Aroma of fruit and spices. Tastes, sweet and fruity.

750ml brown bottle, 2014. Golden colour, hazy. White head that lasts and leaves good lace rings. Nose has orange, melon, fruity. Taste has caramel, grain, orange, melon, lemon, yeast. Aftertaste has light hops and slightly bretty yeast. Pleasant and not bad for the price.

2013 bottle to pilsner glass. Light caramel color. Globules of sediment float. Big creamy eggshell head. Head lasts throughout beer. Aroma is equal hops and yeast. 
Taste is creamy hops. Light and summery.
Yeast is very subtle, maybe it would be stronger if left to ferment in bottle a few more years. 

Very nice.
Aroma is a little funky but has notes of Belgian yeasts, cloves. Pours a great caramel color with and a lasting white head. Tadte of banana and cloves with a full body and a pleasant banana finish.

Pours with very thin foam, which disappeared almost immediately. Reminiscent of an abbey ale, very faint licorice, banana, phenols, and caramel. Alcohol does not make an appearance. 

Good beer.

Butelka75cl.
OCZY : piwo jest przejrzyste o kolorze miedzianym i białej, drobno-pęcherzykowej pianie. 

NOS : na pierwszy niuch idą nuty melanoidynalne i przyprawowe. Przede wszystkim pieprz. Następnie estry w postaci moreli, winogron i delikatniej banana. Biały ser, siano, skórka cytryny i delikatne fenole. 

USTA : średnio nasycone o kremowej konsystencji. 
W smaku pol-wytrawne winne o mocno podkreślonej przyprawowości. Wręcz soczyste nuty słodów z lekko przypieczoną skórką ciasta drożdżowego. Piwo ma delikatna gorycz. W posmaku pieprz i klejące usta. 

ODCZUCIA : pierwszy raz pije tak belgijskiego blonda warzonego poza Belgią. Równowaga w każdym detalu. Pijalne ale za to kremowe. Przyjemne piwo. Świetny blonde.

Light amber, generous head. 
Exhuberant nose. 
Medium body and flavor intensity, refreshing mouthfeel, good length. 
Dry, slightly bitter, crisp. 
Yeasty, malty. 
Has its charms but too dry for me. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Decent ale. Aroma is mostly fruity, banana stands out. Taste is quite dry, and similar to the nose. Palate a bit spicy and head could be more frothy.
Bottle at home, 2010 vintage. Pours deep reddish amber, nose is huge funk, sherbert, fruity, taste is dry, sweet toffee, Brett, floral.

Bottle pours dark golden with 1" cream head. Smell and taste of cloves but not too much, some bitterness but not to much. Just how I like it, nicely done.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Smells like bitter beer. Taste is sort of mediocre if not slightly below average. Like a mildly malty ale with hops. Medium carbonation with some foam.

24/V/15 - 75cl bottle @ LIBF (Leuven) - BB: n/a (2015-702)  Thanks to the Belgian (and Dutch, and...) RB crew for sharing today’s beers!


Clear copper orange beer, no head. Aroma: very malty, grains, lots of cow fodder, wort, bit sweet, caramel, fruity touch. MF: ok carbon, medium body. Taste: lots of malts, grains, cow fodder, bit sweet, caramel, soft hoppy touch. Aftertaste: grains, cow fodder, slightly hoppy, grassy finish.
Pours orange. Can taste cloves with flavors of spices, can’t tell which ones. Not bad but still like Sofie better.
It’s a good beer, is an a Belgian Style, but a powerful of hops. The beer have a little spicy flabour and fruit

355ml bottle pours a hazy mid copper with small off white head. Spicy nose, cloves, pepper and maybe a bit of cinnamon, some floral notes. Taste is, again, spicy with a bit of fruit. Slightly bitter finish but also a sour note and a sweet spiced apple warmth, interesting.
Gelb. Zitrus, Heu, würzige Hefe in der Nase. Am gaumen Pfirsich, Heu, Süße, Banane, hefe, etwas dün.

15cl sample from bottle at the Leuven Innovation Beer Festival (25 V 2015). I don’t really get the high Ratebeer ratings. To me, this amber coloured brew is just a flat Caffè Americano beer. Lots of water, weak coffee. Did not really notice the "piney and resinous edges of the hops" - too bad.
Bottle at Leuven Innovation Beerfestival, thanks for sharing! Crazy boring beer, would drown in averageness on your regular Belgian beer tasting. Yeast, citrus, maybe some orange peel.

Thanks for sharing! Sampled 650 ml. bottle @ Leuven Innovation Beer Festival. 2012 Version I believe. Pale lemon golden, little white head. Nose is wet socks, dull & metallic, sugar, herbs & very metallic; Taste is oily dull wet socks, thin, metallic, very boring malty, sugary,.. Dull thin metallic & sugar body,… I don’t get,… Tastes like a dull & very forgettable Belgian Ale for me, disappointing for me given my love for certain Goose Island beers.
Fast klare dunkel goldene Farbe, geringe weiße schaumkrone. Geruch sehr malzig, reifes Obst. Geschmack sehr malzig, viel reifes Obst, leicht alkoholisch.
Pours clear golden with small off-white head. Aroma of bretts, citrus, fruits and malt. Taste follows. Medium body. Good balance.

Bouteille. Robe ambrée foncée légèrement trouble surmontée d’un col de mousse blanc. Arômes de levures sauvages, cuir, baies, limette, soupçon de caramel. En bouche, malt caramélisé et levures sauvages, herbes âcres, petits fruits séchés, clou de girofle, vieux cuir. Texture semi-onctueuse et corps moyen.

Bière blonde de 7 % d’alcool. Elle possède un petit col mousseux au versement Elle possède un odorat sucré, légèrement citronné. Elle possède un bon goût d’épices, légèrement sucré, tendance à croire même à un goût de melon d’eau. Excellente !

Bottle at Eaten By Monsters, Carlisle. Bright orangey gold, clear as you like. Bread, papaya and an odd plastic note inthe scent. The taste is... my sweet Lord... a honeyed caramel intensity bomb. Full gooey palette. My only criticism - and despite my fondness for this beer it is not a minor one - is the feel of artifice which separates Matilda, the pretender queen, from the better Abbey beers. But if it is a copy, it is a good one, and worthy of enjoyment without comparison.

Deep amber color . Medium , white head. Floral aroma with notes of yeast , spices , fruits. Fruits , yeast and sweet malt in taste . Very light , refreshing , easy to drink . Pleasant dry finish. Good belgian ale.
Murky dark blonde with medium foam. Fresh and crisp, fruity. Nice aftertaste.

Translucent orange with a minimally sized white head. Pleasant aroma containing notes of malt, yeast, caramel, banana, and citrus. Full bodied, smooth, and extremely rich. Flavours, of yeast, caramel, malt, butterscotch, banana, citrus, and vanilla are present with a negligibly hoppy finish. Absolutely delectable.
Out of bottle. Great beer, nice and fruity, spicy notes. Overall great belgian ale.
Bottle. Pours deep amber with a white head. Fruity, spicy aroma with notes of bretts. Malty, slightly bitter and funky taste.
Very good beer with a slight hoppy taste. The overall flavor from start to finish is good
Tap at the Hammered Lamb. Hazy light brown pour. Smooth, slightly sweet, tart medium body with belgian yeast notes in the flavor. Hints of noble hops and Belgian yeast in the aroma.
My kind of beer. Beautiful aroma and a real nice belgian flavor. Looks really good in the glass.
Bottle @ home. 2011 vintage. Big white head, that last long, great lacing, deep orange color. Fruity, spicy, peber, malt, mango, pear. Dry mouth feel, high carbonation.
Aromat trochę słodowy, z nutami belgijskimi. Barwa bursztynowa, kiepska piana, mętne. W smaku nieco popiołowe i owocowe. Ciekawe. Posmak kwaskowy.

Old rating. Bottle from Old Town. Pours an amber/orange color with a nice big soapy head. Aromas of pear, grapes, yeast and cardamom. Full-bodied with a nice sticky mouthfeel. Peppery and sweet on the palate with a touch of sourness. Boozy and bitter finish.

Bottle, 2014 vintage. Cloudy orange-amber pour with a quickly dissipating head. Fruit, bread and yeast in the aroma, pretty classic Belgian ale but a little more subtle and complex, a bit of spiciness like a tripel. Flavour is not quite as bright, but fruity and subtly spicy. Not bad.

ENG: 765ml bottle from Liquor Mart in Winnipeg, poured into the Teku glass. I am curious because I just had Sofie, which in my opinion, was watery and the flavors were very dimmed.

Opalescent orange / copper color with big, white, and again - glairy head. Aromas of bananas, subtle hoppy red citrus, cloves. Tastes tarty-clovy with bananas, quite bitter aftertaste. Medium body, medium to high carbonation. Overall this one is much better than Sofie, much more well-balanced, much more tasty.



PL: Butelka 765ml kupiona w Liquor Mart w Winnipeg, przelana do Teku. Ciekaw jestem jak wypadnie w porównaniu do Sofie, która była cienka jak szampańskoje igristoje, bardzo wodnista.

Barwa opalizująca, pomarańczowo / miedziana, z dużą, białą i znów białkową pianą. Aromaty bananowe, delikatnie chmielowe - czerwone cytrusy, goździki. W smaku cierpkie goździki, banany, dość goryczkowe w posmaku. Średnie odczucie w ustach, średnie do wysokiego nasycenie. Podsumowując zdecydowanie lepsze od Sofie, bardziej zbalansowane, mocniejsze doznania smakowe.

Nice & smooth as one would expect from a Belgian. Beautiful light copper pour w/ a white head that leaves some lacing. The aroma is of soft Belgian spices. The taste is also light w/ spice but highly drinkable. Good stuff!
Pours a copper-orange color with no head. Aroma is orange and an interesting spice. Flavor is sweet orange and a touch of spice. Pretty good.

Bottle. Pours hazy orange with large forthy head. High carbonation. Aroma of oranges and other citrus fruits. Taste brings back the citrus, but also a bit of almost of a cider aspect, herbs, acidic and light bitter finish. Can’t help, but compare this to an Orval. A bit more tarty if I’m not mistaken.

765 (???) ml bottle intermittently into a tulip. Figured I’d give it a shot as the few Goose Island products in province seem to be in the midst of being delisted (with sizeable price reduction!) at the provincial store. Pours a transluscent golden colour, with quickly dissipating fluffy white head. Yeasty, citrus nose with a bit of barnyard funk. Slightly spicy favour, and a bit tart, with a dry bitter finish. Medium bodied, with lively carbonation. Complex and interesting.

A citrusy, wheat Belgian beer. Orange undertones, reminiscent of hacker pshorr.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Sept 2014 bottle. Copper/orange body with a huge off-white head which dissipated slowly. Aroma is tart green apple, pear, subtle lemon, leather, white pepper, and a little barnyard funk. Appropriate carbonation, quite effervescent with some lingering dry sweetness. Very light bitterness, surprisingly sessionable. Top notch.

Goose Island Matilda Belgian Style Pale Ale has a medium, off-white head, a bubbly, brilliant, deep-orange appearance, lots of larger and powdery gray-white sediment roiling about, and a bit of lacing left behind. The aroma is of sugary, bready, sweet, horse blanket, with some citrus aspects. Taste is of those elements, with some white pepper and fairly bitter hop spicing. Mouthfeel is medium, and Goose Island Matilda Belgian Style Pale Ale finishes champagne-like, flavorful, and not boozy. Smooth stuff. RJT

Bottle from Tesco. Clearish amber. Nose is funky brett, brown sugar, woody vinous. Tastes red fruits, gentle funk, first feels dry but turns sweeter, grapey vinous, bready malty. Nice easier funky beer, not sure how it goes in Tesco though.

2012 enjoyed in 2015. Deep orange copper with fluffy slowly fading head. Definitely smell the brett, very tart apple with other funky notes. Very funky, spice notes, past ripe citrus, fermenting dough, old biscuits. Interesting. Lively carbonation. Very dry finish. Palate very similar to a dry champagne.
Tap at Fathead’s, Portland. Colour is deep orange with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Fruits, Belgian yeast, some caramel and malts.

Bottle, vintage 2014, enjoyed January 2015. Pours hazy golden, with a receding creamy head. Aroma is fruity Belgian yeast and notes of brett, with cloves, spices and woody notes, as well as kandi and some lightly roasted malts. Medium body, with average carbonation. Flavour is tart and bretty, with peppery spices, wood, and kandi, as well as flowery, herbal and soapy notes before a dry spicy finish.

Bottle pour. Hazy dark golden with a large frothy white head. Aroma is Yeast, citrus, spices, and a little malts. Full creamy body. Taste is caramel, barley, spices, with a very light bitter aftertaste.

Poured from a 650 ML bottle into a tulip glass.
Aroma- Malt fruit and spice. . . nice!!
Appearance- A clear copper colored brew with a very small white head.
Taste- Has a nice floral flavor mixed in with the malt
Palate- A medium bodied brew with moderate carbonation that has a thin but dry finish.
Overall- A really good beer!! If I come across this again I will definitely drink it.
Aroma of citrus and yeasty, taste is more yeast, some spiciness, drinkable and glad to try!
33 cl. bottle. Hazy orange colour with a white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, caramel, yeast, fruit and brettanomyces.
Draught @ Waterfront Ale House. Cloudy orange with small foamy white head, hoppy aroma, sweetish start with a long fruity finish, low carbonation. Quite nice.
Bouteille de 700ml. Nez fruité avec des notes belges. Rafraichissant en bouche. Caractère Brett tout juste assez présent. Belle fraîcheur d’été.

ファームハウスエール  
ベルギービールのような感じ
香り高いけどホッピーではない
甘くて苦い
大変美味しい
это пиво очень вкусно. я бы, конечно, рекомендую его всем. пожалуйста, обратитесь его. очень хорошо!
his one is very nice, as expected from Goose Island. Slightly sweet notes. Bit less carbonated than the Euro varieties. Recommended.

Super interesting. Made polishing hardwood floors not nearly as boring. Pours an appealing hazy orange - small white head. Tons going on with flavor- dried fruit, banana, caramel, toffee, spice but somehow both bitter and sour on the finish. The use of brett adds a modest amount of funk but tons of interest. Pretty complex. Loved it.

slightly cloudy amber color; spicy, sour fruit aroma; slightly sour fruit flavor although more bitter than sour, with lots of spice notes - corriander; bitter with floral hop notes; nice dry, bitter finish
Poured from the bottle of a 4-pack into the pint glass. good looking glass of beer. Tastes a little sweet and tart at first, turns to spicy then bitter. Pretty good at 7%, should be in a six pack.

765ml bottle to leffe bowl glass, the beer pours a dirty hazy orange with lots of floaties, looks great! The aroma is sour and fruity, lots of citrus, orange peel, lemon, honey, vanilla...I’m very curious at this point. Surprisingly the taste isn’t as sour as I thought but carries lots of bitterness and a bit of sweetness to back it. There’s a dustyness to this beer along with strong fruit flavours and a taste of cigarettes. A bit medicinal as well. Is it good? Yep. But definitely not what I was expecting given the aroma. The beer is quite drinkable, balance is good, co2 is medium, body is medium. Overall if matilda was a real woman she would be dusty, smell like cigars, be a little odd, medium bodied but be pretty decent in bed. Or so this beer implies.

Bottle from the LCBO. Cloudy deep amber with a billowy off white head that recedes quite slowly. Nose has bread, toffee, banana, cloves, grass and a bit of Brett funk. Light sweet caramel and bread start with a medium light grassy bitterness and cherry tartness carrying through to the finish. Light spice throughout. Medium slick mouth with average carbonation and a dry finish. Nice combination of sour and spice.
330ml bottle, pours a very light amber orange with a thin white head. On the nose some smoky spices. Taste is blenty of spice, some clover and a hint of banana yeast.

12 oz bottle poured into chalice. Great aroma of belgianish yeast and some hops. Nothing special on the nose really. Almost no head to it. Easy on the palate with moderate carbonation, but something tasted slightly "off" to me. Preferred Sofie way more.
Very mild for a Belgian Pale Ale. Some spicy, malty notes with a mild hop flavour backing it up. Should have a higher abv and more of a spice bite perhaps.
Nice spicy and yeasty aroma, clear blond ale with a white head. Flavor is very yeasty with a good hop bitterness in the aftertaste. Strong and warming.
65 cl bottle, Calgary, AB, via Coop. Slightly hazy dark gold, yeasty herbal aroma with some lemon citrus. Balanced flavour, somewhat sweet with some honey and cereal then more citrus on the finish.

Pours a dark orange,honey color, small head, some lacing. Aroma is Belgian spices, clove, some banana but there’s a feeling of complexity here. Taste is yeasty with a complex spice feeling. A slight bitterness at the end which is awesome and great balance

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

~Bready malt aroma with fruitiness of fig and berries, peppery spiciness. Light and intriguing.
~Pours a hazy orange golden color with dense creamy white head that disappears.
~Yeasty flavor of fruit and spice, fig, raisin, corriander, white pepper, subdued bready maltiness with light caramel. Interesting.
~Light bodied with high CO2, lingering yeasty finish.
~ Enjoyable brew. Interesting flavors and aromas to ponder
You know what I like about Matilda? She’s sweet, but she has a little bit of funk to her. Just enough that you like it, but don’t question it.

Excellent Belgian ale from Goose Island. I sampled this on draft at the "pub" at the O’Hare airport. The Maltida poured a dark gold color with a decent off-white head. The lacing stuck beautifully to the inside of the glass. The body was smooth and drinkable, with flavors of dark fruit, light but spicy hops, bread and yeast.
On tap. Pours a hazy golden with thin white lacing. Initial aromas of lemongrass with a sweet scent. Goes down suprisingly sweet and refreshing with grassy, citrus aromas.
2009 bottle. Clear, dark amber. Good, solid raisin and wet hay aroma. Flavour has red berries, good malty background. Creamy, fluffy mouthfeel. Nice.

Bottle @ Hoppy Advent Race in Space, Sønderborg. Pours hazy amber with stable off-white head. Atypical aroma of raisins and porto, with vinous and hoppy notes. Vinous flavour with notes of malt, red berries, yeats and dust and some hoppy bitterness. Bitter and sourish aftertaste. Decent.

Bottle, 7%. Fruity and citric aroma with a good raisin note to it. Clear copper colour, a little reddish, with some small bits floating in it. small white head. The flavour is citric and fruity with some berry to it. Has a good balance between the berry flavours, citric notes and bitterness.

Picked this one up at the supermarket on a recent trip to Quebec and i was pleasantly surprised.
Aroma: barnyard, lemongrass, hay bales
Appearance: great head formation and retention, slight haze (positive), bursting with carbonation
Taste: lemon funk, moderate spicy bitterness, nice barnyard brett character, fresh hay
Palate: super dry, prickly carbonation, refreshing bitterness
Overall: this beer rocked my world. Good to see that the buy-out of this brewery did not affect quality. One of the best saisons I have ever had. Great value for the $. Highly recommended.

Tap at The Oak. Hazy gold pour with a thick head that fades slowly to a ring. Aroma is very floral with banana, bubblegum, and light oranges. Taste has lots of floral hops with a spicy, bubblegum yeast finish. There’s a generic fruitiness in there too. Medium body. Not bad but something I won’t go back to.

Hazy golden pour with a thin white head. Thick yeasty aroma, borderline musty, if not for the pleasant floral scents. Solid BPA that’s lively to taste and well-balanced. Medium body, doughy with cloves and spices on the finish.
Nice spicy peppery aroma with a golden medium bodied hazy beer. Taste is bitter and slightly sour, really refreshing. Some extra citrus in the aroma. Not too complex, but very well made great beer.

"Goose Island", "Belgian" style, "Matilda". So there you have it. A flock of geese, Kangaroos and a nation running away from the German army, making beer. The results are as expected: it tastes like a goose necked, kangaroo afraid to take on the "BIG BOY" of brewing: Blatz. It’s true. Save this for those fondue-dipping freaks from Europe. And take solace in the fact that YOU---as a MAN----prefer the greatest beer to ever "blitz" your liver: Blatz. Don’t question it.

Hazy golden amber pour with large frothy white head. Aroma of caramel, malts, oranges, slight hops, faint citrus. Taste of caramel malts, oranges, faint citrus, yeast and faint hops. Medium bodied, nice carbonation, silky mouthfeel, perfectly balanced. Delicious beer.
Cloudy amber,lasting beige head.Spicy yeast nose,hint of citrus. Palate of spicy yeast, tin & bubblegum.Medium strength lasting hop end.Orange notes

Hazy copper color with off-white head. Sugary malt aroma, floral, yeast, funk, spice, clove and banana. Flavor is similar with more lean towards floral/funk and resi malts. Molasses. Medium body beverage. After spending $11 for this on tap I am highly disappointed. What a rip off.
It pours with a hazy amber color with a medium bodied head and lacing. The aroma is dominated by yeast of earthly and basement aromas. The taste has a powerful yeast domination.
Bootle in Eaten by Monsters, Carlisle. Amber with an off-white head. Slightly hazy. Fruity aroma and taste with spicy notes. Also some peach, aniseed and caramel. Good beer.
355 ml bottle. Pours copper colour. Medium lacing. Aromas of bananas and cinnamon. Subtle finish and medium carbonation. Good beer.
Hazy copper with a frothy white head and cling lace. Fresh floral aroma of spice, apples and champagne like yeast. Crisp texture. Spicy malt flavour with clove and banana.

Pours a nice clear golden copper color with a medium head. Aroma of cloves, banana and some weird sour funkiness? Taste is weird on the palate. You feel some citrus sourness in there that lingers . Full body. Hard to say id I like it but it does get better after the firsrt few sips.

Beautiful beer and one that you should buy multiple bottles of and cellar! Yeasty, funky, barnyard, subtle malt, banana and spice. Nice carbonation and beautiful dry finish. Complex, yet balanced. Very nice effort by Goose Island.

Here’s the thing - I haven’t rated for months, but I have tasted literally over a hundred beers since my last visit.
So what’s the diff, why the special attention?
1. It’s a special, very special occasion.
2. This no ordinary beer! 2009 pre Imbev
3. I’ve been drinking this beer since it’s introduction (I’m from Chicago and have been involved in the beer community almost 25 years)
Why now?
This beer is special, even with the take-over. (I already said that, sooooory.)
This beer is unique to the provenance.
This beer has something to offer the US brew community.
Matilda is extra ordinary. It is the first, as far as I can tell, American ale in this category of any note. None - let me restate that - maybe few but only some, of the other beers in this category were around when it was introduced!
Now it is #25. Wow.
PS this is not an Imbev advert. I like this beer.
Think about it: what makes this beer deserve special merit?
A gold GABF?
The fact that it may have been the first on the American scene?
I remember, perhaps 20 years ago, Greg Hall mentioning a trip to Belgium, perhaps the first among many.
I remember the introduction of Belgium styled ales into the Goose line.
From Belgium 31 years ago I had a flashback and some one said "Not much of a good specimen of the Belgian Wheat style..."
Are you sh*ting me you f****n’ m****n?
This is a classic Dubbel, may it hit you in the head and die of the XTC.
(This person is in need of a beerbrain ImPlant!)
What you have is a beer that is an off-spring. It is born of this country and the aspects of it’s terroir, are you listening AbbyRoad? It’s uniqueness is a value of it’s existence.
And so we have the uniqueness of american beers, whether originated here or derived from a special place elsewhere.
WAKE UP.
Learn your history and enjoy, but don’t misplace, whether here or Imbev - This beer is sweet and I hope will flourish...
Look at the listings - I have tried most of them. Cheers!!

Very Light smell, malty taste smooth...light and a bit watery, no hops, slightly sour bitter..ok x2 very strong flavor, maybe a touch vinegary...too old?? Very bold though...seems different from first rating but only lowered by 0.2....had at Megan's work party day after my 2,000th beer party

Hazy amber pour with a fairy fluffy white head that leaves a decent amount of lace. Lots of fruit and floral notes on the nose with a hint of funkiness. Quite similar on the palate with a dry, slightly tart finish.

Not much of a good specimen of the Belgian Wheat style. Kind of bitter/sour and not in a traditional rich, yeasty Belgian kind of way. Disappointing. Not sur why it is otherwise rated so highly other than it might be a bad specimen from Mactoberfest.

Nice golden color, fruity and floral aroma. Flavor is hard to place - fruity but also a bit... musty? Hard to describe it but definitely enjoyable. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours deep orange/golden/copper, slightly off white head, frothy, medium lacing. Aroma immediately spicey, cloves, cinnamon, hints of bubblegum and banana on the nose, paired with slightly fruity notes (nondescript), slightly tart. Highly carbonated, a lot more banana on the taste than the nose, tartness does not register on the palate - but the bottle is only six months old - some sweetness, quite a bit of wheat protein presence but clarity and Brett doesn’t account for it. . . Very faint caramel present, as with a lollipop character.

Smells sourly of spontanely fermenting yeasts, hints of urine but also with malty sweetness. Tastes like dry white wine, malt, mild pale ales and some cheese. Very complex and well-composed beer - I like it.

A better Belgian than Belgium can brew. Pours an unfiltered amber with a small head. Aroma is of grapes, yeast, and basement. Tastes of yeast, plums, candy, apples, and sugar. Has a medium body with tingly carbonation and a light vinous aftertaste. Very well balanced beer.

Pours a dark orange,honey color, small head, some lacing. Aroma is Belgian spices, clove, some banana but there’s a feeling of complexity here. Taste is yeasty with a complex spice feeling. A slight bitterness at the end which is awesome and great balance. A very nice brew!

Superb Belgian from......Chicago? USA does it best (and worst) when it comes to beer. This Illinois beaut is no exception, glowing opaque copper with a crisp white foam. Smells of white grapes, sweet piss, honey, wheat, yeast, basement, raisins and earthy musk. Exceptionally smooth and tasty. Perhaps best described by a friend new to the style as "everything I like about the idea of wine without any of the bad shit I don’t like". A wee bit of spiciness and berries in the taste as well, very mildly bitter with an enjoyable dry fruity finish. Excellent stuff, this.

"nice fruit and spice aroma. yeasty, but mellow. a touch of hops mingles with the spiciness and sweet in the flavor. quite good all the way around. well crafted brew. surprisingly, the weak link in a Sophie-Pere Jaques-Matilda tasting."

Bottle 33 cl.

Hazy orange, off-white. Sweet orange or tangerine, yeast, light spices and caramel malt on the nose. Sweet malty taste, with dry finish.

Creamy yeast and coriander type of aroma. Burnt amber opaque color. Thin foam head. Potent at first taste as this brew means business but then softens and welcomes you in. Mild sweetness and has a deep complexity.

Draft. Orange-copper color. Thin, off-white head dissipates quickly. Sour; string alcohol. Lingering finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From old notes, tasted with Curtis and some friends in Nashville, probably some time near the summer of 2012, from a 2010 bottling. Pours clear dark orange with a thick white head that leaves average lace. The nose is brett funk forward and caramel malt with a nice fruity pineapple note. The flavor is a bit sweet with the pineapple and caramel up front, moving to really great dry, spicy, and funky brett. The body is medium with average carbonation and a long spicy brett and touch of pineapple finish. Just like Orval, I think that about two years is the sweet spot for this beer.
Orange golden with a big white head. Aroma of brett and light grassy hops, floral and funky. Taste is lightly sweet caramel, citrusy fruit, bretty goodness. Really nice and not what i was expecting.

(bottle from 02-2014) Pours a semi-hazy orange color with a tall white head that retains very well. Aroma really pinballs between scents and constantly morphs and changes through floral, fruit, and herbal shifts. Funk tags along as well. For the floral phase I perceive predominant scent of rosehips although I smell potpourri from time to time. For the fruit phase all things citrus are displayed with a cornucopia of scents ranging from grapefruit, orange, and lemon with some residual apricot lurking mostly in the background before slamming to the forefront with further warming. The herbal scents are more minty, but they seem to die down with further warming which was a bit of a letdown as that element lifted the aroma even higher in the early goings of consumption. Flavor holds the aforementioned apricot, sweet caramel, and a good dose of lightly stinging citric hops on the finish. The case could be made for these hops being spicy. Nice undertone of funk sounds out on the far finish, but the dryness isn’t quite there yet. This bottle is only 7 months old, and maybe the brett hasn’t yet had a chance to crisp this thing up, so it would be interesting to see how one of these ages. Mouthfeel is lightly syrupy which is an undesirable characteristic for this kind of beer, and perhaps with age, this beer will lose some weight. Carb’s ok. Overall this is a solid belgian ale that, at its current price point, will prompt me to purchase another when it’s a year old to see how it’s coming along.
Orange maroon pour. Consistent lacing. Rustic earthy nose. Some citrus fruit. Medium bodied and a little viscous on the palate. Complexity is nice. More of the fruit and a fairly dry crisp finish.

Drucken på flaska från London. Svag fruktig lukt, kroppen och smaken likaså. Hade väntat mig mer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

/// Petit «gushing» à l’ouverture! Rien de trop abondant, mais tout de même désagréable… /// Bière orangée tirant sur le jaune, remplie de particules en suspension, très effervescente, et surmontée d’un large col blanc, très dense, très mousseux, cotonneux même, bien persistant, et qui laisse une riche dentelle sur les parois du verre. Arômes de pain frais, malt mielleux, fruits du verger (surtout de la poire en fait, avec un peu de pêche, abricot…), avec une petite pointe de levure acide typique des bières ensemencées de brettanomyces. Davantage en arrière-plan, on note des effluves plus herbacés et épicés (poivre, clou de girofle…) auxquels le houblon contribue certainement. On note également la présence d’un houblon plus floral. Nez intéressant et agréable, belle complexité, bonne intensité. En bouche, pétillement élevé sur la langue, onctuosité moyenne au palais. Au goût, pain frais, malt mielleux, poire et pêche, avec une touche de levure acide, et une finale au houblon qui semble à la fois un peu herbacé, un peu poivré et un peu floral. Amertume légère, équilibre sucré/acide/amertume intéressant. En bouche, intensité moyenne, complexité moyenne. Une bonne bière, sans plus…

Bottle from Safeway in Redwood City, CA. Pours a hazy golden orange. Aroma is dried fruits, white wine, spicy yeasty bits. Taste is dry white wine, apples, guava, plums... I’m getting a lot of dry, mildy sour taste from fruit skins (less of the fruit sweetness). Some spiced cloves / coriander / floral you’d expect from a belgian farmhouse but not overpowering. Very reminiscent of a white wine to me.

Pours orange, no head. Aroma of sweet malts and spice. Taste is sweet, malty, banana, good.

Almost no head. Orange golden hazy. Aroma of yeast, belgian?, fruity and spicy. Taste is also fruity and spice, some caramalt. But also a bit sour in the end. Started okay but there’s a spicy, pepperish and sour aftertaste i don’t like.

Very good beer and one of my favorites. Unfortunately a bit pricy. Fruity flavor but not too much. Balanced.

765mL Bottle (No, you’re not misreading that). Golden amber, fairly minimal white head. Aroma is caramel, pepper, nuts, toast, resin, earthy, and a slight hint of citrus. Taste is tart and fruity, with hints of apple, pear, caramel, and nuts. Fades into a sweeter, earthier, yeast and clove and finishes with a slight lingering hint of pine and citrus from the hops. Fairly fizzy carbonation, smooth and creamy. 7% ABV is hardly noticeable. Very well balanced beer, would consider storing one away to see how it ages, should I find the time.

My store just got this in this week, so I had to try one on.

Pours a nice amber colour but with almost no head, which I find curious in a Belgian. Mild aroma of faint citrus and of course, Belgian yeast. Leaves me somewhat worried. Flavour makes up for it though- nice robust Belgian ale, ripe cherries, spices. A little bit sharp, but the bottle is young. I expect this would be incredible after some cellaring.

Bière blonde typique belge avec un nez très présent de levures. Le goût est de même sans vraiment d'autre arôme. La finale est assez longue avec encore des goûts de levures. Pour les amateurs de type belge classique

On draught at Belmont Station. Golden color. Aroma is pepper spice, yeast, plum, grass, and citrus honey. Taste is bittersweet yeast, pepper, banana, prune, grass, and honey. Finishes with a slight bitterness, but mostly a refreshing sweet farmhouse aftertaste.

Beautiful beer. It has a sweet aroma, reminiscent of many Belgian ales, but the taste was more earthy and robust than I expected. The bottle’s label suggests laying down for up to 5 years. If I got my hands on another bottle I would do just that.

Pours a nice dark golden amber colour with a thin white head. Fruity aroma with slight malty hints. Rather sweet flavour but some subtle sourness at the end. The further I got into the beer some slight piney tastes came to the forefront. First Goose Island product I’ve tried and very excited to try more.

Meio do caminho entre a Pale Ale, mas não tão amarga, e a Belgian, mas mais encorpada.

Transfer from BA review on 9-25-12- 
 Poured from bottle into tulip glass

 Appearance - Pours a hazy orange-copper color with a nice two finger white head that receded quite rapidly. Once the head has faded, a moderate level of lacing is left on the sides of the glass.

 Smell – The aroma is heaviest of lighter fruit aromas of pear, banana, apple and peach. Mixed with these fruit aromas are notes of a yeasty smell as well as some spice aromas of clove and nutmeg. Rounding out all these are some aromas of a bready nature, which when combined with the rest create a very nice aroma overall.

 Taste – The taste begins with many of the fruit flavors that were also present in the nose. The apples, pear and peach which start are also accompanied initially by a biscuity flavor. Soon as the flavor advances however the yeast and spice show up bringing a yeast cake, banana, and classic yeast spice profile (clove and nutmeg) flavor to the tongue. In the end flavors of a more herbal and grapefruit citrus nature come to the tongue, leaving a sour and sweet (emphasis on the sweet) flavor to linger on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel – The body of the beer was on the slightly lighter side with the carbonation level being rather average. Both were quite fitting for the fruit flavors of the beer as well as the style.

 Overall – A nice fresh tasting Belgian strong pale. While not super “strong” it is smooth and flavorful. A good drinker and one to try if you get a chance.

750ml bottle pours a pale amber color with a 2 finger white head that retains well and leaves some spotted lacing behind. Streams of carbonation rising to the surface. Aroma is light fruits and spice with some yeasty notes and hints of caramel. Taste is a spicy hop bitterness with a light fruity and malty sweetness. Light to medium bodied with generous carbonation. A nicely done Belgian style pale ale and recommended.

bottle in a trade thanks a lot to cunningham! shared with a friend. poured a cloudy amber colour with a white head. spiced pepper smell, spiced yeast, grains, sour notes, lemon peel. taste is like a bad orval clonde

Pours clear amber with low white head. Aroma of honey, wheat, cilantro, light herbs. Taste is rich honey sweet, balancing out with subtle bitterness towards the finish. Light, very smooth body with soft carbonation.

Pours a dark orange/honey color small head, some lacing. Aroma is Belgian spices, clove, some banana but there’s a feeling of complexity here. Taste is yeasty with a complex spice feeling. A slight bitterness at the end which is awesome. One of my favorites, this.
(bottle) bright clear orange amber colour with a medium tall white head; aroma: floral, urinal cake, hint of barnyard; balanced flavour with no finish

I had this at Global Brew. Pours copper with off white head. Taste citrus, sweet, belgian yeast. I thought this was pretty good. I would definitely drink this again.

de couleur dore legerement ambre on sens tout suite le malt un peu sucre comme la banane en bouche c est une biere typiquement belge avec son malte en bouche tresb bonnne biere j aime aussi la bouteille c est une 2014 on dirait une bouteille de vin

Good beer. Great amber color with a bit of haze. Hits the palate with a bit of spice and has very Little aftertaste. Nice head. Overall a worthy but not spectacular beer.

Poured from 12 oz bottle into tulip glass.

Appearance: pours a 2" frothy cream colored head which slowly falls with some mild lacing. Color is a amber-orange, cloudy with sediment in suspension. Extreme amounts of champagne-like streaming carbonation.

Aroma: banana and coriander, caramel, Belgian yeast.

Mouthfeel: medium bodied and slightly astringent. Finish is dry with a bit of lingering alcohol burn.

Flavor: sweet caramel and spices, raisins, a hint of pineapple, yeast rolls, strong earthy hop presence.

Overall: nicely done and a pleasant brew for sipping and contemplation.

From notes. Draft to plastic cup at Migration event. Pours copper with an off white head. Aroma is subtle, sawdust, pine resin. Flavor is caramel, belgian yeast, pine resin and grassy hop in the finish.

Pours a cloudy copper with a ridiculously unmanageable head, requiring ten or fifteen minutes to tame to three or four pillowy fingers, great retention and heavy lacing. Nose is dominated by brett, with a distinct sour edge, against stone fruit and caramel malt. Taste starts out sweet, but moves quickly to sour, with a lingering sour and bitter finish. Mouth feel is slightly heavy, with lower than expected carbonation.

Oh, that’s nice. That’s very nice. Mildly funky and sour, with just enough brett to be interesting, but not overwhelming. Loads of character, with a gentle warming as the bottle progresses.

The body has warm reddish orange amber color with a cloudy haze. A thick and tall off white head caps off the beer and makes some nice lacing on the glass. In the nose I pick up lots of good things. There are notes of spicy and medicinal phenols with tropical fruit, yeast and sweet honey like malt. It also has a light touch of funky earthy hops. On the tongue there is a tasty mix of all the spicy/medicinal and yeast notes with some tropical fruit and honey sweetness. The funky and sweet notes are tempered with a good balance of earthy dry hop spice and bitterness. With its medium to full body I get a slightly different mix of flavor notes each time. The texture is kind of smooth and dry with a nice level of carbonation.

2013 12 oz bottle. Nice fruity aroma. Poured a hazy orange with a frothy off-white top. Taste of spice, sweet fruit, citrus, Belgian yeast with a subtle dry finish. Active carbonation, medium-thick body.
25.87 FL OZ. ($10.99) taste is very tuff. very big flavor beer. Smells very similar to a sweet german wine or a moscato grape mold. worth trying once.

Bottle from Petaluma Market. Golden brown in colour with some carbonation. Aroma is of sweet strawberries, some plum and funky fruit yeast. Taste is a creamy mix of citrus fruits with a slightl belgian yeast taste in there. Some spice on the finish. This is really smooth, flavoursome and hides 7% really well.
Love the names given to many of these beers, but this one was not my ’cup of tea’.

Poured into a trappist glass; Hazy orange color with a frothy 1 finger head; aroma of citrus hops (orange and lemon), cloves, and a touch of yeast from the bottle conditioning; Taste is citrus up front with no bitterness fading to a very lightly bitter herbal aftertaste that lasts; Carbonation is lively and well balanced; Mouthfeel is on the full side of medium. An absolutely exceptional beer. This reminds me of Leffe, which I imagine it is modeled after, but better. Less bitterness and more flavor.
Bottle from Voldby. Pours hazy orange with a good off-white head. Slightly bitter taste of malts, yeast, spice, fruits. A bit sour. Soft carbonation. Bittersweet finish.

Pours a hazy orange, moderate head, yeasty aroma with a hint of urine. Mediocre in taste and body. Meh.

DWG; Pours cloudy golden with a frothy, moderate lasting and lacing white to off-white head head. Nose is malt, sour, fruit and spice. Taste is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a light bitter, mostly sweet lasting finish. Body is medium to full, texture is oily to creamy, carbonation is soft

Bottle (2013), 355ml. An orange beer with a creamy head that fades away after a couple of minutes. It has a floral aroma, just like Goose Island’s Sofie, but less intense. Taste is slightly bitter at the beginning and siur at the end. Medium to heavy carbonation and also a little bit watery.

Bottle (2013), 355ml. Pours a slightly cloudy orange colour with a creamy offwhite head with medium retention. Earthy aroma of yeast and sweet malts. Medium body and carbonation. Sweet, citric and spicy, refreshing and drinkable, with a medium bitter and alcohol finish.

Hits all the right notes for the style, looks like it belongs in a Belgian trappist glass. Copper/orange with a small, silky oil skin head. Aroma of wine barrels and dried fruit. Taste is woody and smoky, some dried fruit, peat. Abrupt finish.
Bottle bier huis ossett. Amber colour halo white head. Aroma is lemon hops. Taste is fruity yeasty slight spice ok hoppy bitter finish. Nice body prickly carbonated. Good stuff.
Fantastic brew. Pour is a nice light amber with a thin white head. Aroma is grainy but great.

In the bottle. Pours dark golden in color. Easy to drink but with good flavor.

Pours a hazy amber color with off-white head. Dark fruits an dspice on teh nose, with a little yeast. Finishes with a decent malt backbone.

On tap at Umani Burger in Santa Monica. Very fruity and spicy and an honest & enthusiastic attempt at the style. une belle couleur ambré, des saveurs équilibrés, un corps agréable! Je suis vendu, une bière a reprendre

Poured into a tulip glass. Pours a clear golden amber, with a large white head which fades slowly and leaves good lacing. Nose is caramel and Belgian yeast. Taste is light malt with some caramel and has a long finish that is rather dry for the style. Not bad at all.
Bottle to tulip - Nice deep orange color with a generous head. Has a sweet candy aroma and sweet fruit flavor to it. Pretty good.
Duft av citron og høy. Fin gyllen farge. Lite skum, litt langs kant. Frisk smak av høy og sitron.

Unique even by Belgian standards. It has caramel sugar, some orange peel, a bit of wild ale funk, and some baking spices. There are some hops for balance, but it still isn’t really a hoppy beer. A little sour. Creamy head, very easy to drink, refreshing. Great beer, can’t wait to age it and see what happens.
From bottle. Pours a hazy almost orange color. Yellowish head. Very little lacing. Funky light sour aroma and taste with some fruitiness. Complex. Some sweetness. Finish is lightly bitter.

2012 bottle
1 pepper and spicy Belgian phenols, no hop aroma, slight caramel sweetness 2 murky straw with a lacey head 3 toasty sweetness with a wild peppery brett flavor, some clove and allspice 4 medium body with a lively carb 5 A nice sour beer with a big hop kick. I would recommend this, but I would prefer more sourness.
Caramel and malt some spices on the back make up the aroma and taste... not bad!!!!!!!!
2013 bottle. Little, if any, funk, so I was a bit disappointed. A few more years may do it. Otherwise a decent Belgian with what you'd expect.

bouteille de 765ml de blonde ambrée. arome d’orange et de céréale. au gout acidité marqué et arrière gout de céréale. intéressante et complexe mais comme je ne suis pas un fan des bières acides ce n’est pas mon type. audrey donne 4,3
Poured from a 22 ounce bomber, thanks Brian. The aroma is funky, some ski boot. The flavors are tropical fruits, soft herbal hops.
2014 Matilda. Nice blend of hops on top of the Belgium yeasts and spice. Really enjoyed this.

In bottle while in Chicago; quite nice .. somewhat sweet with a little spicy note. Good attempt at a Belgian ale (though still not as good as the actual Belgians).
I would buy this again
Easily my favorite beer...incredible precision with flavor...lots to absorb. Interested to see if this beer stays amongst world best.

very fresh 12 oz 2011 bottle - 7/13/11 date - served at about 50-55 F.{from 8/2011 notes} 

Appearance - a clear amber with a small head that quickly settles to a lasting ring. Visible moderate carbonation. 

A light to moderate strength aroma promises some yeasty and spiced light malt, with plenty of cloves. The flavor itself largely follows, but being more spicy and flavorful than the nose indicates. The spice complex is too reliant on cloves, a commmon complaint (from me) for light Belgian styles beers. The beer does have some underlying complexity that is perhaps most obvious in the lasting finish. Lightly earthy with hints of raisins and more than a hint of yeast.

M - Good carbonation streaming up from the bottom is also evident in the mouthfeel of this medium bodied and lightly crisp beer. 

O - Plenty of flavor despite a nose that is a tad light. I enjoyed this beer more as I got further thruthe bottle, some acclimation perhaps, but likely some warming too. It has more complexity than my first impression indicated but, unfortunately, an overload of clove as well. I’d like to try an aged bottle down the road.
I really enjoy this beer. Kind of a unique flavor as far as I’m concerned. Love the hoppy-ness, love the spices. High ABV so a little sharper, but a great drink.
Bottle. Pours a dark amber with light head. Nose is belgian yeast and burnt bananas. Tastes like dried bananas, toasted malts, and some spice.

Bottle conditioned from 27/11/2012. Consumed on 24/4/2014. Medium white head. Gold to amber body. Visible carbonation. Belgian yeast, hop, malt, sour, hint of Maraschino cherries. Banana. Champagne. Taste is sour. Dry finish. Good carbonation. Refreshing. Somewhat of a summer beer. Fair play to Goose Island here, a really good take on Orval.
Dunkel lys gyllen farve med lyst skum. lukt av gjær, banan og frukt. Smak av gjær, frukt og krydder. Melkebaren.

Pours like a copper-amber sunset with an active soapy white head that leaves wet lacing as it fades to an adequate coating. Aroma is biscuits, yeast and mild fruit esters. Banana and clove. Taste too is biscuit malts and yeast. The fruit esters are a backbone that ripens as this beer warms. Nople hops. Spicy, sour, well-carbonated. Quite nicely balanced. Leans more on the malt character vs fruity sweetness. A yeast-lovers treat.
Clear light amber pour. Aroma is yeast, fruit, bread. Clean, slightly spicy, bready.
Malty aroma, nice amber color, little to no white head. Nasty and spicy yeast profile. Great beer.
Hazy dark orange in appearance with a white head. Aroma of belgian yeast, dark fruit and spices. Taste follows nose with a slightly sour finish.

The appearance is a clear orange with a very small white head, and the aroma is fairly light with only hints of Belgian yeast and sour fruit. The taste is mildly sour and slightly sweet, and the palate fuses an average carbonation, medium body, slick texture, and a slightly sour finish.

I am going through a Belgian Ale phase. This beer pours a hazy golden straw with a big white head. Scent is spicy. Flavors are complex mix of lemon, earth, with overall mild sweet flavor. Live yeast makes it nice and lively. Bottle - Sherlock’s - Decatur, GA

Nice solid Belgian style. Orange color. Aroma of banana and some tart apple. Taste is well balanced with Belgian style yeast, spices, sweet orange. Drinkable, with good carbonation. Nothing special but really good.

Tap at New Bohemia. Beautiful appearance characterized by copper color. Little head. Taste is complex. Some spicy qualities. Some hops. Malt is there. Very easy to drink given the alcohol involved. Definitely one of Goose Island’s best. Finish is really solid. I would hook up with this Matilda.
Nice and smooth Classic Belgian flavors. Great palate with medium body and fruity nose.
Pours a nice amber with a thick white head. Nice aroma of fruits. Taste is typical Belgian ale. Nice carbonation. Hint of fruit in the taste. Not very bitter. Just a solid Belgian ale.

2014 edition....

12oz picked up at the COOP... poured into my short goblet 1/2" head dies back quickly.... very clear orange brew... no lacing.

Aroma shows big phenol... clovey and lesser peppercorn... esters are equally large with pear and sweet apricot... doesn’t really gel with me, perhaps too much of everything.

Again... clove phenols.. pear juice.. background toasty malt essence.. The palate is not nearly as pronounced as the nose... really lackluster.

expected body and carbonation... Just an Okay brew.. I’ve had Matilda bunches of times over the years, and am never too impressed.

Bottle, 2012. Dark golden with thick offwhite head. Aromas of banana and marigold, maybe a little sweet bug spray but it smells like summer so that’s ok. More sourness on the back of the tongue and more of that vegetal taste that the aroma predicted. The alcohol is balanced and the mouthfeel is nice, maybe a bit thin. Beautiful label, interesting beer. Glad I tried it but don’t have to have a second.
I noticed this beer can be aged and should’ve read the bottle before I opened it. The flavor, head and taste is pretty unique. A bit sweet for my liking but interesting nonetheless. Neat beer.

Straight filthy. This beer is wonderful. So spicy and sweet and the balance is nuts. Keeps you wondering what’s next. Very complex. As it warms up it just gets more complex and delicious. This is what beer is all about. Taste and craftsmanship. Matilda is just it. I respect Goose Island for what they do. Sometimes I think they stretch too far then I drink Matilda and chill out and just understand. They are so chill and so complex. Excellent beer and an excellent brewery.

La bière a une belle couleur orangée et une mousse onctueuse qui a un goût de levure. À l’odeur, les bretts sont présents avec une odeur aigre et «funky». Mais il y a aussi une odeur sucrée qui fait penser à l’orange. Au goût, c’est l’acidité des bretts qui frappent en premier, puis c’est le sucré d’orange et même un petit côté épicé. Personnellement, je trouve ça divin!
Hazy amber pour with minimal white head. Spice, fruit and hops in the aroma. Spicy hop and fruit taste. Dry citrus hop finish that is slightly sour. A fine beer.
tap. Amber with one finger head. Medium malt body with some Belgian yeast and slight spice.

On draft at HUB 51 in Chicago. A favorite from my Chicago trip. A delicious and American Belgian styled ale that has qualities of yeast, fruit and mild spices. Hops are balanced with mild sweetness and malt.
Bottle, pours a reddish brown with a white head. Fruity taste with a hint of sour and spice. Nice tasting beer.

Tap at O’Hare. Pale amber with a low, fine head. Nose of amber malts, caramel, dry and earthy with minerals, hay, light citrus, light esters. Medium sweetness with peaches, caramel. Turns dry and earthy, with minerals. Crisp and light.
Pours Orange Amber with a thick sticky head. Nose is apples, bit funky. Taste has some citrus and spice, coriander, slightly acidic and a sour finish.

330ml Bottles from Tesco, Hexham; Rehills, Newcastle and The Bottle York.

2020 edition bottled on 12-Jun-2017. Hazy amber coloured with a thick white head of foam that exploded out of the bottle. It has a tart apple and citrus flavour with smooth barnyard and plum flavours on the spicy, warming finish. Excellent!

2011 bottle aged for 6 years. Hazy golden coloured with a large white head of foam. It has a sweet floral fruity flavour with candi sugar and vanilla followed by more spices, lemon and dried fruit on the smooth finish. Excellent and this has aged superbly!

2011 bottle aged for 4 years. A cloudy amber beer with a spicy almond, lemon and vanilla flavour followed by a herbal citrus and smooth earthy finish Superb!

 2011 bottle aged for 3 years. A hazy light amber-golden beer with a zesty fruit and spiced citrus flavour, floral fruity notes and a vanilla, lemon, bubblegum and blackcurrant finish. Excellent!
Belle apparence dorée tirant sur le cuivrée. Beau collet de mousse. Odeur de cuir. Une touche d’acidité en bouche. Déception!

A fusion of two styles that I just don’t feel mesh well. Belgian Tripel and IPA. The caramel and hops from the IPA side get pushed aside by the Belgian flavors. Tart fruit, peppercorn, apple skin, clove and yeast. Sour finish and a bit acidic for my liking. The flavors are all there but not working together.

[Bottle / 2009 / ~4 years old] Thanks, Kevin! Foggy copper with lighter, amber edges, almost fully opaque - only a little translucency when held directly in the light. No head, only a wispy, white collar. Aroma is full of drub, musty funk, damp cellar floor, cobweb, barnyard stalls... Wow! Wasn’t expecting funk like this. Nice balance of tartness in the aroma, too; sharp apple skins, lemon juice, & a hint of acetic vinegar. Taste has lots of damp, cheesecloth funk, abrupt apple skin & stone fruit acidity, lemon flesh, light vinegar, & a strong, tannic, barrel presence in the back-end. Light, effervescent carbonation... puzzled by the lack of head. Not at all what I was expecting from this beer, but it was pretty damn good.



[Tap / 2013 / Fresh] Fresh Matilda is a much more subtle experience. Still funky, still a little tart, but not nearly at such vibrant ends of the spectrum. You could say that makes it more balanced... Because it is. But I think I prefer it with some age. Still a pretty solid brew when fresh, though.



[Bottle / 2007 / ~7 years old] Just outside of 7 years old, likely. Thanks, Ed. Still notable carb, mild head/collar. Aroma is a little faded at this point... Dusty cellar floor, flowers, must, & a small hint of tropical fruit. Taste is softer Belgian yeast with notes of flowers, gum, peach, & a light bit of musty funk. A little past it’s prime, I’d say. Not as good as the 4 year old bottle I first had.

Pours a hazy orange. Nice long lasting head. Smells of banana and apricot with a lingering funk. Taste of pepper, banana, apple and barnyard funk. It has a candied apple/cherry finish. Taste a lot like a cherry jolly rancher. Very dry finish. I'm not usually a fan of the Belgium yeast esters but this one is very manageable. This is a very nice and not too over the top funky beer. It's not the best I've ever had and it surely isn't the worse. It's right in the middle.

2012 vintage. 12 oz bottle into a pint glass.

A: Pours a cloudy orange color. The eggshell-colored head is fluffy and bubbly, about two fingers high. Lacing is splotchy and inconsistent, but definitely exists.

S: This is funky, but not overly so. Notes of earth and...um...funk help balance out its notes of bread, apple, and pear. There’s some spicing which is very subtle, too. While it’s not the most complex, the notes it uses are very well done and very enjoyable.

T: The first flavors are quite fruity, bright, and somewhat sugary. Not only does this bring the typical apple and pear notes, but strong citrusy qualities are also existent. The funk is very subtle, creating a balancing note with its sweeter flavors. The finish is also lightly biscuity. Much like Duvel, it isn’t super complex, it just uses it’s handful of notes brilliantly to deliver a killer drinking experience.

M: As expected, it’s fizzy and light, with no hints of alcohol anywhere. The finish is damn-near bone dry. It’s light enough where it’s pretty damn drinkable.

O: This one is pretty close to Duvel in terms of quality, but perhaps not quite there. Who cares?! It’s still freaking excellent. I’d really be intrigued in aging this one even further, too.

12 oz pour, hazy orange amber hue with tiny particles, medium foamy head, some lacing, smells a bit tart and funky, tastes about the same with some spice (pepper/coriander,) some candy sweetness, yeast come through, more Belgian than pale ale, interesting

Had on draft and had not had in a couple of years, nice funky aroma. Flavor was spicy and tart. Was so funky I asked to taste the Jolly Pumpkin beer next to it just to be sure the beer was not from the wrong tap lol! Great beer spicy tart some pepper.
Had one from a bottle last week and as it warmed took on a fishy odor, I dumped it with about 1/3 left. Tap 4.2- bottle 1.0.

Light amber color with a foamy white head from the tap. Year and spice in the nose. Thick candi sugar sweetness with bitter orange peel, some spice and an almost bread doughy yeast. A bit thin. Nice easy drinking Belgian.
Robust sweet malty Belgian pale ale with a deep amber gold color and slight funky aroma with a slight fizz to the palate. Has a malty bitter sweet long finish.
On draft. Cooper color. Fruity, almost sour aroma. Fruity and sweet taste. Ends very sweet, sugarcane like.

12 oz bottle pours a slightly hazy gold/amber color with small off-white head and not much lacing. Aroma is full of fruit and spices and Belgian yeast: banana, pears, coriander, are the most noticeable. Taste is slightly sweet, with a bit of dryness in the finish. Body is medium with lively carbonation and a slightly sticky mouthfeel. A very satisfying Belgian ale.
On tap. Pours a dark amber with light head. Aromas of burnt resin, fruity esters, and caramelized bananas. Flavors of dried bananas, resin, toasted malts, and light spice. Very nice.
Fairly new bottle so not much Brett character. Spicy apple with some pear maybe banana. Spices definitely. Pepper, coriander. More alcohol presence than I like in a Belgian pale, though.

2009 Bottled. Carbonation greatly reduced. Low aroma of faint citrus and fruits. Caramel flavors are present but not heavy. Canned pineapple flavors border on tart without truly getting there. Beautiful even after four years. Just a touch cloying, but come on. It's old!

Bouteille 765 ml. 7%. Couleur ambrée, mousse beige mince. Arôme de fruits jaunes mûrs et de Brett...paille mouillée, cuir...En bouche, fraîche, elle s’étale en douceur, notes d’épices, de levures, de Brett...un peu de fruits. Excellente en mangeant, se boit bien seule. Très bonne.

Nouveauté au Québec, cette bière des États-Unis a une couleur blond orangé et une mousse épaisse. Au nez, je dénote du foin, des houblons herbeux, des traces de cuir, de levure Brett, un peu d’ananas. En bouche, c’est complexe, puissant : l’ananas et le cuir donnent un goût singulier. J’ai apprécié, mais je ne rachèterais pas. Le goût de cuir et de paille a fini par me tanner à la longue. Cheers!

Bière orangée arborant une myriade de petites particules en suspension ; limpide, mi-épaisse et coiffée d’un petit col de mousse blanche. En nez, levures sauvages, un peu de cuir, de vin blanc et de pêches. Au goût, fruité très présent (abricots confits, pêches, un peu d’ananas), et tout juste piquant en finale. Étonnamment légère et à haute buvabilité, on la voit effectivement bien s’agencer avec une multitude de plats, mais aussi simplement avec un verre. Excellente belge, une des plus accessibles en terme de levures bretts.
Pours a tan color with a small head. Aroma is hops and a little spice. Taste is hoppy on the front and a little spicy on the finish. Tastes more like an American Pale Ale than a Belgian Ale.

Bouteille 765ml. Couleur orangée foncée trouble, mousse beige crémeuse laissant une dentelle éparse. Arôme d’ananas mûrs, levure, cuir, brett. Goût de levure, brett, fruité, paille?, légère acidité. Carbonatation moyenne-faible, corps moyen-dense.

bottle bought at local iga grocery A: funky, vinous, pleasant spiciness, cheesy/wood App: clear dark copper white head nice lacing. t/p: med body with lightly acidic finish. o: great. can’t believe I now have the chance to grab this one so close from home.

Un épais nuages de mousses. Un nez de levure sauvage et d’agrumes. Une belle complexité. Les houblons dégagent des notes de fruits tropicaux accompagné de saveur végétal avec une bonne acidité. Exellente !!!

765ml bottle. Clear dark orange pour with a foamy white head. The brett is strong with this one. Huge wild, funky, barnyardy, cheesy, peppery, leathery nose. Taste is biscuit, citrus, nuts, caramel and more funk. Medium body, good carbonation, smooth texture.

Couleur cuivrée avec un beau col blanc. Nez de céréales d’épices et d’agrumes. Un épais nuage de mousse recouvre une robe dorée aux reflets orangés. Légèrement trouble, on peut y apercevoir de fins sédiments en suspension. Un nez très vif de levure sauvage et d’agrumes surprend. La complexité de cette bière réside dans la merveilleuse symbiose des différentes saveurs qui se côtoient dans chaque gorgée. Les houblons dégagent des notes de fruits tropicaux, les bretts procurent un certain aspect végétal et une bonne acidité et les céréales sucrées qui enveloppent le tout à la fin. Un peu trop pétillante à mon goût, n’empêche que je suis ravi de voir cette bière sur les étagères du Québec.

765ml bottle. Clear pale orange body, medium white head with good retention and lacing. Intense carbonation. Light Belgian nose: yeast, peaches, floral, coriander, pears. Taste is yeasty, very fruity, with oranges, peaches and pears mostly, some sour notes, a leathery aftertaste. Very nice.

Alot of fruitiness in the aroma and taste... Even through the finish... Apple pear..a little funk...a real nice goose offering to go with sofie which is great...I wonder if this is brewed in New York with their main line or Chicago?bottle says Chicago ...mmmmm

(bouteille 765ml - 2013) - Bière orangée coiffée d’une mousse blanche à grosses bulles qui s’affaisse rapidement. De petites particules en suspension sont aussi visibles. Au nez, des parfums d’agrumes (lime?) s’agencent à des vapeurs sauvages qui s’expriment avec retenue. En bouche, une belle complexité de levure belge, plus fruitée qu’animale, s’étale en profondeur. Hazy orange copper pour w/ white head. Banana, citrus, yeast aromas. Flavors include bread, fruit & spicy sour funkiness. Dry finish.

Fast didssapating white head over pretty amberish golden beer. Enticing nose offering sourness, spicy yellow fruit and something bretty, decent intensity. A dry, shallow attack on the palate, underwhelming flavour intensity, offering little of aroma promises. Good spritz, citric acidity, some cideresque bitterness, but it is hollow, lighter than medium bodied and invokes associations to lager. In the finish the apple bitterness lasts a while, but that isn’t too satisfying in my opinion.

On tap.  Amber color with an orange hue.  Small white bubbly head. Overripe fruit aroma, banana, spices. Fantastic malty flavor. Very light hops. Christmasy spices at the end. Light mouth feel. Dry, clean finish.

On tap into a shaker. There?s a spicy yeast aroma that comes through strongest, with some farm-like odors. This is accompanied by some not as strong aromas of creamy tropical fruits, citrus, and earthiness scents. It pours a cloudy copper-gold with a white, puffy head which leaves behind some faint lacing. It?s mostly citrus sweet (medium) with some lighter floral bitterness (medium), and even a light, mellow sour. The first thing noticed in the mouthfeel is the abundant, fizzy carbonation. The crisp, medium body is bready with sour and bitter fruits, toffee, grains, and floral notes. It has a buttery smooth grainy spicy finish and leaves an interesting spicy/floral aftertaste, with some earthy notes; which has some moderate staying power.
Tap. Pour is rich gold color. Aroma of apple, banana, biscuit, and candy. Taste is sweet with a hint of sour.

This pours deep amber, darker for a belgian pale. Hint of sienna shimmer. No head. Minimal ribbons. Just moving over an old review.


2010 Bottle received in a recent trade on the other site poured into a Hair of the Dog tulip glass. This is one of the sour batches and I will be reviewing it based on what it has become, not what it was intended to be.




A - Pours hazy amber orange with a fizzy one and a half finger tall white head leaving little to no lacing down the glass.




S - Lots of sourness up front enveloping almost all the other aroma’s. Aside from the strong sourness their are hints of lemon, pear, green apple, dulled citric hops, and plenty of brett.




T - Starts off with a strong acidic pucker slowly giving way to a mix of chewy bretty yeast, green apple, pear, and some light citric hop bitterness. The finish is bone dry lingering long after the finish. While this beer wasn’t intentionally turned sour it is still a good beer overall.




M - Medium body and flavor with lively carbonation. Strong, acidic, pucker in the feel with a bone dry finish.




O - I am fully aware that this beer isn’t supposed to be sour, but why not? I actually enjoyed this one for what it is. The pucker is strong, and the finish is bone dry, but it still hit the spot.

355ml/12floz bottle into a trappist glass; served cool. Bottled on 18April2013, reviewed on 9December2013.

Aroma: Oranges and sweet tangerines! Spices; I’m not sure how to describe it, it’s faint but reminds me of snickerdoodle cookies. All pretty mild, but pretty nice!

Appearance: Clear orange-yellow body with a semi-persistent, foamy, white head.

Taste: Strong spiced orange flavor. Somewhat yeasty, too.

Palate: Medium body, with a moderate-long spicy finish.

Overall: The subtlety of the aroma cleverly disguised the huge amount of spice and orange/tangerine flavors in the taste. Really good stuff, I enjoyed it a lot!

P: A clear honey glow with floating particles and a small white head. Head vanishes as quickly as it formed and leaves a thin transparent swirl on top. 

S: Honey, bandaids, cinnamon, fruit esters, coriander, barley, melon and a clean yeast strain. 

T/M: Cinnamon apple sauce, metallic taste in the back, orange oil, peroxide, biscuity, pears, powdery yeast, lime, barley, grains of paradise, coriander. Medium body with a prickly carbonated flare finishes semi dry. 

O: A well balanced brew that has great flavor. The spice profile plays well off the earthiness and fruit presence. I’m anxious to grab more and put done age on it.

355ml bottle from Utobeer, Borough Market, London (£4.20):

Strong pineapples strikes you first with this one and the beer is quite juicy on top of that. There is some grapes and citrus notes that follow along with some milder fruits such as some apples, peaches, pear and some floral notes with a touch of funk and some hints of tart towards the end. There is some mango and a little spice too.


Bright orange -amber colour with a pinky-sized, bubbly white head that holds relatively well over the opening minutes and looks to leave some nice lacing on the glass too.


Spicy with some yeast starting things along with a great combination of pineapple and banana that is very fruity and refreshing. There is a great mix of fruits all round, with some mango, apple and pear among others all featuring in this one. I could detect citrus and funk towards the end but in was the fruits that dominated throughout.


Medium bodied with lively carbonation and a fairly sweet, slightly spicy palate and a slight citrus tang too. The beer was pretty smooth with an outstanding balance and the alcohol was completely hidden into the bargain. A great beer and all rounded off with a crisp and refreshing taste.



An outstanding beer and a real surprise if I’m honest, I had been expecting this one to be a good beer but I was taken aback by just how good it turned out to be. A must try.

Nutty, funky, and malty… interesting, yet seemingly as solid as odd compared to others of the style every time I try it



A medium, leathery brown body supports a big, dynamic frothy off-white head leaving delicate, fading bubbly lacing all around, this bottle was a lazy gusher even after spending the night in the fridge

-

An interesting and strange combination of caramel, leathery malt notes with generic barnyard, clove, banana and creamy cheese overtones, generally enjoyed, yet somewhat odd from my perspective, I understand the inspiration for this is coveted, but I’ve also never been able to appreciate the juxtaposition of sweeter brown ales with mundane flares of funk, and more than anything the big cheesy influence just turns me sideways, I’ll take a super pale wild bomb or a vibrant red creamy sour over this muddling combination any day, in an effort to appreciate, I do understand the earthy, almost nutty nature the wild tones spiral off of as a pleasing experience

Sweet yeasty aroma with some lemony and bourbon notes. Hazy amber with a bright white creamy head. Farmhouse yeast, lemon, and hay.
Bottle - Light brown sugar. Bread and some light sourness. Cloudy gold with a rich beige head. Light caramel, fruit esters and yeast. Bret is underwhelming. OK.

Single from the LCBO in a brown wine bottle with a plastic sleeve over the cap, 2013 written on it. Pours an amber colour with loads of tiny particles. The warm frothy head has decent retention and gives out nice sticky lace. Very sour aromas like a lambic with notes of fruity malts and Belgian Ale yeast. Oh wow... was expecting the sourness to continue in the taste, but no. Just the fruity malt and mild yeast. Actually, pretty floral overall in the mouth. Still can’t believe the sour nose does not show at all in the taste. As it breathes, the sourness seems to calm down and spices come out (even light cherries in the aromas). A decent Belgian-style ale, but a little too all over the place. Probably gets better with time.

750 ml. bottle about six months old. It pours a nice deep golden orange with an off white head. The aroma is very fruity with some nice pineapple and dried apricot notes. Light spicy brett. The flavor is very spicy and dry with dried fruit, pineapple and wet hay, horsey brett in the finish. The brett character is very subdued, but adds nice complexity. Great lively mouthfeel. Finishes dry and complex. Loved it.

22 ounce bottle into tulip glass, bottled on 1/20/2012. Pours lightly cloudy golden orange color with a 2-3 finger foamy and rocky off white head with great retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Dense foamy lacing clings on the glass, with some moderate streaming carbonation. Aromas of big pineapple, peach, apricot, orange peel, pear, apple, hay, floral, grass, candi sugar, caramel, pepper, light funk, and yeast earthiness. Fantastic aromas with great complexity and balance of yeast ester, hop, and malt notes; with great strength. Taste of pineapple, peach, apricot, pear, apple, candi sugar, caramel, grass, floral, light funk, light pepper, and yeast earthiness. Slight earthy bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of pineapple, peach, apricot, pear, apple, candi sugar, caramel, grass, floral, light funk, light pepper, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Damn nice complexity and balance of yeast ester, hop, and malt flavors; with a great malt/fruitiness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium-high carbonation and medium bodied; with a very smooth, crisp, and lightly prickly mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is a highly excellent Belgian pale ale! All around great complexity and balance of yeast ester, malt, and hop flavors; and extremely smooth and crisp to drink for the ABV. A highly enjoyable offering.

Bottle 2013 vintage. Pours an amber color with a decent head that fades slowly to nice lacing. Aroma of malt, fruits, some pine and spice with bit of caramel. Taste of malt, some caramel sweetness, citrus, with some fruit and spice in the background. Subtle bitterness and the finish is quite dry. Medium body, smooth with a nice bit of malty character. Nicely balanced as the there is no hint of the 7% ABV. Nice beer for the style.

Pours gold. Nose is tangerine, citrus, fruity. Taste is tangerine, grapefruit, on the sweet side, yeast. Very strange end , kinda metallic. Smells better than it tastes. A little watery. Refreshing but not particularly good. Off taste.

Small head medium carbonation amber pour aromas yeast caramel fruit spice the flavours caramel ginger and some clove a yeast touch sweet and bitter taste lemon a grain note the finish a pale ale and that is that the best tastes malt and yeast yes a typical pale ale

Gingery spice note on a semisweet orange and caramel malt backbone. I can definitely see the beet sugar contributing some flavor too, though maybe that’s a psychological effect from knowing it’s there? Drinks really clean for a 7% abv beer, has a sort of savory quality due to the spice. Great stuff.
Had a year 2009 bottle. I thought it was very good. I didn’t know what to expect but I was happy with this one.

This pour is a real treat: golden fizz with a slinky white cap that laces nightly. Aroma is mix of spice & yeast. Great taste with a nice interpretation of the Belgian style, all sweet yeasty goodness with a sliver of spice & a slight sour twang & an interesting surge of peaches, topped with a vague champagne palate. Great brew as I take out pirates & liberate my insanity in far cry 3.

Tap in hotel in Columbus, pours clear, not much head. Nice aroma, la fun du monde esque. Strong but pleasant. Makes the mind wander in a good way. Thank you Chicago.

Draught. This is a nice Belgian but is over rated in my opinion. Too cloying and not enough aromatics.

2013 batch marked 00:11-02/28/2013. Orange-copper pour with champagne-like sparkling carbonation leading up to a short-lived white fizzy head. The taste is grainy, citrusy, with a moderate bitterness that lingers briefly at the end.

Aroma of apricot and bread. Tastes like clove, banana, mozzarella. Light carbonation, medium body. Long finish fades into light bitterness.

This is a beautiful beer! Pours amber with a quickly dissipating head and no lacing. Nose is dough and cotton candy. Notes of pear, dough, light candy, cereal and some light grassy hops. Taste is light sweet and medium
Bitterness that has some lasting power. Light but somewhat sticky body with lively carbonation and a decently long lasting dry finish.

This is an excellent dark amber selection. Pleasant aroma, spice, fruits, smooth to the palate. Goes perfect with garlic mussels.

Draft. Dark amber pour with a thick white head. Lots of lacing. Nose is yeasty bubblegum, champagne. smooth mouth feel with belgian yeast, some champagne funk. Good run of the mill belgian. 12oz bottle. Pours a bright coppery orange color with a medium white head that drops fairly quickly leaving a bit of spotty lace. Fruity sweet aroma with a nice yeasty character, mainly apples and pears notes, with some light floral scents in the mix. Taste starts off a bit fruity sweet with some funky yeast notes to complement the fruit. Floral and earthy hop notes are light but present. Ends with a spicy sweet finish that is a bit dry. Mouthfeel is medium bodied, medium carbonation, smooth.
Had on tap at their place on Clybourn in Chicago. Pours amber with minimal head. Spicy and slightly tart. Nice beer. Had on tap and bottled.

2010 vintage bottle. Pours hazy copper-brown with a very thin white dissipating head, very fine clinging lacing. Aromas of dark cherry, leather, and oak, some floral notes, dough, and banana. Medium body, smooth, low carbonation. Medium sweet, light tartness, a hint of bitterness, with some black pepper spice in the finish. It sounds like the carbonation issue may not be due to aging. Really nice, complex yet mellow.

Bottle. The beer comes across as a hint of sour and heavy yeast. Not getting any fruit nor hop aroma. Interesting beer flavor.

Botttle pour. Nose sweet malt spice peach. Taste sweet up front some fruit then peppery spice and bitter finish.
Blue cheese body odor aroma. Med full bodied but thins out in finish with hot phenols. Bad finish and lingering off flsvors. Maybe a bad vintage (2013).

12 oz bottle of 2012 vintage from Westholme Stores, Goring. Clear amber with a controlled white head; pleasant Belgian yeast aroma; clean in the mouth with some fruit, but a predominiately yeasty taste; and a dry finish with a touch of spice.
