Bottle from Vinmonopolet Bestilling enjoyed at home

Copper hazy, big frothy white head. Smells of brett, some kind of funk of the non messy part, other belgian yeast esters, malts and some fruity notes. Moderate sweet, fruity, a bit of funk, yeast notes, no dry mouthfeel. Moderate bitter. Very nice belgian with brett. Wonder what this would turn out to taste in a year or two?

Pours an organic orangish color with light tan head. Smell is spice, tart fruit and a bit of spoiled vegetation. Taste is spice, sweet tart fruit, green apples, a bit of the spoiled vegetation in the nose ending a bit dry. Medium body and nice subtle carbonation.

12oz bottles, on the road and as last resort in an overpriced bar without taps in Chicago. Shy fruit and spice in the aroma blends into a convincing malt-forward whole in the taste of spice, well-placed (pale) ale hops, cane sugar, caramalts and a rich, creamy palate. Clean and expertly executed cover version of a Belgian ale, putting Belgian yeast to proper flavour-defining use, and that outdoes some originals in drinkability. Slightly reminscent of a yeast-improved spéciale belge, a still underrated style. Was this even better before ABInbev took over?
On tap at the Mayor of Old Town. Orange and hazy appearance with a white head. Aroma and flavor of bananas, Belgian yeast, spices, pepper, light fruit and sugar.

(2010) 35,5cl bottle from Redmonds of Ranelagh. Bright, cloudy orange tinted amber, white head, fizzy, doesnt last. Big sour nose, sherbet, candi sugar, rhubarb, gooseberry, granny smith apples and leather. Very impressive. Lots of spice in the flavour, cinnamon stands out, some dark fruits, a little plum and raisin. Texture is dry, really fizzy as per the style. Great big body but alcohol is well hidden, except for a little warming note in the finish. Finish is long and a little oily and estery. This is really good, I should drink more Belgian style ales.

On draft at The Brass Tap Carrollwood, tulip glass.
Light aroma. Dark amber appearance. Light sweetness. Medium body, soft carbonation. Overall a good competitor for a belgium.
Poured as a taster at Vintage Cellar - aroma is nice with a bit of malt and spices, tastes are malty, bit of spice, bit of hops. Tasty stuff.
Rated from backlog. Dark amber. Small creamy white head. Lasting. Citrus, pear, caramel, some spice. Soft and creamy. Nice balance. Mild bitter finish. Clean and refreshing.
Bottle. Pours light amber with slight off white head. Aroma of floral hops with a slight spice hint. Taste of floral taste.

Aroma: On a sour / acid base we can find sugar cane, flowers, bubble gum, apple and banana. Superb complexity despite the acidity. Very wide palette.
Appearance: Clear golden blond with a thick off white head, starting very sparkling and transforming itself into a beautiful foam. Lasting is quite long and the foam is sticking to glass leaving a small lacing.
Taste: Sourness is smooth and opening for apple, pear and floral flavors. A little herbal bitterness is giving a little dry finish. Complexity of aroma is not repeating in flavors so well but remains interesting. An excellent balance between sugar and sourness. One of the few sour ales that I find delicious.

Tallahassee, Fl - ABC Fine wine & Spirits - 12 oz bottle. Pours a slightly murky medium copper with a thin off-white head that clings to the edge of the glass. Aroma is very off-putting and difficult to get around - reminds me of overripe fruit and baby diapers. Fortunately the flavor improves somewhat with some light cognac notes, a hint of apricot fruitiness, some faint nutmeg-like spices, a touch of caramel sweetness, a bit of booziness in the background. Mouthfeel has a nice thick smoothness to it. Drinks much stronger than 7.0% ABV. Once you get past the aroma, not that bad of a beer.
Poured froma tap with amber orange brown color. Citrus and spice in the taste. Excellent beer

2011 bottle about 2.5 years aged. Very smooth. Crisp mouthfeel and lingering flavor on the palate. Some citrus and apple flavor. Malt forward but well balanced.

Source : Richard’ Grocery

From a growler with my dad. Light orange pour with a white head. Aroma is a little alcohol, sweet, caramel, and kinda yeasty. Taste is honey, light fruit, spice, and just a little heat.

Pours a hazy golden with a thin white head that leaves some lacing. First aroma of leather and pineapples. Subsequent whiffs are mostly made of tropical fruits, light dustiness. Taste is fruity and overall Orval-esque, quite nice! Body is low to medium and carbonation is high. A bit too high for me. A really great product that I will never scroll past from now on!
Slightly hazy orange pour with a nice white head of fine bubbles. Aroma is banana and sawdust. Taste is spice, banana, and slightly funky. Soft carbonation. Good beer.

Pours a clear gold from the bomber with fluffy white head that leaves moderate lacing. Aroma is dirty, funky laundry, earth and hay, muddy. Taste follows, earthy and funky. Solid brett beer, I’m impressed compared to their regular stuff.

Golden copper with little head. Aroma is sharp of fruit. A little yeasty in flavour the palate is decent but verging on watery. Flavour a little fruity and malty.

2012: Aromas of faint brett character. Cloudy golden orange color with off white head that dissipates quickly. Nice soft mouthfeel with tropical brett character, nice bitterness. Good lacing touch of caramel sweetness nice overall.

On tap at frontera ORD. Poured into goblet. Carmel color with half a finger of almond head that quickly dissipated but left solid lacing. Bananna, malt, yeast aromas. Up front spices, yeast, and funkier than I expected. Finishes with a little apricot sweetness.

It pours copper with golden highlights; the head is bone-coloured and mousse-like. The aroma has notes of: candied-apricots, sourdough, lemon-juice, and barnyard funk. The taste is light sweet, that finishes light tart; there are notes of: sweet grains, candied apricots, grapefruit-zest, and strange(albeit pleasant) yeasty notes. The palate is medium-light bodied, has light carbonation, and a medium yeasty finish. Overall, I don’t normally say this but the merit of yeast flavours supersedes the lightness of the beer.

Crystal clear golden pour. Light white head. Fruity and spicy aroma. Green apple. Lemon. Grassy. Flavor is yeasty but not overwhelming. Grassy. Fall spices. Clean finish.

Pours amber, aroma of citrusy lemon, taste initially sour, blends into earthy finish

This is a very nice beer. I have had two 2013 bottles and one was really good and the other was just ok. Waiting to try a 2009. Thanks Kevy for the 09. It is a very different beer with 4 years on it. Much more tart. Still very good.

Almost an excellent beer. What is good? The flavor and mouthfeel. Delicate fruit and malt flavors. What is wrong? The terrible rotting protein aroma.

This has always been one of my go-to beers. I will admit though, its better as a draft style beer. This is a must try for any Blegian style beer fan!
Bottle. Belgian yeast, lemon, and malt aroma. Hazy golden yellow with moderate head. Sweet lemon, yeast and malt flavor. Very nice.

Matilda 2013: Belgian Pale Ale. A beautiful amber color with light carbonation but no real head. Great aroma, almost allspice like with floral & grape notes... The taste is a sweet malty base with fruity & spicy belgian yeast notes, a full mouthfeel & an effervescent carbonation. Lots of fruit flavor, a wonderful beer.

750mL luibucbjdo bottle. Pours a semi-hazy amber with a huge beige head that grows. Aroma is very fascinating, a blend of dank weird yeast with some rich malt character underneath that almost makes sense. The flavour is less intense than I was expecting, with way less yeast flavour than the aroma indicated. Very sharp, perfume-y, with a huge malt body underneath that is very tasty. Feels somewhat thick on the palate but not huge. Interplay of the yeast and malts is very interesting, this must age well. The balance is just fucking scrumtralescent. Hops don’t factor in very much but provide a nice background. Very good, worth having again, the only thing holding it back from a higher rating is that it seems somewhat subdued overall.
Pours deep gold with a fluffy white head. Complex aroma and taste with yeast, plum, spice, caramel, citrus.

On tap @ Goose Island in O’Hare. Pours bright amber caramel with very thin head. Aroma is rich roasty caramel malt with sweet floral yeasty after notes. Taste is clean medium caramel malt with nice nutty undertones. Dry floral yeasty finish. Not much hops, nor did I expect any. Abv matches the body well.

Tap at Tesori in Chicago. Pours medium amber with mild lingering thick head. Nose is a bit sharp but appropriate to style. Medium body and great mouthfeel. Notes of malt and clove predominate but has warm sweet bready fullness with some yeastiness. Not too heavy though. Pretty good - would try again. ---Rated via my mouth

Excelente Belgium golden Strong ale americana. Cor alaranjada com ótima formação de espuma. Aroma cítrico, herbáceo, notas de fermento belga. A Belgian Ale purchased at LCBO. Comes in a big wine bottle, well balanced.

Draft at Mac’s Place in Charleston. Light amber pour with a large rocky white head. Fruity, grape, and yeast dominated aroma with touches of spice a Belgian candy sugars. Flavor presents spicy yeast dark fruits, plum, candy sugar and maltiness. Complex character and medium bodied. Good stuff.

Beautiful deep gold color. Aroma is slightly phenolic with some marzipan notes. Malty but not particularly sweet. Wonderful, medium bodied beer. Would be excellent with Chicken or a rich eggs benedict.

Bottle, Embrun LCBO. Dark yellow, fluffy, foamy white head. Spicy, fruity, and sweet sugar aroma. Yeast as well. Some floral and perfume notes. Taste - yeasty up front, lots of fruitiness, and then a really nice gentle sweetness accentuated by some fruity hops. Maintains the dry yeasty Belgian characteristic you would expect, but adds a really unique sweetness and fruity hop character. Very original and well done.
November 2012. Bottle. Straw yellow color with a large white head, Aromas of light fruit, yeast, malt. The fruit shows well all the way through to the lightly hoppy finish.

Une courtoisie de Viper666. Une bouteille datée du 03/08/2012 qui porte le numéro 1119. Une robe orangée et passablement embrouillée. Un bon col mousseux qui finit par tomber après quelques minutes. Un nez de fleurs bretteuses, de céréales caramélisées et de blé suri. Un goût très peu bruyant, légèrement boisé, ni trop sucré et sans être trop funky, plutôt facile et aimable avec des notes douces de céréales caramélisées qui transportent des flaveurs de fruits à chair jaune et orange. Une bouche à la belge. Une texture en mousse. Une finale sur un parfum de cuir légèrement sucré.  Loin d’être exceptionnelle, cette bière se laisse boire plutôt facilement.
My favorite beer from the Vintage Series. Subtle Brett character. bottle dated 2013
Surprisingly light body. Nice banana and fruit aroma. Complex for a lightish body. Really good. (2010 vintage)

Hazy Amber pour, huge 4 finger head. Aroma of orange, lemon, banana, spice, yeast, barnyard, musty. Fruity and spicy, orange, pear, green apple, corriander, yeast, barnyard funk - a lot happening here. Fairly carbonnated, dry mouthfeel. Lots of lacing left behind. Glad the infection problems have been cleared up!

Pours a nice orange amber color with a white foamy head. Aroma is nice of caramel, spice, orange and malt. Flavor is a little thin with notes of orange, yeast, malt. Finish is relatively clean. Mouthfeel is thin and carbonation is below average. Overall this is a decen tbeer.
Dark amber. Small creamy white head. Lasting. Citrus, pear, caramel, some spice. Soft and creamy. Nice balance. Mild bitter finish. Clean and refreshing.

Bouteille de 650ml #1119 brassée le 3/08/2012. Bière orangée avec une mousse beige et discrète. Le nez est de brett boisé. Une touche de caramel sucrée est bien présente tout comme ce côté fruité. En bouche le liquide ne fait pas de compromis et se laisse boire tout seul, l’effervescence aidant. Les saveurs dominantes sont le caramel, le bois, les fruits et les bretts. Entre une valse avec Matilda (Waltzing Matilda) manger une carbonade Flamande avec Madame Rose ou me retrouver dans un scandale à la Polanski avec Lolita (Nabokov) devinez dans les bras de qui je me laisserai tomber ?

2009 Vintage. Tasted 19 June 2013. 
Appearance: Amber yellow towards light brown, some sediments.
The aroma was this beer’s strongest asset, displaying a great, fruity, wine-like nose: Lots of hops but also sweet, rounded light caramel-like malt aromas.
Taste: Rounded, light sweetness.
Palate: Medium body, rather creamy mousse / carbonation. Medium long finish. 
An interesting and good beer but perhaps not very Belgian (for those who care about labels and categories). Age (4 years) seems to have served it well.

Draft to taster. Looks solid; a transparent gold with foamy white head. Smells of Belgian yeast, light hops, and spices with a fairly sweet backbone. Tastes like it smells with an average mouthfeel. Some herbal notes too. Pretty bland.

Good Belgian.  I am not crazy about the rest of the beers I have had from goose island, but I like this one (others are not bad, just not in my wheel house).  I know AB bought a stake in this company, but I doubt that impacts the bottle of Matilda I enjoyed tonight.  I usually like my Belgians a little hotter than this one is, but a break from the really high abv won’t kill me.  Good job, will buy again.

Glowing amber color. Fruity smell, Smooth with a spicy, yeast fruit finish that pulls dry right at the end. It takes your palate and your taste buds through two different journeys and then has them meet up right at the end. Great.

Pours light amber, creamy head.  Sweet biscuit malt, Belgian yeast, and floral hops in nose.  Slightly sweet.  Middle is spice (nutmeg?), light wood, banana.  Finish is sweet and malty with subtle hop tang.  Good Beer.
Sweet and malty saison with lots of sugary notes but a nice fruity complexity to the finish.  Not a saison as I had expected but still nice.

Honestly, I had high hopes when I read the word "brettanomyces" on the label.  


Pours a hazy golden color with a generous white head.  Aromas of lemon, banana flavored baby food and some tranny fluid (not the automotive type).  Taste is slightly sweet with just a hint of sour.  Pretty refreshing, but not as good as you jokers make it out to be.

Bottle. Pours a clear deep amber. Weak white head with minimal retention and lacing. Smells of malt, yeast, fig, apricot, banana, weak caramel. Tastes of malt, fig and banana upfront, caramel finish, slight bitter. Very unique. Medium carbonation and silky finish. Very interesting brew. Need to try on tap.

2013/06/09 - Pours a hazy, dark orange copper color with a thin, soapy, white head. Aroma is biscuit, pears, hay and barnyard. Taste is a pleasant mix of sweet pears, apples, spices and barnyard funk. Mouthfeel is medium with medium to high carbonation.

Very good Belgian Ale. Bottle. Pours a nice amber colour, with almost no head. Light body.
Really good Belgian with flavors of caramel, malt, barley, floral hops, and nicely carbonated.
Very sweet and very bretty that cancel each other out, another great beer from Budweiser

Bottled	28/05/13.  A reddy brown coloured beer with an off-white head and lace.  A typical Belgian Ale.  Yeasty and slightly sweet and sour.  Flowery Saazy hops and moussey fruit.  Highish carbonation - it did gush a little.  Pleasant enough but fairly ordinary to be truthful.
Bottle share. Hazy yellow gold. Aroma of barnyard and spices. Taste is malty, yeasty, spices, funk. Barely wine?
Bottle. Clear amber color, no head. Faintly yeasty nose. Fizzy carbonation, light body. Gentle hop finish. Tastes lighter than it’s ABV, very drinkable.

Draft @ The Barley Pub with a hefty price tag of $10.50 for a tulip, Damn that hurts! Color is a deep burnt orange with small soapy, white head. Aroma of dried fruit, spice and mild barnyard. Flavor is Belgian yeast, candy sugar and mild floral hops. Medium bodied with a sweet finish. I liked this beer, just not for this price tag. I could find a 22 oz. bottle for the same price or less. I’m sure this would also age nicely in the cellar as well.

765 ml bottle from LCBO.  Pours a modestly hazy golden orange with average slightly off-white head.  Aroma is fruity and yeasty with some sweet caramel.  Flavour is tropical fruit including pear, sweet caramel, spice and gentle earthy hops.  Very easy drinking for 7%.  Solid.
Smells like shit. literally. A little too watery, seltzer-ish on the tongue. Otherwise, light coffee notes, fizzy, not too yeasty, leaves and grass. Lingers with warm chocolate notes.

Pours a lightly hazed deep gold ale with  puffy white cap that lasts a while and reduces to a surface lace. Medium carbonation from bottle conditioned priming. Aroma is demure but it has pleasant apricot tones riding over some musty hop notes and a hint of sweetness. Flavour follows aroma with the fruity-apricot flavor meeting some spice and earthiness, malts are found in the finish - odd but different and pleasant. A decent rendition of a Belgian Pale that has promise for improvement with cellaring.

the best of both worlds. Pale Ale with Belgian love. 
Sweet fruity top with slight hop below.
Pours golden with a puffy creamy head.
Taste is a hoppy fruit salad. YUM.
A solid above average brew.
On tap at the airport in Chicago. Golden with a thin lacing head. A bit of butterscotch, with a thick golden malt and a spicy finish. Delicious.

Tap in Butcher & The Boar, Minneapolis. Deep orange brown, hazy, thick white head. Quite a full flavoured Belgian style, fruity, boozy, spicy, big yeast presence but more fruit/spice than sour. Moderate hop finish, maybe just enough to stop it being cloying. It’s not bad as a nightcap beer.

Re-rate, bottle in Gibson’s Chicago. It’s nice, fruity, spicy boozy. Heavier than most real Belgians, if that makes sense. Pleasant with food.
Poured from a bomber.  Belgian yeast with orange peel notes.  Overall, a very enjoyable Belgian ale.

Very nice orange-gold body with decent beige head.  Great hoppy aroma, with hints of orange in the notes. Smells very much like a complex orange-juice tonic... appealing, eh? The flavour is a strong barley-orange mix with a simple dry finish, a great Belgian-style brew, more like an orange schnapps experience. Decent finish. This is a great orange-style heavy Belgian brew, a nice reminiscence of what life was like back there. But nonetheless a little heavy and overbearing.
The best part of this beer is the spicy flavor. You get the sweet hops, with an incredible spice finish.

2010 vintage.  Its a nice beer.  Sweet in flavor beet flavor comes through with dark malt.  Yeast is not the dominant flavor.  Light malted yeast aroma.  Slight tart on back of tongue but in a pleasant way.  actually a very very good belgian..

One finger head that fads quickly,rusty amber look,some carbination here there,smell reminds me of some Belguim beer. Like some abby triple,dubble tyoe thing not pale ale. Smells like it’s gummy,sweety,fruity. Taste nowhere near as sweet as I thought,a little watery,a bit spicy and a bit fruity. It’s fine,but I don’t think it\’s super amazing or anything. Cheer’s.

765mL bottle from LCBO.  Yep, 765.  Pours clear amber with a thin head.  Light malty aroma with slight spice and tons of noble hops.  As it warms I pick up sour/tart notes.  The taste starts with noble hops and spices, and leads into a tart finish.

Bottle [765ml]. Pours a slightly hazy copper-gold with an average size long-lasting fizzy off-white head. Minimal lacing. Aroma of fruit, lightly sour grain, light grassy hops, yeast, herbs and spices. Flavour is grassy and herbal, a bit sweet and yeasty, and finally there’s some citrus and a light bitter finish. Average to medium . Pretty good, nothing amazing but enjoyable enough.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

March 11, 2009, vintage -- 12 oz bottle -- The label says this develops in the bottle for up to 5 years and I popped it a bit past the four-year mark. At this point, the yeast absolutely dominates the aroma with hints of newly mowed grass and lemon. The taste is just so smooth with little bits of sweetness and bitterness dancing around the edges. Excellent. Wish I had a few more of these hidden but guess I’ll have to start over with my next trip to the beer store.
Love the brett and fantastic balance going on in this, fruit and some earth and mineral and a brisk effervescent freshness with a nice edge of dry from hop and the conditioning yeast.

Appears on the brassy side of copper amber with loads of sparkle and a thinnish covering  of off-white head. Has typically fruity, sweaty, sour Belgian yeast aromas. Sour citrus and basement prominent on nosing. Silky mouthfeel with some prickly carbonation. All the aromas manifest themselves in the flavour profile along with orange juiciness and tart, tangy malts. Lingering sourness carries the finish on and on.
Pours light copper with white frothy head. Aromas of earthy hops, yeast, melon and citrus. Similar taste with a bretty taste. Nicely balance with the alcohol.

Sweet belgian yeast, cloves, sweet malt on the nose. Clear copper, thin, short-lived head. Taste yields some interesting sour/tart notes that weren’t apparent in the nose upfront, clean middle and a belgian yeast/slightly spicy finish. Slightly hoppy at the end prevent this beer from being cloying. Medium body, carbonation. Not bad.

750 mL bottle.  Pours copper with a foamy white head.  Aromas of citrus, melon,  herbal hop, yeast and brett funk. Mild malt sweetness well balanced by alcohol bite and earthy hop. Tasty now but would like to see this age up and develop more brett character.
Pours an amber brown with decent head and lacing... Into a chalice... Sweet, slightly spicy nose... Smooth, abv is barely noticed... Good beer... Probably on my faves out of all theit belgium styles

Fidelis sourfest 2013. This bottle is from 2010. Lacto Matilda 04/16/2010. One day before my birthday.  This stuff is pretty infected. Sour as all hell. Best unintentional sour ever. Lots of funky funky yeast flavors going on. Good.

Apricot orange w/ tiny bubbles that linger on the glass. Medium hops. A deceivingly smooth 7%. Pronounced spice notes. Light fruitiness, but too light to pinpoint specific flavors.

650 ml bottle.  Pours a golden bronze with a minimal white head.  Taste is of wheat, yeast, fruit, spice, hops, pine, resin, caramel and grape.  Has a decent slick body.  The finish is spicy and warming.  Good, but a touch underwhelming.
Draft. Pours cloudy golden brown. Full body. Mild sweetness. Taste of dried fruit. Medium carbonation. Smells like raisins and spices.

From bottle at HOTB. Nice funky nose, sweet with a bit of vapor and light woody notes. Mild Brett. Medium golden clear with light haze, topped with big fluffy head. Medium body with medium carbonation. Starts light sweet with caramel, honey, and a bit of funk. Yeasty with alcohol vapor and honey. Light sweet funky after.

12 oz bottled 11/28/2012. Honey gold color with a thin white head.  Aroma of sweet candy, bread, belgian yeast, and fruit. Sweet and spicy. Just how I like it. Nice sweet malts, fruity, floral, a bit of bread, with a nice subtle spiciness. Nice lingering spicy dry finish.  Great pick for rate 250! Very enjoyable.

Bright orange-amber color with a fluffy white head that dissipates quickly. Aroma of Belgian yeast with big banana notes. Sweet and fruity with a little pepper.  Pretty mellow mouthfeel - could use more carbonation in my opinion.

Bottle 2012 Tomlinson’s Inverness [130413]

Aroma of soft Belgain yest, sweet pale malts, some floral esters, bit of honey, slight cereal note, touch of funk, very soft lemon

Taste as aroma, soft aromatic fruity malts, soft sweet cereal, alcohol well hidden, soft spicy hops, light bready malt, hint of apricot, light honey, mellow belgian yeast, I like this

Overall - Soft mellow sweet but quite complex beer - it’s good
Part of a build your own sixer.  A little expensive for what it’s worth, but this is a spicy belgian style

Bottle at Fox and Hound in Erie.  Pours golden with filmy white head, dissipating to a running white film.  Nose is apple, lemon and some bubble gum.   Unknowingly sweet, candy apple, strawberry Big League Chew, pear.  Rather dry and unassuming.  Tasty.
floral and spicy. very easy to drink with a great balance of light sweetness and subtle alcohol taste and mouthfeel.
Golden appearance with a thin white head. Aroma is light and slightly floral. Flavor is light fruit esters with notes of spice. A little peppery in the finish.

This poured hazy and amber with not so much carbonation and just a finger of foam. Good lace.  Really fruity and floral nose on this beer.  I can smell the pilsner malt and I love that. It’s got a little booze in the nose but I’m not offended. There’s some caramel as it warms, a little spice and a bit of cinnamon.  This beer is very rich on the palate. Orangey, Belgian yeast, musty, then pepper and coriander and hop bitter.  Really well played like good hand in cards.  Malt is pretty sweet and  the body is a touch syrupy.  This one is pretty wild with complexity but never disintegrates.  Nice balance, crisp dry finish and puts bitter and honey together with a brett character and is inviting and intoxicating
Pours burnt orange with white head.  Aroma is floral, Belgian yeast, citrus and earthy.  Taste is sweet with a tart citrus finish.   Medium bodied with an oily mouthfeel.
Pours amber with a fair amount of head. Lots of spice and fruit on the nose. Lots of malty flavor with a bit of spicy hop finish. Pretty delicious for happy hour
Nice and spicy with a sweet malt finish. Has a small hop finish and a slightly crisp mouth feel

A light golden ale with a crisp white head. The fruits are spicy with a nice pop on the palate. The finish is clean. Overall there are similarities to a complex wine. This would probably rock if aged a few years.

2012 bottle, 11C. Orval glass. Orangish amber with a thick cream head that lasts well. Fruity aroma with nectarines, lemon pudding, spices, a little caramel. Sweet caramel and nectarines, less citrus than suggested in the aroma, lots of spices, a fair bit of bitterness, slightly zingy sourness.Lacks that light, dry intensity of what it apes. Less convincing as it warmed. Probably like it better with a year on it.
33cl bottle thanks to iantbonewilson. Copper color with Thin to medium head. Medium but soft carbonation. Light caramel, malty aroma. Nice!
I liked it, but i didn’t think it was super special. Maybe i just think Belgian ales all taste the same...

Uploading old ratings that were missing comments. Yeasty and lots of dark fruit notes. Full palate and very rich.

12 oz bottle..Pour is gold with a nice white head..Nose is belgian spice,clove,spice,swetness..Taste is spice,clove,spice,yeast,refreshing,herbal..Palate is sweet

Aroma of coriander, spice, and Belgian yeast. Pours a transparent amber with a foamy rapidly depleting white and spotty lacing. The taste is a fruity sweetness. Fruit, malt, spice, coriander, Belgian yeast, with a slight grainy finish and aftertaste. I missed the hop presence. Medium body and medium carbonatin. Overall, very enjoyable and drinkable.

Hands down the best beer I’ve ever had from Goose Island et. al. Very fruity, slightly spicy, with some malt presence that doesn’t overpower. Pours a nice copper, tan color, with a thin head. Delicious yeast flavor, not too grainy. Damn.

Guess who’s new to Texas!  I have a bottle of Matilda that I’ve been holding on to for a while that my wife bought in Michigan, and low and behold I ran into it on tap at the Tap Exchange in San Antonio.  It’s time to do a fresh review of this baby.  It pours a gorgeous, bright golden orange color with a billowy white head that leaves behind some great, messy lacing.  It has a wet, grainy wheat-like aroma that almost smells like a soured wicker basket.  Nice.  In the mouth, though, it’s a real surprise at first sip.  There’s something a little plant-like about it, a little sticky and fruity, but still very powerful of slightly soured grains.  Still, it finishes not sour at all, very clean and more sweet than not, with a delicious, hard candy-like stickiness that hangs around the roof of the mouth for quite a while.  It must be the candi sugar.  Er, sorry, beet sugar.  The hops really help spice things up, and the thinness of the beer seems to turn this beer into more of a hop oil delivery system than anything.  Very nice, and really impressive!

12 Fl. Oz. Bottle (2012). Poured cloudy copper with a huge white head. Sweet aroma of citrus fruits, caramel, malts and yeast (typical to Belgian beers). Taste is also sweet easy to drink; caramel and fruits a bit of sourness towards the end. Nice brew.

Bomber->trappist.  Hazy copper with small offwhite head.  Aroma of clove, ginger, citrus, yeast and spice blend.  Flavor is ginger, clove, citrus, yeast.  High carbonation with a sour finish.  Very interesting.

Sample pour from a 22 ounce bottle, aeomas of light toffee, hops, fruit and aome spice.  Flavors arw the same, dark fruits with some spicy yeast, light black pepper.  Nice beer overall I should try to get some more.

355 ml bottle.

Originally rated on 20090730.

Pours copper color with a medium head. Aroma of caramel, toffee, malts, ripe fruits and yeast. Flavor of yeast, caramel malts, toffee and some fruity notes. Nice.
Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy light amber color with a moderate head. Nose has that weird Belgian sweetness to it. Taste is a little bit sweet, but very average, especially for the style. Meh.

33 cl bottle vintage 2009 @ home. Bottled on 18.09.2009

Aroma has toffee typical to aged Belgian Ales, some apricot, plums and grainy note. Flavour has plums, some overripe aprifot, ripe fruits, some toffee and hints of peppery spices. Also the same off‐flavour I observed in an aged bottle of Mikkeller It’s Alive! The sour aroma I liked about this is gone. Better fresh, but not bad in this way either.

Compared a 2010 and 2014 bottle side by side.  Fresh bottle was a mostly clear golden orange with a persistent white head that settled to a film.  2010 bottle was very murky amber with same white head that settled to a ring and dollop. Aroma of 2014 has Belgian yeast fruitiness and some caramel sweetness along with slight coriander and phenolic note.  2010 aroma has tart apple and pear with a vinyl quality and hint of grain.  Taste of fresh bottle has Belgian yeast fruitiness, clove, some toastiness and mild pepper.  2010 bottle has a mild tartness with some faint lemon and apple fruitiness, some grain and some cooked vegetable flavor.  Mouthfeels are different also with new bottle being more creamy and full bodied while the older bottle is more crisp and carbonated with a lighter body.  I much preferred the newer bottle to the older one and really enjoyed the 2014’s flavors. 
 
2013 Pours a dark golden orange with big soapy head that sticks around and great lacing.  Aroma of juicy fruit barnyard and clove spiciness.  Taste starts with some sweet fruit like apricots, then the funkiness sets in mid palate with the clove and pepper.  Decent amount of bitterness and a phenolic flavor.  Medium bodied with an oily texture and lively carbonation.  Finishes dry.  Good but a bit too much of the phenolic flavor to make it a favorite.  
 
---Jeremy H

Bottle pour into tulip..bottle date 1/2/13...great copper color..like a very clean fresh penny..head recedes to a slight white filmy coating on top..quite enticing aroma..Belgian fruit goodness..just enough carbonation and action ...perhaps some cinnamon and clove..mouthfeel is quite smooth and silky..finish is marked by a good bit of the spice punch balanced out with some tartness...quite a tasty offering and a nice hybrid of several styles..definitely would pick this up more often it was more readily available locally..

Not a bad beer out of goose island.  Has a real unique taste that is hard to describe. I would have to say it is really fruity. Pours golden yellow

Pours a deep reddish golden color with a decent sized fluffy beige head that slowly dissipates to a cap on top. had at the chilli fest in galveston. can’t remember the last time i had a beer like this. super refreshing but with a barnyard type flavor. interesting

On draft at the Dutch with lunch.  Yum.  this stuff went well with the crab cake sangwich.  Light coriander nose.  Thin head. 2012 Bottle; Matilda is my daughters name, also a 2012 vintage, so how could I resist?

2012. Fantastic nose, festive spice, a hint of strawberry and white peach and a lovely yeasty undertone. Lovely golden appearance with lots of lacing.

The soft fruits from the nose carries through into the taste, with a hint of grass and spice with a wonderful candy finish. The Belgian yeast is prominent and suitably delicious. The beer has wonderful depth in taste.

A suitably excellent beer: The second best Matilda from 2012 :) 

Botlle: A 12 month old on my daughter’s first birthday. The beer has not improved as much as I hoped after 12 months in the cellar. The nose has now become much more vinious, and the soft tones I noted last year have been subsumed by a lot of green apple, and more vinious and sherry notes. Down rating, sorry Tilly :( .


2020 a bottle from Tesco and bottled 3 years ago! Nose is brett, honey, funk, cherry, pastry. Taste is a clean brett, lots of funk, floral, banana fruit, leading to earthy spice, dry (presumably the brett) with the last remains of the candy sugar, cloves, pepper and spice in the finish.  Very different than my previous experiences with the beer - not sure if it;s changed or I have in the last 8 years - probably both.

Bottle. 12 oz. I drank this while Janine drank Sophie. Pours orange-ruby pinkish with a huge, fluffy, tightly-bubbled white head. Aroma of ripe strawberries, funky yeast, and some subtle grassy hops. Tastes very much like light strawberry tartness, subtle lemon sourness, and a bit of dusty yeastiness, which carries through into an odd spice flavor in the finish. Body is fairly full with a hell of a lot of carbonation. This is really nice and fairly unique, especially for a Belgian ale. I’ve had this on tap when it was sour, which this was not, but I guess it is fairly young. The date on the bottle is 04/04/2012.

Boy is that a pillowy head! Beautiful lacing. Deep golden color with a slight haze. The very standard spicy citrus aroma. That candy sugar thing happening in nose and taste.  Nice texture...lingers on the palate. Mild, drop hop finish.

From notes - 10/23/2012 - Sample pour of hazed amber with full white head.  Nose is Belgian yeast, pineapple, tropical and sweet but pretty smooth.  Flavor is sweet and smooth again, with Belgian yeast coming through healthy.  I’m not a Belgian yeast kinda guy normally.  Flavor is tropical fruit, pineapple, maybe some guava?  Not sure.  Light and smooth with light lacing.  Not bad.

Bottle from Mari’s.  Pours crystal clear orange with a finger of off white head that sticks around a bit.  The aroma has orange peel, lemon zest, brown sugar, some dark fruit notes, molasses.. but overall the citrus is in the forefront.  The taste is spicy like a saison almost.. but there is a good bit of hoppiness, orange, grapefruit, cinnamon spiciness. This is a very nice beer like the rest of Goose Island’s Belgian styles.

Pours a cloudy orange rust color with a small fully carbonated head. Nose is sweet, fruity and yeasty with a bit of mild spice. Taste very typical of a Belgian beer, unfortunately not my favorite style, pungent and yeasty. Finish is short and slightly sour. Not my taste, but nice for a Belgian Ale. Quaff Score 6 / 10
Pours a hazy orange with a white head and sweet aroma of yeast and fruits. Taste is similar, of yeast, spices, and fruits with a spicy, medium finish. Solid, drinkable, Belgain
Pours a peachy colour with good lacing. Nice yeasty belgian candy aroma. Citrus, candy and hoppy flavours. Good stuff!

Aroma is strong and amazing, with spicy and floral hop notes plus belgian yeasty esters.  Taste is low bitterness, with some spicy and fruity notes from the yeast plus funky brett character, very complex and hard to describe.  Finish is lingering brett and bitterness.

Amazing beer. Slightly sweet and fruity but all so tasty with a nice alcohol burn.

Light sweet flavor first hits the.pallet folowed by citrus of the Styrian hops not a ton of bitterness. Great sweet fruity finish given by the brettnomyces

A frothy head tops a golden orange effervescent beer, but lacks much aroma.  What aroma there is, is peach and apricot.  The body is lively and medium.  The taste is all there - peaches, pears, cloves and a bit of banana. Very dry, easy to drink and a nice beer.
From a 12 oz bottle shared at home.  Pours clear gold with a thick white head.  Peach notes in the aroma. Malty flavor with notes of orange rind.  Smooth finish.

A clear golden Belgian style ale with notes of caramel, mildly funky and spicy yeast, coriander and orange peel.  Slightly sweet with a mild peppery bitterness.  Bubbly.  Boozy and easily quaffable.  Could be a bit more robust.

my first beer from Goose Island!!! Pours a spritzy efferfescent bright orange with a thin dense packet of head. The nose is subtly bretty with tons of floral hop and fruit notes. Notes of lemon peel, orange rind, pineapple, grains of paradise. Sweet and smooth complexion with a hop forward accent a and just gorgeous floral and ester notes. The finish is mildly bitter and has a bit of hop resin smack with a mild Brett note. Opens up a bit with light funky and mold earthy green grape and fruity note. Overall, just an incredible brew.

A good brew. Thanks Harold. Aroma is full of yeast, clove, citrus, some peach, and spices. Pour is bronze colored with a nice white head with great lacing. The taste is full of citrus and light tropical notes with a honey/tripel-esque flavor - fruity and sweet. Slightly soapy strong flavor in the mix, mingled with spicy and yeasty notes.

12oz bottle into Trappist glass.  Hazy orange-golden color with thin white head.  Aroma of malt sweetness, tangry citrus and spices.  Taste is fruity tasting malt and yeast, caramel, bread, some hops, some alcohol and spices. Ending is dry and peppery. Medium body and carbonation.  Nice.

This was a special rate because I had drunk this for the first time in the city in which it was brewed in. Pours a tangy orangeade with which sustained a whitish ring atop. Smells of banana peppers, white wheat, lemongrass, yeast and wool. Tastes of coriander, pink peppercorn, wheat grain, and light candied sugar.  Pretty good stuff.

Bottle. Golden ale with a thick creamy top. Nose has some sherbert and malt with a healthy load of coriander. Mild banana and some light citrus too. Lots of carbonation in the mouth, and the taste is incredibly malty. Bordering on sweet bit then hits you with a powerful bitter. Tons of coriander and sweetness hits once again. More banana hints and there's a threat of alcohol which fails to emerge heavily. Tasty, if a little heavy. Not sessionable, but tasty!
has a nice sweet smelling fruity/spice aroma.  Well balanced body gives a nice mouthfull.  A nice blend of hops and spice, warming, good brew.

Flaske delt med Egil på Cardinal des-12: ravfarget, med lavt skum. Krydret aroma, nellik og assosiasjoner til peppernøtter (kan det skyldes den sjeldne gjærsorten som iflg. bryggeriet er brukt?). Mild og god med ganske lav bitterhet, et deilig koseøl. Må sjekke om de har denne på polet.

Bottle from a bottle shop in Chicago. Pours clear golden with a minimal white head. Aroma is some malt and hoppy fruitiness but mainly brettanomyces, some fruity sourness, cloves, spices. Very drinkable, mild taste with a little sour, bitter and spicy ending.

Dark and inviting! Goose island is one of my favorite breweries. Not as great as Sofie but has more fruit and nut qualities.

I guess Goose Island is no longer craft beer, so here’s a toast to the evil empire of evil beer. This evil beer is pretty damned delicious. Lots of brett/funky fruity yeastiness on the nose. (bottle) Thin off-white head, clear orange amber body. Sweet aroma, moderate malt and caramel, lots of fruit, yeast. Medium body, soft carbonation, a little oily. Flavor is very sweet; fruit (banana and tropical), caramel, bread and yeast, moderate alcohol, mild hops, hint of spice.
12 ounce bottle.  Pours a dark gold with an average white head.  Aroma of malt, caramel, fruit, and yeast.  Taste is yeast, malt, tart fruit, caramel, and spices.  Very nice.
Sweet malts, yeasty with a kiss of spice in the nose. Mmmm, Brett. Mildly tart with Belgian spices on the palate. Crisp and clean. Creamy body. An excellent shelf beer.

Pours a clear gold with a medium white head.  Aroma has light tropical fruit, herbal notes, and spice.  Flavor is definitely herbal and spicy...mild grassy hops...pepper.  mouthfeel is medium and lively with a dry spicy/peppery finish that hints at herbs and fruit.
07 bottle. Smells candylike and cidery. Sweet cidery taste. Highly carved and medium thick

Yummy and very lively carbonation.  Delicious fresh strawberry/apple aroma.  The color is an opaque caramel: beautiful.  Sweet and darkly grassy flavored.  Spicy, too.  The texture is smooth and slick, with a spicy bubbly feeling...(best description?).  Very interesting, good to share because it’s a full-bodied beer.

12 oz bottle to tulip. Appearance: frothy white head. Gold, slightly hazy. Inviting. Leaves patchy irregular lacing. 

Aroma: immediately hit with the scent of apple juice when opening the bottle. Otherwise, esters, floral, fruity, Belgian yeast (aside: I hope someday my tasting sense and vocab is developed well enough to be able to replace "Belgian yeast" with a more accurate, discerning description).

Palate: medium body, lively carbonation , mouth-coating. 

Taste: moderate hop bitterness, light-moderate sweetness, moderate duration. Not as fruity as aroma suggested, nice pumpkin-pie spice. 

Overall: starts quite nicely with a pleasant, playful interplay of spice, fruit, sweet and bitter. By the end, it tastes too much like a Belgian-spiced apple cider for my liking. Seems like a solid beer, but not one I'm likely to seek out again.

Bottled on 8/17/2012

Pours a deep golden color. Aroma is quite complex. It has a very earthy smell, grass, citrus, sweet malt. Taste ha a medium sweetness, with a slight sour note at the end. It has a medium body with lively carbonation. Overall, this is a good beer.

12 ounce bottle - $3.49 at Total Wine & More in Kennesaw, Georgia.



Bottled On: 08/17/12.



Appearance: Pours a clear, darkened gold body with a medium-small, white head.



Smell: Moderate maltiness with a very light toastiness and thin caramel edge. Vibrant melange of fruitiness, particularly as it warms, as with the taste, sometimes it’s a note of pear, apple, sultana, citrus, even kiwi.



Taste: Sweet, sugary barley with a touch of treacle. Hint of tropical fruitiness (just a hint, mind you), but also a little golden raisin and apple. Lightly spicy yeastwise, leafy, maybe even a trace of gum in there. Lightly bitter. Some warmth from the alcohol. Sweetish, soft finish with a bit of spice lingering into the aftertaste.



Mouthfeel: Medium-plus body. Medium-plus carbonation.



Overall: Matilda is a fairly enjoyable, fruity Belgian-esque ale.

Aroma grass, citrus, herbs, Appearance. golden, clear, With a nice white head and decent lacing Taste. A mild malty and medium spice beer Palate. Nice smooth mouth feel, moderately carbonated with a mild spicy hop finish Overall. A very nice American Brewed Belgian style ale. A very drinkable beer.

12oz bottle---> tulip.  Pours a hazy light orange with a decent sized white head.  Aroma is pretty funky with hints of sweet fruit and caramel.  Taste is fairly sweet nonoffensive malt with a great hint of brett dustiness, and peach.  Medium thick palate with slightly fizzy carbonation.  VERY solid beer.
bottle.  clear copper with a medium, creamy head.  dusty basement aroma.  dry, dusty and clean like a rayon very with a little more sweetness.  in line with an orval style beer.
.3 l draft  pours an orange/amber color with a small white head.  Aromas of tropical fruit, sweet malt.  Medium bodied, nice dry finish.
2008  picked up from Chicago vintage series. The aroma is amazing of spice pepper. The taste is great with slight taste of fruit. Amazing

2011 vintage. 22 oz bottle, bottled 21-Jan-11, from Beers of the World in Rochester, served in a stem glass. Pours clear orange-amber with a tall, frothy off-white head that remains and leaves dense lace. On the nose, there are notes of sour fruit, apples, banana, flowers, pale malts, grain and a touch of barnyard. The flavour is well balanced, slightly dry with a complex fruity, funky, barnyardy, slightly tart character. The finish is long and malty with plenty of Brett notes. On the palate, it is medium in body, silky smooth with above average carbonation. Overall, this is a great Belgian style pale. It has just the right amount of Brettanomyces notes to keep it interesting, paired with a nice malt profile. Refreshing and complex at the same time, this makes for a great session ale. 2012-01-30

Pours a dark orange color with a large off white head.aroma is tons of spicy Belgian yeast, lots of clove, some peachy hints,  nice. Taste is the same lots of Belgian character, spicy yeast, cloves, peach skin, bubbly mouthfeel very good Belgian.
Dark orange hazy pour.. Crazy strong fruit aroma.. Taste is apricot and pear.. Some spice. .. Really good for its style
Pours a nice brown/orange color with a little head.  Nice aroma with a well balanced taste that has hints of fruitiness.  Finishes very clean.

12 oz bottle poured into a tulip glass.  Pours a golden amber with a nice two finger off white head.  Aroma is Belgian yeast, bread with a nice fruity sweetness.  Taste is sweet and fruity with a bit of funky yeastiness.  Nice.

Poured from a large bottle purchased in Chicago into a narrow-style glass to drink.  The beer had a rich, semi-cloudy amber color with a modest foamy white head that had short retention, but good lacing and average cling.  The aroma has a pleasant blend of yeast, floral hops, touches of citrus and spice, and a good caramel malty effect for balance.  It had a somewhat bitter citrus and floral taste, with a subtle yeast sour effect and some modest caramel malt and candy notes.  The beer was fairly wet and filled the mouth with a slight creamy effect, but had light carbonation and life.

From notes: Poured a hazy orangey-amber with a very small, thin off-white head that was gone quickly.  Aroma of apricot mixed with a touch of yeast.  Body was a bit fuller than medium, with a very slight thickness to it.  Mild flavor of stone fruit up front that quickly gives way to a tart flavor reminiscent of citrus rind.  As it warmed, the stone fruit took on more of a candied sweetness that mixed interestingly with the tart citrus.
Bomber bottle of the 2012 batch. Pours amber/copper, semi-thin lasting white head. Aroma of spicy apricot, taste is sour apricot yeast banana, finish is good. Nice beer.

Bottle shared by Rob during a great unexpected visit.

The beer is hazy and orange, with a light tan head. a decent amount of lacing is left on the sides of the glass. The aroma is inviting, offering citrus, Belgian yeast, malt, candied fruit. The flavor has a healthy hop presence, with a nice combo of sweet, candied fruits and Belgian yeast. The feel is medium bodied with appropriate carbonation. Overall, a tasty beverage. A bomber is perfect for sharing a couple / few ways. I would have this again.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-04-2011

Pours a cloudy golden color with 1in of quickly disappating head. Aroma is of lemon and sour fruit. Tastes of,lemon zest, biscuity/bready malt and caramel. Full bodied with good mouthfeel. Overall, it’s a decent belgian beer with a slight sour finish, but it just isn’t my thing.

Pours a beautiful copper with very small head. Smells of sour peach, orange and serious spice. Definitely a heavy sour forefront. Nice spice on the tongue with some pear and orange peel. Bit of a hop bite. Flavor not as strong as I was hoping. Could use a little more fruit flavor to go along with the other nice spicy notes, which was disappointing as everything else about it is superb. Refreshing beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Sample from the Decatur Craft Beer Fest. Dark gold and bubbly with a thin tan head. The aroma is pine, flowers, and a faint mineral note. The flavor is citrus sweetness and sourness. The palate is medium, hard, and crisp. Overall, this is a surprisingly refreshing and crisp ale. Very nicely balanced use of brettanomyces.

22 oz bottle dated 8/6/12 served in a Three Floyds teku glass. Pours a hazy glowing golden orange with an inch of white head and nice lacing. Carbonation seems high, lots of bubbles. Aroma is white grapes, apples, pears, dough, and raisins. There is a bit of funk there too. Taste is raisins, apples, Belgian yeast, bread, white grapes, and a mild hop bitterness. Mouthfeel is highly carbonated and easy drinking. Awesome beer, one of the best from Goose Island.
Un bellissimo colore ambrato schiuma chiara non molto persistente, profumo fruttato che si riconferma anche all’assaggio. Dolce e speziata.
Very enjoyable brew from Goose Island. Nice aroma and flavors of Belgium yeast. Otherwise very crisp with some nice fruity flavors.

Tap. Pours hazy orange amber with a large creamy white head that leaves good lacing. Aroma is peach, yeast and citrus - orange and lemon. Flavor is about the same, medium sweet and a bit spicy with a lightly bitter citric rind dry finish.

Canned peach aroma, fruity and tinny. Clear orange, medium yellow head. Peach flavor, dry at first but ends in a crescendo of sweetness, never coming close to being cloying. Brief appearances of funk keep it interesting. Finishes with a nice malty peach combination. Lovely.
Pours clear orange gold. Aroma is very interesting-floral, green. Palate is great- big,but not too big, floral and candied fruit with a good hop presence.

Bottle poured into Goose Island tulip glass. Pours orange with no head, slight lacing around the glass. Very thick body, nose is citrus. Taste is apricot, apples, very sweet, a bit cloying. Not bad, tough to drink more than one.
Bottle. Pours a dark gold colour with a large white head, plenty of fruit and yeast in the aroma, the taste has a light sweetness, with a hint of spice with a dry finish.

Aroma- some hops, wheat, caramel, funky Appearance- bronze, big bubbled white head Taste- somewhat hoppy, funky, slight metallic finish, caramel sweetness Palate- crisp and clean, decent mouthfeel Overall- To me this tasted like a slightly more hoppy brown ale with some Belgian funk. Weird and not entirely appealing. Meh.
Juicy fruity Belgian yeast aromas. Fruity Belgian flavors. Overall not too bad of a Belgian style beer.

On tap at Cafe Napoli (St. Louis, MO), poured into a Goose Island tulip. Sweet glass. Fruity esters, spice, clove, biscuit, tangy hops, grass, and straw in the aroma. Taste is fruity, white pepper, light banana, straw, biscuit, light caramel, and yeast with a lightly spicy finish. Medium body with high carbonation. Nice brew and a great Belgian interpretation.

pour is somewhat transparent copper with a light tan head and some larger bubbles. Nose has a strong malt base, lightly toasted nut and crystal malt, with golden fruits, pear and peaches, behind. Taste is the same with a bit of candied fruit, not sugary, some peppery spice in the finish on a lighter body and crisp finish with moderate carbonation.

Golden colour with a white head. Fruity and light citric aroma. Mild sweetness and a moderate nice fruity flavour. Mild ale considering 7%.
[Bottle from Vinmonopolet in Halden, Norway]

Poured from a 650ml bottle into a pint glass.

A: Pours a hazy amber color with a nice frothy off white head with nice retention. Sticky lace down the side of the glass.

S: There is some light yeast with some small fruit aromas. Cherries and other vine fruits are present.

T: Same light yeast from the nose with the same mild fruits. Slight tartness and there is some banana as well. Although the flavors were kind of muted.

M: Nice and refreshing. Light bodied with a decent carbonation. The aftertaste leaves something to be desired as it is non-existent.

O: Definitely not a strong ale, more like a light Belgian brew. Decent, but nothing worth revisiting.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-22-2011

2012 on the bottle and drank in 2012. Clearly this shows it should be aged. Medium reddish - orange amber with fizzy, lasting, frothy, beige head. Nice lacing. Lovely sweet smell of malt, tropical fruit, caramel, and herbal elements with coriander, honey with notes of yeast.Crisp bubbly smooth medium oily body. Sweet butter malt start with caramel, herbal yeast, tropical fruit and well balanced against the earthy spicy dry finish. Beautiful beer and look forward to an aged version.

Honestly, nothing incredibly special with this beer from Goose Island.  Pours a nice golden color with a thin white head that dissipates without much lacing.  Aroma is fruity with some hops but not really complex and the flavor notes are much the same.  Maybe some kiwi and pear and it’s not very hoppy.  Moderate bite on the tongue.  It’s a nice beer to drink but not one to really savor or crave.

Pours a dark golden orange with a medium white head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is dominated by yeast with mild hoppiness peaking through. Taste is a nice balance and sweet and sour, with a very mild bitter finish. Mouthfeel is a bit thick, but it suits this style. Matilda beer reminds me of a less sweet Fin du Monde without the spiciness.

Comes out of the tap a beautiful clear golden with a thick, fine-bubbled, pale cream head. Fruity aroma has notes of banana, pear and tangerine plus a subtle malty tone. Rich & fruity flavor delights the taste buds with banana and pear notes plus hints of tangerine and butterscotch. Texture has firm body and plenty of fizz. Waltz with this Matilda!

Aroma- some hops, wheat, caramel, funk
Appearance- bronze, big bubbled white head
Taste- somewhat hoppy, funky, slight metallic finish, caramel sweetness
Palate- crisp and clean, decent mouthfeel
Overall- To me this tasted like a slightly more hoppy brown ale with some Belgian funk.  Weird and not entirely appealing.
22 oz bottle - definite Belgian yeast aroma. Backed with some solid malt aroma. Not as sour as a lot of Belgians. This is a pretty good one. One is enough, though with this higher alcohol content.

THOUGHTS: A wonderful beer that already seemed to have improved in the few months that I’ve had it. I have to try to lay down a bottle of this and Green Flash Rayon Vert and try them side by side. Two great Belgian style ales made right here in America. There were hops present bu they blend so well with the yeast and are balance expertly by the malt, the bitterness is really held in check. Very complex, but easy to drink.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a sparkling, clear, light amber with a small to average, off-white head that mostly diminished leaving fair lacing. The aroma had light light-colored bread, caramel and candy sugar; light herbal and grassy hops; moderate to heavy doughy, earthy and slightly spicy yeast; slight funky yeast; grape; apple; pear; white wine; honey; and ever so slight alcohol. The initial flavor was lightly sweet, light to moderately bitter and slightly sour; while the finish was light to moderately sweet, lightly sour and acidic, and slight to lightly bitter with an average to long duration. There was caramel malt, candy sugar, honey, lots and lots of yeast, bready yeast, spicy yeast, slightly funky yeast, earthy yeast, sweet and tart apple, grassy hops, white wine and slightly sour grapes. The light to medium body was dry with fizzy carbonation and a slightly metallic and lightly dry finish.

Great for its style. Medium bodied considering. Sweet aromas. Great finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Hazy copper-amber with an off-white head. Aroma of sour Belgian yeast and fruit. Taste is a little sour, mostly malty and yeasty. Dry and on the heavier side of medium bodied. Decent brew

Bottle pours a slightly hazy amber-orange, with an immense white head, excellent retention. Nose is yeasty and some floral notes (lilies?) Mouth is rather medium bodied, with some clove, biscuit and Belgian yeasty spice. Finishes sort of weak, although it might be an old bottle (sale price). Overall decent though.

Bottle 0,33l. Gold, slight haze, healthy dome of white, medium-coarseness head. Aroma is refreshing grain, light spice, orange peel, rose hip and tart apple. Flavor is the same, trending towards brett flavors without the brett. Delicious. Light body, hops only subconsciously perceptible. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Deep golden with lacy white head.  Sweet fruity aroma with tart notes.  Spicey with peach-like undertones.
It’s a good stab. Smooth and just a little bubbliness. Missing some kick of some sort though

Aroma is orange peel and brett. White rocky head over hazy orange body. Flavor is subtle tart fruitiness and lots of funk.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Ein Bier welches nicht als Durstlöscher taugt. Dieses Ale, welches dem Belgischen Stil nachempfunden ist will genossen werden. Auch gut für einen Winterabend.
Matilda is solid, but the G.I. Sofie is far better. (In both cases, G.I. offers a somewhat hamstrung version of a belgian -- lacking elegance, but certainly nice in a pinch.)

Botella con mi marido. 
Huele y sabe a fruta, Welchito! Bien seca. Muy rica,

Orange, white head. Good lacing. Nose is huge white grapes. Taste is white grapes, white wine, light spices and hops, apricots, and funk. Dry, bitter, minty finish. The rare yeast made this a really unique beer.

12 oz bottle to glass; newer style for me - definitely a fan of this one - aroma was orange and funk; great looking hazy orange amber.  taste was caramel, orange, and malt up front - tart and funk on back end dries at finish.
(tasting at Des Peres Schnucks) hazy gold. Aroma of spice and yeast. Flavor is spice, yeast, sweet malt.

Gold, slight haze, healthy dome of white, medium-coarseness head.  Aroma is refreshing grain, light spice, and tart apple.  Flavor is the same, trending towards brett flavors without the brett.  Delicious.  Light body, hops only subconsciously perceptible.  I can’t remember having a "Belgian Ale" this good before!  Update: The next day this beer still blows me away with every sip.  Masterfully brewed; quenching and delicious, even addicting.  The yeast character is very wine-like for a beer that isn’t sour.  Great job!

12oz bottle poured into a La Chouffe tulip and enjoyed with pan seared sea bass and a light herb salad.

A - nothing all that special, Golden straw colored with a decent head that did not last too long and left a little bit of lacing.

S - I got some sweet fruit (maybe grapes and apples) along with some citrus grapefruit.

T - I get a lot of fruits; apples peaches grapes and grapefruit. then the hops come a knocking and leave a clean finish.

M - Light and lively yet this is more full bodied beer than you’d expect.

D - Definitely a beer I could drink all night. It left me wanting another one. It was excellent with the fish, one of those moments that will make me remember the pairing and try to repeat it.
Good and refreshing Belgian ale.  Delightfully citrus sweetness, caramel malt, and yeast

Tap. Pours hazy amber with thin, fizzy white head; short retention and good lacing. Aroma is bread and caramel malts, Belgian yeast, candy sugar, herbs, floral hops, dates, pears, and light spice. Flavor is sweet malt forward with good fruit esters and faint hops; sugar notes throughout with a dry finish. Medium body, warmth, and carbonation.

Bottle 22oz.
Pours clear golden with low off-white head. Nice lacing. Aroma is of bretts, citrus, fruits, malt. Taste is of bretts, citrus, fruits, malt, sligth alcohol. Overall: Good body. Very nice balance. Drinkable. [ Bottle 765ml. Pretty similar to the other ones I had, but with kinda more bitterness, and a little something off in taste/aroma. We are talking fermentation issues. Downgrading this one a tad.]

Bottle (22 oz). Golden/orange with a small white head and some lacing. Aroma of brettanomyces, citrus, fruits and malt. Taste of malt, fruits, citrus and slight brett. Mouthfeel is slightly dry. Really good belgian ale. Brett add a nice dimension to this beer. I would be curious to see how the brett develop in this beer it’s cellared 2-3 years.
This beer was pretty good it was smoothed and very easy on Tue palate I would drink again

Beautiful golden light color.
Strong banana aroma and then surprising cereals and spices.
Subtle malty finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From notes: Aromas of clove, subtle yeast, hay, and banana, with mildly sweet flavors of tangerine and spice on the palate. Thicker mouthfeel then nose suggests.

--- tasted while on a long journey to understand the world around me...
Had in a bottle 2009 vintage. Really nice aroma with a fruity and spicy flavor. Hints of vanilla and orange in the finish. Very complex and good beer
22oz bottle. Taste or the orangey fruity flavor, ok better than blue moon- Belgium style just isnt for me

Yuck!Smell and taste are horrible.  Color- orange with a fluffy white head.Didn?t like the hops, malts, fruitiness, or spices.  I very much disliked this beer.

Retried a bottle from 2009 and it was much better, so rating now reflects it.

Bottle, 2010 vintage.  Cellar temperature.  Poured into a snifter.  A mostly transparent orange coloured ale.  Persistent white head.  Yeasty aroma with citrus fruits, lemon zest, apple and pepper.  Medium to full bodied and oily.  Flavour is spicy with an earthy character.  Citrus fruits then mild honey, hard candy and pepper.  Long malty finish.

2012 Vintage. Pours golden orange with a medium sized off-white head. Smells funky and of spicy, earthy hops. Taste is both spicy and funky. Medium-bodied with a smooth texture and a fair amount of mouth-carbonation, Goose Island Matilda finishes with a mild spiciness and funk.

Poured from a bottle into a Belgian style tulip glass. Pours a somewhat hazy amber with orangeish highlights. The aroma is characteristically Belgian with a crisp quality and a touch of tartness. The taste is nicely bready with notes of vanilla and Ritz crackers, minus the saltiness, that is. There’s also a bit of fresh ground black pepper. It is very slight. The body is nicely thick and sticky. The carbonation is rather soft. Overall, this beer is quite well rounded.

Very nice beer. Another extremely refreshing brew for the hot summer. This pours a light amber with a frothy head. The aroma has some fruit and a bit of funk. The flavor has the fruit, funk and a bit of sourness. Very tasty.

Very large head, orange ish head, mostly diminishing.

Hints of spice, medium body

Bottle from the Anderson’s. Pours golden with bits of yeast floating about and a massive two inch white head that leaves lacing. It’s got that Belgian yeast thing in the nose plus some kind of sugar. A bit fruity on the tongue. Very drinkable. Solid for style.

2012 Bottle poured and enjoyed at Rathskellar. We have a bottle of this in our cellar (2009 maybe?) and have never tried it.

Pour was gorgeous peachy orange color. Very nice yeast and fruit aromas.

Flavor of orange, hint of clove, nice warm alcohol feel. Got much better as it warmed. Very delightful!

Belgian Pale Ale. According to brewery alcohol is 7.2. Golden color, baking spice aroma, fruity biscuity malt flavor, dry body

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Tropical fruit in the flavor and aroma.  Very nice Belgian Ale.  This one was about 18 months old and was quite nice.  There is a slight spice bite and a sweetness to this one.

355 mL bottle from Ealing Beer Festival, drank at home into a Westmalle glass.  Lively head that quickly disappears.  Clear orange red and fizzy.  Fruity, a little spicy and heavily hopped perfumed aroma.  Fruity, sweet and candied, with some dryness at the end.  Interesting and nice.

Ar: Peach, hay, some tart lemon.
Ap: Clear amber-gold - medium-small off-white head with decent retention and a ring of lacing.
T: Peach and nectarine up front, semi-sweet with toasty malt - some funky barnyard flavor, though not too prominent - medium bitterness, hops with a spicy and slightly tropical profile - finish has more fruit, ripe peaches and hint of banana. 
P: Medium body with medium-high carbonation - finish is medium-dry.
O:  A pleasure to drink - wonderful array of fruit flavors, and some nice malt, sweetness, and hop accents.

Fruity, sweet smell.  Cloudy, amber gold color.  Taste explodes with sweet, caramel infused malt, and spice, banana notes.  Smooth finish.  Yeast in this beer adds a beautiful character all its own.  Outstanding
Nice and fruity belgium flavor.  Another good "break in" beer to belgium yeast.  Highly enjoy this brew!
Pours orange golden with an off white head. Aroma is sweet and fruity with some spicy hints. Flavor is sweet, malty notes at first that lead to fruity lemon, orange, and yeasty spice.

Pours a hazy coppery orange.  Juicy fruit combo of aromas with a hint of funkyness.  Starts with spicy flavors followed by a smorgasbord of fruits and flowers, with a trace of Brett.  Mildly sweet with lots of well blended aromas and flavors.  Very complex,  Damn good beer!

Poured a very pretty orange gold color with very little head. Smell and taste was exactly like that of a barn...It could have been liquid straw and I wouldn’t have known any better. That being said, it was so unique and surprising, I liked it a lot. Not something to drink over and over, but once in a while it will definitely spice things up.

2012 bottle. Dark copper colour with a small white head. Sweet spicy aroma with orange, caramel, peach, apricot, lemon, cinnamon, a faint sour wheat note. Medium, nicely carbonated palate. Bittersweet flavour with caramel, orange, other fruits and spices, as well as a mild funkiness in the finish. Really nice.

Pours amber with a nice head. Nice aroma of cloves, yeast, bananas. Full bodied with an okay palate.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

22oz bottle. Poured a relatively clear light-red/orange color with a small and quickly dissipating head. Aroma is some yeast notes, mild spice and fruit characters. Flavor is spice malt, with some fruity notes, nice and hoppy.

On tap at Money Plays. Pours a clear copper golden with small off white head. The aroma is caramel malt and yeast. Thick mouthfeel with a strong yeast and fruity malt flavor. A good Belgian from Goose Island.

Love Chi Town! I’ve had this beer several times and its always rich and sugary and sweet and good stuff Orange hue, white head, lots of hops and bitterness, tastes hoppy, piney, citrus. Aroma of hops and oranges, caramel.

Bottle dated 10-21-11. Funky barnyard, sweet, tart, and citrus/floral aroma.  Copper with a moderate, quickly dissipating beige head, suspended sediment. Sweet funky barnyard flavor, some tartness and a spicy finish. Medium body. Nice at the end of this 105 degree day.
Pours a clear amber with a minimal off-white head.  Smells of barnyard, hay, earthy, floral.  Taste is mild, bitter and sweet, hints of tea.

Deep amber color with a short white clean head, some lacing left behind.  Strong lemony, orange aroma is quite different than other Belgian beers that I have had.  Taste is sweet and finishes crisp with a slight tartness.  Nice brew!
Bottle (2012 vintage): pours hazy golden amber with a thin white head, aroma is sweet and some funkiness, taste is sweet, spiced, a bit funky, very dry finish.

Thanks Sean for sending me this. 375ML 2011 vintage poured into a Champagne flute.



A - No head at all. Gorgeous orange gold appearance.



S - Interesting scent. For the most part, i’m getting a sweet brown sugar scent with fresh cut grass and cherries.



T - Fairly large up front bitterness followed by an underlying molasses sort of sweetness. figs and cream. Sugar cubes and bready belgian charicteristics



M - 100% carbonation,medium heavy body.Lingering hop resin of pine needles



O - Not bad. Pretty tasty and overall, a bit too sweet.

A dark copper colored beer with a smallish cream colored head and decent lacing. A bit darker than I expected for the style. Nose is full of Belgian yeast esters and candi sugar; bubblegum practically jumps out and smacks you in the face. Again, there is a wonderful play between the sweetness of the malt (and also the orchard fruit and a subtle berry flavor) and the slightly tart funk. Not exactly barnyard, but there is a musty country orchard kind of flavor with some freshly cut grass/hay. Some yeast and subtle spices in the back but nothing too strong (especially the spices). Medium body and carbonation. Has a nice creaminess and drinkability to it.This goes down incredibly easy. Probably one of the most pleasant Belgian (Strong?) Pale Ales I’ve ever encountered. Delicate, subtle and incredibly balanced. Try this. NOW

Bottled 11/05/2010.  Pours a cloudy copper-gold with minimal carbonation...just lacing the sides of the glass with a few bubbles dotting the surface.  Aroma is distinctly Belgian: sweet, spicy yeast, floral hops.  Flavor is a little bit funky with a subtle pasty element, and pleasant, mildy-sweet malt base with quite spicy, lingering hops.  As it warms some fruitier flavors come out, and I would say it improves considerably.

12 oz bottle dated 2012.  This was offered to me by the bartender at Gibson’s in Oak Brook, IL.  The copper colored ale poured with a big frothy head.  A good looking Beligan Ale.  The bottle conditioned ale claims 7% abv, it was very deceptive.  There was no sediment. This is an excellent ale for this style.  It seemed milder than others that I have tasted.  Smooth finish with some sweetness.

Bottle shared at a farewell to beerandbeyond tasting at Dagan’s place. Hazy golden, white foam. Smells sour and muddy, tastes sour, but slightly bitter and sweet towards the end. Medium body, light finish, soft carbonation.
A bit creamy, but otherwise a solid, albeit genetic belgian style ale.  Nothing particularly stands out.
Golden color, big head, lost of lacing. Aroma is spice and lemon, sweet malt in the background. Dry finish without any hop presence. It’s an ok beer, nothing I feel compelled to have again.
Bottle from whole foods. I think this wa a bad bottle, it was slinky with a rotten fruit aftertaste. I will try it on tap at goose islan and update site everyone seems to love this beer.

Pours a bright cloudy golden with a robust white head.  Aroma is very a little subtle but very pleasing.  Honey and lemon are most distinct, somewhat grassy, cherry, hints of some cider and bubblegum.  Taste is a touch sour, with caramel, cherry, and sugar.  Finish is bitter and astringent.  Medium bodied and feels fizzy when drinking.  I get the impression that this beer is lighter than it actually is.  Very enjoyable.

12 oz bottle.  Bottled on 04/04/2012.  7% ABV.

aroma - light floral hoppiness, faint smell of honey, fairly distinct malted aroma, a bit of mustiness typical of style, notes are subtle and pleasant;

appearance - copper-red-brown, a bit lighter than many belgiums, head quickly dissipates, decent carbonation 

taste - malt balanced with nice presentation of hop, a touch of spiciness (pepper?)on the finish,

palate - not exactly silky but very smooth for an ale of this magnitude

Overall - another enjoyable and well crafted beer by Goose Island

Smells mustard seed out of the bottle.  Smells mustard seed when poured into a glass, too.  I’ve occasionally had beers with this scent to some degree, but never to this extent.  Some other spices and yeast, too (it’s a Belgian!).  Malt becomes more noticeable in the smell after it sits a few minutes.  Pours to super thick, massive head that commands your awe and patience.  Lacing is phenomenal.  Copper/gold color.  5 on the epic appearance.  Flavor: whoa, this is different.  Definitely some peppers going on of some sort.  Very spicy.  ABV burn that seems much higher than 7%.  Fairly acidic and light-medium bodied, as I understand is common for this more general Belgian ale style.  Some fruity tang, but I can’t place my hand on just what kind of fruit other than something vaguely orange-ish.  Some have claimed this is sour, but I disagree - it’s just got a peppery, fruity tang.  Aftertaste is maltier and keeps the tang from being overpowering.  Very neat beer - not much like anything I’ve ever had before.  Belgians of all kinds tend to be such fascinating beers.  This is very sippable in slow doses.  The description of "fruity and spicy" yeast is dead-on, as with complex maltiness, but I don’t notice the hops as much as GI claims.  Nonetheless, a good beer that deserves a better-than-solid rating.

Decent sized white head o fine and dense bubbles.  Reduces rather quickly to a thin sheen of foam on the surface.  Little bit of funkyness in the aroma with legit sourness, some tart fruity aromas and some leather.  Color is a dark orange.  Soft malts with some chalky grains on the palate.  Light bodied with biscuity malts, tea leaves and herbal hops flavors.  Light sourness that makes the mouth salivate for more.  Finishes grainy and dry.  An ok belgian.

Ornage, slight hazy. Malts, dried apricot. Almost barley wine like malt heavy. Im missing the yeast characters. Update: no im not. Quite nice actually.

-- rated with ’lankku’ (N9)

Smells of heavily perfumed hops like a good Belgian. Pours an amber blond colour without too much head or tracing. Taste has a touch of sourness, some bitter finish. It’s along the lines of Chouffe or Delirium Tremens. A likable session style Belgian. Bottle from Health Food Store in Lebanon, NH.

Pours a rich orange with a paperthin head. Funky aroma with Brett up front, spicy yeast and hops in the back. Taste follows, slightly medicinal. Smooth and hides the alcohol pretty well. Not bad

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft. Pint. Poured dark brown amber at the top, orange in the middle and bright yellow at the bottom. Big fluffy head that left a lot of lace. Though pleasant in appearance it ended up having a tree gummy taste I did not like. More sweet malt flavors than hop bitterness. Finished smooth. Well blended, but no subtle flavors. Sorry, this felt like a heavy sweet beer syrup in water. Noticed some drastically different and varried reviews of this beer, mostly more positive than mine, but I am sticking with my gut.

Poured from a 12oz bottle and served in a snifter. The beer poured dark amber with a reddish tins.  It smells very sweet with a hint of cherries.  This beer is exceptionally smooth.  It tastes kind of like cherries with a slightly spicy aftertaste.  This is an outstanding beer that I would gladly recommend to friends.

Pours apricot muddy with no head
Aromas of apricots, citrus, banana, some sourness
Very sweet overall. Some hints of sourness which balances it good. Tastes of bubblegum, bananas, apricots and some citrus. Nice!

Appearance: Hazy orange body with light white head.  Minimal retention and lacing.

Aroma: Great aroma very complex, slight fruit flavors with a nice spicy note.  Alcohol is present but not overwhelming.  The smell sends you in a lot of different directions

T: Spiciness and floral up front but balances out with a nice fruity and maltiness.  A flavor from raisins seem to become very present.  Again alcohol note is present but not obvious.

Palate: Medium bodied with medium carbonation, very easy to drink.

Overall a very nice belgian style ale.  True to style and very drinkable.

O: This is outstanding, it’s making me wish AB didn’t own Goose Island because I’m so conflicted. I guess it doesn’t hurt to buy once right? It’s going to be hard to ignore...
Copper pour.  Draft. Sticky head.  Wheat scent. Grassy citrus and sweet taste.  Not my style but can tell this is a great beer for those that like belgiums

Aroma of pungeant floral and  yeast.  Very intense.  Pours amber with a small head and little carbonation.  Taste is much like the nose.  Heavy floral with roses being most prevalent.  Hints of iron and bread dough.  Nice Belgian and much different.

Tasting at World Wine & Liquor in mentor, Ohio. Poured into a 4oz. plastic cup. Hazy orange body, white head. Aroma of apples & pears, subtle fruity notes. Alcohol, sweet malts. Flavor has lots of raisins and wine like taste. Some grapes with fruity spicey yeast. Light to Medium mouthfeel. Long sweet aftertaste. These Belgian styles are not the best versions, but are still pretty tasty.
2009 bottle at home. It pours mid-amber with sweet peach and perfumed violet nose. Sweet candy sugar with a slight burnt caramel in the finish. Little in the way of carbonation.

Poured into a Duvel tulip from a 12 ounce 2012 bottle.



A: Hazy amber orange body with a thin white head with poor retention. This looks pretty nice, I like the color of the body.



S: This is absolutely phenomenal and complex. The smell is intense and thick right away, lots of sweet citrus of orange mostly with a mild funk that’s slightly leathery and mildy spicy. Semi-sweet, but also dry, this is just outstanding.



T: Floral flavors up front, mild leathery funk to this, and a very slight spice on the finish. This is a great beer, but it’s lacking after the aroma.



M: Light to medium bodied with mild carbonation.



O: This is outstanding, it’s making me wish AB didn’t own Goose Island because I’m so conflicted. I guess it doesn’t hurt to buy once right? It’s going to be hard to ignore...

Pours a hazy reddish brown, hardly any head, but with a good bit of carbonation which calms down after a while. Lots of belgian malts & yeasts in the flavour,  with dried fruits, cherries, raisins. Nice belgian style ale
12 oz bottle at Lou Malnatis.  Pours cloudy copper in colour, with thin white head.  Nice malty beer, spicy belgian yeast! Nice!

Slightly cloudy, deep amber colour. No head, exlcuding a thin white layer of bubbles. Rich, wheaty smell, high fruit notes. Possible drunk too cold, initial taste is lacking slightly in all areas. Palate heavy with fruit including gooseberries and apricots. Hops never materialise.

Originally reviewed: 1/11/09. As others have noted, this brew exploded with foam when opened! It was like a volcano. I tried to review this before, but couldn’t even pour the entire beer. Took about 10 minutes to pour this one. Huge white head (as I’ve stated), great retention and lacing. Smells of banana, clove, mix of other fruitiness. Typical Belgian PA scent. 

Very fruity brew. Some hop bitterness present, but not very much. Carbonation level is the highest I’ve ever had in a beer. I’m burping like crazy, and the bubbles burn as they’re going down. Kind of a weird experience all around. The flavor is pretty good. Not sure if I got a bad couple of bottles, but this was just weird.
