bottle , pours medium brown with orange hew nose is funky but not huge. first sip is maltyy sweetness like candy corn, belgian yeasty esters and ketones, finish is strong plsant with nice muth feel.
Very good and comparable to some of the best real Belgian varieties.  Medium bosy, smooth finish, some brett funk, banana and a little citrus.

Pours only slightly hazy dark golden orange.  Not much head or lace.  Smell is sweet floral notes with banana and just a little spice and just a slight funk (perhaps from the saaz).  Taste is more sweet floral, some skunky hops, banana and light spice.  I find it to be complex but refreshing.  If you told me it was a Saison I would certainly believe you.  Nice.

Pours a nice amber copper color with a slight head.... aromas of caramel, green banana, clove and a touch of wild sour notes.  On the palate it is pretty straight forward a nice malty pale ale that has been brightened up with the complexity of brettanomyces.  Well balanced solid beer that starts like pale and finishes straight Belgian....
Draft. Hazy dark golden pour with white head. Sweet and banana aromas. Sweet candied sugar, banana, light spice and yeast tones.

First tried this beer last year in Chicago. Liked it so much, it got me started enjoying craft beer. Hazy orange with a half finger of head that soon dissipates. The aroma and taste is of spice, nutmeg and slight hops. Very nice.....

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft pours dark amber with average tan head.  Bready aroma with hints of fruit.  Typical flavors of a Belgian that include spices, caramel, and breaded malts.  A very nice Belgian from the Goose Island brewery.

Golden brown color. Sweet smell of citrus and caramel. Almost a 1/4 inch of head and very little fiz after the pour. Light flavor up front with a very slight bitterness. Has a strong, quick citrus flavor followed with a slight caramel and spicy flavor. Bursts with a ton of complex flavors. The citrus flavor stays with you strong after you swallow. Would be great almost anytime of the year but is really a great beer for the spring. Light, fruity, and zesty. I would splurge on this again as a treat for myself. 4.5/5.

http://the-foodninja.blogspot.com/

Poured into a goblet. Not much head but some white, tiny bubbles around the edge of the glass. Nose is intoxicating! Fruity, spicy, Belgian yeast. Slight Brett funk. Flavor delivers on the promise: caramel & toffee maltiness, cinnamon, w/ ripe apples, pear & spice. Incredibly complex flavor overall, while maintaining a light body & easy-drinking texture. Love it!
Banana.  Sweet.  Dark amber.  Thin light head.  Similar to fat tire. Bread/cereal taste.  Medium ibu.  Yeasty.

Really nice lacing on this beer, my glass is just covered in white foam. Taste is sweet and a little funky. A little thick and malty. Smells a little resiny. Definitely some spice on the back of the tongue. Nice beer overall. I prefer Sofie or the sisters.
From a bottle poured a light brown color with a fair amount of head.  Light sweet malty flavor with a quick finish.

My 100th for ratebeer. Appearance was cloudy orangish gold with creamy 1 finger lasting white head, spotty lacing. Aromas where funky yeast ie oranges, grapefruits, spice, coriander? Slight sweet malts. Taste was sweet malt upfornt, then the stars of the yeasts come out. Oranages, grapefruit, spice and bittersweet funky  sourish yeasts. Palate was smooth creamy frothy carbonation with balanced body and average length wonderful funky finish. Outstanding  Belgian Ale...

A big rich nose.  The thing which impressed me most about this beer is how soft it is, it just coats the mouths and caresses the senses.  Need to be careful as at 7% this one is very easy to drink, and if over imbibed may cause to you wake up naked on your kitchen floor the next day.
Bottle. Clear amber colour with a small head. Sweet, yeasty aroma. Sweet fruity flavour with hops.

Poured on draft into taster glass
Aroma: citrus, hoppy, bit of funk, sweetness, peaches, grapefruit
Appearance: coppery color.  2 finger head that lingered a bit
Taste:  medium sweet, light bitter, and heavy sour
Palate:  medium body, thin mouthfeel, and sour aftertaste
Overall: i like the funk from the Brett.  It had an interesting taste in the little sample i had.  very enjoyable.
From old notes. Nose of spices, yeasts and subtle orange. Taste is similar with a touch of cloves. Very nice white ale.

Pours a nice cloudy tangerine with a short-lived finger of head.  Good lacing.  Plenty of esters in the nose.  Some soft fruits too - apples, white grapes, I don’t detect much coming off the malts.  It tastes rather refreshing.  Similar to other BPA’s that I’ve had without a very aggressive yeast presence.  Nice and floral.  I’m struggling to dissect this one.  It’s quite good, though.

Thanks to  master H for the help with this one.  Ummm cookies to the nose with this burnt amber pour and thin white head.  On the tongue medium with predominant umm cookie note followed by subtle cream soda, lemony hop, and salty caramel.  Nice beer.
Copper orange color with a white head.  Aroma of coriander, spice, and Belgian yeast.  Belgian yeast flavor, coriander, and spice rounds it out.  Really nice beer.

Golden color and decent amount of white head remaining along the side of the glass. Smell was very full of spices and bubble gum. Taste is floral and strong on the belgian spices with some coriander shining through. Mouth feel was sparkling and crisp.
pours amber with white head.aroma of orange yeast and malt and clove.flavor completely match aroma with a long dry finish.solid

Bottle. Slightly hazy copper color with a medium off-white head. Spicy nose, plenty of coriander, spices. Yeast. The taste is spicy with an orange peel acidic sweetness. Plenty of Belgian yeastiness. Fruity. Good malt backbone. Overall, not a bad effort from GI. Would be nice with a roast chicken.

12 oz bottle pours amber with a light tan head.  Aroma is sweet fruit, malt and yeast.  Taste is basically the same with a hint of spice.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Nice enough. This shows a lot of yeast character on the nose and palate. A hint of brioche as well. This falls a bit flat on the finish.

Bottle at Monk’s cafe Sveavägen. 2008 vintage. Hazy orange pour, thin white head. Aroma of sugary malts, fruity, some jelly beans and madeira. Flavor is smooth sweet sugars, quite some aged malts and dead yeast. Aged nicely. Quite round and well balanced flavor.

On tap, served in a Goose Island goblet glass. Light tan head which dissipates quickly. Light lacing.  Honey gold in tone, very clear. Effervescent and light mouthfeel. Banana & clove flavors, some hops. Seems a bit thin and flat for the style. Much more easy drinking than I expected.

Bottle at home. Amber coloured with beige/off-white head. Aroma is candi sugar, belgian yeast, bit of fruit and some spice. Taste is quite sweet, bit of butterscotch, werthers originals, caramel. Some fruit there somewhere too, in the background, maybe apple, or something plum like. Something vaguely vegetable in there too. Finish is slightly spicy, little bit of ginger maybe. Quite nice, but nothing knockout.

22 oz Bomber-Sampled @ Specific Gravity-Salisbury Md-Golden pour w/a moderate white head. Sweet spiced aroma. Kind of a basic Belgian Ale, some hop, some spice, a little candied sugar sweetness, mayde some banana. Smooth & easy to drink. I prefer My Belgians from Belgium, but this was a solid brew, you could do a lot worse.

From notes.  First reviewed 4/27/2010.  Poured from a 22 oz. bottle into a tulip. Bottled Jan 2009.

The head on Matilda surprised me out of the bottle. A great, pillowy head formed immediately and had nice retention. Patches of sticky lace clings to the glass. Honey orange color.

Citrus hoppiness, musty pale malt, alcohol phenols, cloves are all noticeable in the nose.

Pale malt with a sweetness like honey jumps out at first taste. Earthy notes, with a swirl of spice. Mild alcohol bite. Lemony hops add to a fruit composite with pineapple and banana notes as well. 

Crisp and smooth, with a medium body. Slightly oily residue.

Enjoyable taste and very easy to drink the first one. After that, I am satiated and liable to switch it up; it is fairly sweet to keep drinking. A positive addition to any session, or with a dessert.

Bottled on 4/8/2011, 22 oz bomber into a tulip glass. 

A - Dark amber body, fairly murky with some sediment floating around. Decent sized white head dies down to some large edging. Great lacing and retention.

S - Starts off with some belgian yeast and spices. Lemon, biscuity malts, and some subtle funky brett notes finish it off. 

T - Nice balance between the flavors here. Belgian yeast, coriander, lemon, biscuits and light funk. Mouth feel is medium with a nice amount of carbonation.

O - It’s not even a year old and its already showing a some funky brett notes. I think I’d prefer this beer fresher, but its still tasty and refreshing.

2011 Vint. Slight sour cherry note on nose, clear, well attenuated- chilled for a while to drop sed out. Rich golden straw color. Great clean currant flavor, hint of peach with pinch of pear, slight diactyl,- yeast have cleaned it up great, but will be amazing to see what she’s like in a year. Bit sparkly for BW but will grow and change. pretty exciting foo. Good balance, but more important it’s hinting @ what’s going to be.

2010 vintage from gift box set. (Would have tried the 2011 last summer, but the roomie snagged it first!) Pour from big bottle into Maudite glass. Head is slight; wants to lace though. Beer is medium amber, leaning toward brown--think tobacco sunburst guitar. Aroma is malty, brotzen, brown sugar. Flavor is sweet--huge malt. Alcohol flavor is about in line with strength. Palate balanced. Slightly sticky, maybe toffee-like finish. Kind of doppelbock-like in some ways; the doppelbock of the ale world? Also, I get touches of spice--cinnamon--late. Good beer, not my favorite Goose Island though.
Les effluves de grange donnent le ton, soutenu par un corps malté, délicat. Aucunement surette mais épicé et légèrement fruité. Les houblons s’impliquent bien dans le bouquet, très agréable.
Draft. White fizzy head. Fruity esters aroma with malt sweetness. Hazy orange body. Wonderful complexity on flavor, malt forward, but noticable hops and fruity citrus.

22 ounce bottle, bottled on 4/8/2011.  Served in a tulip, the beer pours a hazy orange/amber color with about an inch off-white head.  Head retention is good, and there’s a decent amount of lacing left on the glass.  The brew smells like citrus (orange peel, lemons), yeast, apricots, pears, cloves, and some other sweet spices.  Taste is pretty much just like the aroma, but there’s also some bready malt and apple flavors noticeable.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, it’s a bit coating and has high, but soft carbonation which helps make this brew very easy to drink.  I think it’s a good overall beer, and it’s definitely worth trying.

Orange and hazy, so-so head and decent lacing.  Smell is of Belgian yeast, fruits, and a bit of earthiness.  Taste has fruits, mostly lighter fruits like apricots, pears, apples, plenty of great Belgian yeast flavor, a little citrus, some nice spices.  Body is lightly carbed and medium, with a lightly fruity, slightly sweet aftertaste.  It’s a damn fine beer, very tasty.
Bottle: 2009: it pours a dark, hazy orangeish color with a small white head.  Bready, yeasty aroma that gives way to a full sweet, bready flavor.  Tasty beer.

03-02-11 Bouteille 330ml Embouteillée 21-09-11: Belle couleur orangée cuivrée pâle, avec un moyen collet de mousse blanche et une effervescence moyenne. Premiers arômes funky genre orval en plus intense, avec des notes d’herbes et de craquelins. Pas très sucrée avec une moyenne amertume en bouche, mais plus légère en finale. Bonne petite base maltée qui fait un bon balancement. Corps entre léger et moyen avec  texture légèrement ronde et une asser forte carbonisation. Finale asser astringente sur des notes légèrement fruitée.  Saveurs pas asser prononcées à mon gout. :Bataille avec une orval, puisque inspirée de cette dernière (bouteille fraiche et jeune) et remarque surprenante de ma part puisque je trouvais la orval assez puissante, la Matilda est plus puissante, mais pas plus complexe et la orval l’emporte haut la main.

Bottle, 2006(!) vintage thanks to gwguest.  Pours clear apricot with two finger creamy head, impressive retention and lacing, lasting till the last drop.  Nose is lovely, with fruity yeast, soft orange lemon citrus, a little funk, pale malts.  Taste is similar, soft fruitiness blended with pale malts, yeasty dry finish.  Palate is medium, a little bit of sharpness from carbonation that competes with the flavor.  This really held up well, super enjoyable, reminds me of some of Fantome’s offerings.
Fruity, spicy, bready, citrus. Sweet yet slightly drying. Some banana, caramel. lively mouthfeel. Bonus points for having the same name as my daughter!

A cloudy, yellow-orange pour with a thin, white head.  The aroma has a lot of fruit and floral notes, plus a little spiciness.  It has a medium body with a somewhat oily texture and fizzy carbonation.  The taste is a little tart with mild warmth and a dry finish.
Goose Island really makes great Belgian style beers and Matilda is no exception.  This one is always a go to beer for me in the local restaurants and bars.
Pours golden yellow with a fluffy white head. Smells like fresh squeezed lemons. Sweet malts and citrus, has a funky sour taste. This is a great Belgium style and well done.
Thick frothy head off of pour with orange amber color. Flavor was not as deep or intricate as I had hoped, although my tastes were perhaps unrefined enough to notice details. A bit of fruit flavor.

Hazy orange pour with thin white head. Sweet fruity aroma with some grassy and spice notes. Taste is a banana, orange, light clove and even some faint licorice notes. Sweet with mild carbonation and medium mouthfeel. Quite tasty.

Tasted on tap at Olympia in Maplewood, Missouri, USA, into standard pint glass. Poured a hazy, deep orange color with moussy off-white head, long lasting with lots of Belgian lace. Aromas of grain, mild malt, earthy and slightly spicy hops, many yeast esters/phenols: apricot, pepper, banana, active compost. Bready malt flavor with mild hops bitterness, overall impression is tangy, fruity, tart. Medium body, fairly high carbonation, lingering bittersweet aftertaste. Well-crafted and well-balanced. I’ve never had a beer exactly like this, and I liked it a lot.
Very enjoyable. Much like all of the other Goose Island products. I would drink it again.
2/18/2010 bottling date. Clear amber color/ ivory head. Dusty pale malt buckwheat, light fruit, malt grist aromas. medium bodied. grainy pale malt, honey, floral, melon fruit flavors--good belgian.

Bottle at home. 2 year old. Hazy deep dark orange colour with a smal off-white head. Aromas of sweet fruits of peaches and some yeast. Mild malt sweetness in the mouth and a sweet flavour of camphor candies. Some taste of sour berries and alcohol. Round and mild bitterness. A fantastic interpretaion of a belgian ale. Very pleasant ale and distinct flavours.

2010 bottle from 99. Hazy, orange-gold pour with a persistent, creamy, white head leaving heavy lace. Nose is fruity with a bit of funk, although I suspect the nose is dampened somewhat by the head. Medium body and fine carbonation give a smooth and very pleasant mouth feel. Apricots, red apples, cloves, some Brett-like funk, oranges and tangerines. Finish is medium and continues the fruitiness, spice,  funk, and soy and tobacco umami. I’ve had fresh Matilda on tap several times and it can’t compare to this year-old bottle. Cellar this one for full enjoyment and drink warmer than you think you should!
A great surprise waiting on a flight out of Chicago. Spicy, fruity, hoppy at same time. Very drinkable and delicious.

Bottle 2009 drank 12/31/11. Pours a amber orange, with some carb bubbles and light head that leaves a fair amount of laceing. Smells and taste caramel, hay, floral, citrus, dough.clear, heavy cloying sweetness, lightly bitter, medium sourness, medium body, sticky, average carbonation. I really had no idea that this beer was going to taste as it does had to read a few reviews before I was reassured that the beer hadnt spoiled. It was very sweet like a apple cider/pear juice. Slight bit of hops hardly any small amount of caramel is coming thru and a bread nose. Weird beer I wouldnt buy it again but for what it is so so.
Cloudy deep gold, thin head. Aroma: sweet malt, floral. Good sweet malt flavor, grain & floral hints, floral lingers.  Medium light body, moderate bitter finish.   Nicely done

A - pours fizzy dark golden with small light head. 

S  - Aromas of belgian yeasts,  sour apples, pineapple, apricots, and banana.

M - light body with fizzy/bubbly feel dry. Sublte astringent.

T - Lightly fruity- pineapple apple on the nose, astringent grassy flat middle, with long spicy cloves end to light malts. Interesting abrupt move from nose to palate.  Better cold

O - A good fruity belgian brew. Interesting beer with no middle. Very abrupt nose.

7-
12oz bottle: Appearance is a hazy brown with white head. Aroma is of stale malt. Taste is similar to Duvel, fair amount banana and various spices sweet malt backbone.

Long Island, NY - 2010 edition 650 mL poured into a wine glass. Pours a cloudy orange golden color. Lots of yeast dispersed throughout. Aroma us fruity with tones of berries and other exotics. Taste is strong of fruits but with a mind sweetness. The sweetness is balanced with a layer of hops. A well developed sophisticated Belgian Ale.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a clear light orange color with a thin white head. Aroma is Belgian yeast, honey, cloves, spicy. Taste was a Belgian yeast, vanilla, honey, slightly sweet and bitter; cloves and banana. Not bad from someone not partial to Belgian ales.
December 20, 2011 bottle from Lakeville Liquor.  Semi-opaque orangish pour with nice head and lacing.  Fruity and spice in the aroma and taste, with some malt.
Huge yeasty sourness.  Some people like that, I was reminded of fermenting hay.

This is a great beer there  were lots of belgian yeast flavors and  the banana clove  coming through in a flavor..glad they went back to original recipe. Had this several times and for awhile it was a different beer. Now the flavor is back to the way it was when originally released. Bread, cereal, banana, bubblegum, clove.

The color of apple cider, with little head.  Aroma of apricot and spice.  Good, but light malty flavor with some sweetness and a touch of bitter.  Also a bit of pine (the taste and aroma together as I’m taking a drink reminds me of a ski lodge for some reason).  Pretty good.
36cl, Vintage 2011, American brew, from De Bierkoning Amsterdam, complex brew, malty/fruity and slightly spicy/woody, yet balanced, hazy, good head, nice brew, yet expensive
Flaska märkt 2010. Bärnstensfärgad öl med lätt vitt skum. Doft och smak av jäst ,citrus och örter. En mycket bra tolkning av en belgisk ale.

This beer used to be better and seems to get worse every year.  - more fruits and less perfume. +++ Sampled from a 22 oz brown bottle this beer poured hazy bronze color with a large foamy yellow white head that lingered and left great lacing. The aroma was brett, Sweettart candies, perfume, bubblegum, lemon and chalk. The flavor is tart and chalky with strong perfume, bubblegum. brett, lemon and Sweettart candies. Medium length tart chalk perfume and brett. Moderately full bodied. Ok.

I had this on tap while spending the night with some of my best friends at McGregor’s.  Very little head on this deep bright gold nearly clear beer. Fruity nose with a subtle yeastiness. Medium body and slightly creamy followed by a pleasant alcohol warming. Sweet malty flavors with a hint of caramel are cleaned up nicely with the noble hops in a somewhat dry finish. 
12/20/2014.  Bottle dated 5/17/12 (0742) from Chris T.  Similar to above, but started harsh and malty toward the bottom of the bottle. Improved when warmed.
Spicy nose.  Orange attractive color, clear.  Sparse lacing.  Toffee in the palate along with oranges, lots of subtle stuff going on, quite excellent.

2009 vintage, consumed in July 2011.

The beer pours a hazy orange color with a white head. The aroma is very nice. I get some toffee notes, as well as some nice Belgian yeast and cherry notes. There is a little bit of funk and a little bit of tartness in the aroma.

The flavor is more complex than the aroma. I get some leather and funk like you would get from brettanomyces, as well as a lot of juicy cherry notes. There is also a little bit of toffee and some brown sugar mixed in. I get a little oak character, but it is fairly subdued. There is some light tartness.

Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

Amazing beer. First had at a beer festival, and have been enjoying it since. Great complexity, with a little bit of a bite. Had on tap and in bottle.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Ruddy pour. Definitely a good bit of spice and fruitiness; sweet, caramelly, dried fruit. Mmm.
On tap at Beer Bistro.  Clear copper pour with a small white head.  Fruit and spice aromas.  Fruit, caramel malt, and spices..

12oz bottle. Amber with white head. Caramelized sugar, yeast, orange, spice, some fruit. Light but medium body, sweet/sugar, average carbonation, dry finish, little bit of fruit and chardonnay, very well balanced, quite nice.
Nice amber/orange color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of yeast, floral, citrus, & spice; Flavor of sweet malt, yeast, fruit, some hops, citrus, and spice; Nicely balanced; Well done overall.

Appearance:  deep orangey gold, short creamy white head quickly fading to a small cap, syrupy lacing.  Aroma: candi sugar, spicy yeast, flowery hops, and a rather unpleasant note of rotting fruit.  Taste: sweet and fruity, with notes of yeast, spices (cinnamon), a little booze, and a surprising toasty malt note.   Finish: tingly, bittersweet, with that lingering brown toast note.   Notes: 	Not bad.  Nicely balanced between sweet, bitter and spicy, and I really liked the toasty, malty finish.  The aroma was the only thing that wasn’t in the ’pretty good’ range.

12oz bottle from Chuck’s poured into a Trappist glass. 2011 vintage. Pours a dark golden orange with almost no head. Aroma of candied sugar, dark fruits and caramel. Taste is light sweet and light bitter. Taste of sugar and dark fruit. Medium bodied with a creamy texture. Lively carbonation and a long finish. Overall, very good. Can’t wait to grab a 22oz so I can have more.

Belgian ale with breat. Dark golden colured and hazy. Has a white head, medium duration. Heavy breat-aroma, barnyard aroma, leather, faint sweet malt. Nice- Good flavor, acid, sweet malt, more barnyard. Dry, astringent, creamy texture and lively carbonation.
barnyard, leather, golden, hazy, white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, light body, oily feel, fizzy, long finish,

Refrigerated bottle poured into a trappist glass.  Pours orange with small white head.  Some lacing, medium body, medium carbonation, and aroma is floral & yeasty.  Taste is complex floral malt, yeast, and some spicyness.  Pretty good.

Hazy light copper pour with a massive rocky khaki head.  Wonderful light sour aroma with barnyard hints (only us beer nerds would call a barnyard smell pleasant!).  Nice dry funky flavor with a dulled bitter finish.  Medium/light bodied with a highly carbonated creamy small bubble mouthfeel.  Great delicate sour beer from Goose Island.
On tap, in a goblet. Clear amber-orange color. Thin smooth head. Very little splotches of lace. Spicy belgian aroma. Good crisp texture. Very easy drinking.

Has a very floral nose and taste. Very drinkable, would go great with almost any dish.

Bottled on January 29, 2010, consumed October 11, 2011. Have another bottle aging until 2013.
Tap. Slightly tan head on a deep murky ruby brownish hue. Woody, slightly sweet dar fruit aromas. Touch sour, dark fruits and grapes in the flavor. Bit sticky medium body with soft carbonation.

Perhaps something wrong with this bottle?

Smells very sweet of dark fruits and malt.  taste very sweet, yeast, and with little bitterness.  It’s sticky and lingers with something ashy and acrid on the back of the throat.

This poured a darker red color with a beige head. Aroma was some dark caramel, dark fruits, belgian candy sugar, and some yeast and spice.  Flavor was a bit sweet, mainly burnt sugar and dark fruits with some nice spice too. Different.
Wow, was this one complex.  Fruit, earth, burnt brown sugar, yeast, beets and booze all brought together to make a pretty damn good beer.
Pours a crisp amber.  Fairly heavy, bubbling head.  Distinct apple/cider aroma.  Described a Belgian/Pale Ale hybrid, reminds me more a bitter cider.  Not quite what I expected, but pretty good.
Bottle, pours ruddy topaz w/ foamy quickly-dissipating white head, aroma is curried carrot, some burnt sugar, curried caramel throughout w/  warm rummy finish, nice

Bottle at another Irish place. Pours slightly cloudy golden-orange with a minimal ring of a head. Nose hints at the Belgian yeast character, but is otherwise rather mild. Taste slight sweet, some bitter, and a pinch of tart, and definitely Belgian spicy yeast. Palate is light yet exciting with a nice dry finish. A decent brew with lots of character. Refreshing but potent at 7% ABV. Glad I got to try it.

In taster at BJs.  Looks like a strong piss yellow color (which is good) with off white head.  Smells Belgian yeast on my nose as well as maybe some caramel.  Tastes of some relatively warming amber and a little twang of Belgium.  Little bitterness.  Overall 6 of 10.

Btl. 2009: no head, deep red golden colour. Fat nose with some nuts, orange, grape as well as a little sugar. Very fresh medium body and length. To fresh as I find it almost grapefruity. Sugar and grapefruit.

Pours amber-gold with very little head.  Almost no aroma.  Flavor is candy sweet with not much carbonation and not much else.  Not awful, but got to admit I’m disappointed.  I’m wondering if I got a bad bottle.

A little hazy amber colored beer, with a thick off white head. The aroma of malts, with hop bitter and fruits. The taste of sweet fruits, a little sour with some hop bitter. The aftertaste is malty sweet and notes of bitter.
Gold to orange colour with a nice decent head. Smells cheese, fungus, nasty feet, sour. Tastes sweet and yeasty. Light carbo, medium body.
Bottle. Aroma of apples and pears.  Sweet fruity flavor.  Champagne like carbonation.  Nice dry finish.

Bottle @ Joes Tasting shared with Joes and Dutchdrebus. Hazy light orange color, small white to off-white head. Unfresh smell: sweat, cheese, sour, sweet and musty. Taste sweet and yeasty, some wrong mango or apricot. Decent carbo, low to medium body. Bad bottle?

Not a favorite style of mine, but I can appreciate the quality of this beer. It has a nice bright fresh lightly fruity, lightly spiced taste. At around 7% ABV it is easy drinker, a nice beer to pair with a cheese offering a fish or a chicken dish.

Pours pale copper with 1/2 finger head and great retention.  Aroma is spicy Blegian yeast and caramel candy.  Taste os s[oce. caramel, coriander, candy sugar, some citrus, and balanced hop bitterness.  Body is medium, creamy, avg carb, dry finish.  Overall, one of the more solid offerings from INTERBEV.
A beautiful looking beer! Amber with a thin white head. Spicy-apricot, from what I can tell...
Bottle in trappist glass. Sweet, cooked vegetable aroma. Deep orange colour. Faint carbonation. Sweet fruity and bready taste. Very nice.
Fine belgian blond beer, with a strange spicy sour aroma and a sweet taste.
Tap - small thick head, dark amber color, yeasty aroma, fruity balanced flavor

2010 bottle. Pours deep orange with medium head. Slightly murky but not hazy. Nose is primarily yeasty, then orange, lemon and bit of mango. Nice deep malt and yeast flavour with bit or orange and mango fruit on the tongue. Very nicely balanced on the palate and an excellent interpretation of a Belgian ale. I like it. It’s deep flavoured, although not particularly fruit complex.
Draft pour: not a bad Belgian ale with all of the characteristics you would expect but nothing special.
This beer is really pretty decent, but still nothing much to it.  I like some more complexity.
2011 330ml bottle. Bitter Belgian orange on the nose and tongue. Hardy Belgian yeast vibe coupled with lots of hops also. Reminiscent of a ’Saison’ .Very tidy
Pours golden orange with yeast suspended. Aroma of orange, honey and spices. Taste is spicy and fruity, good hop kick with Belgian yeast esters. Slightly bitter finish. Very nice indeed

2-11-11 Batch. I like they date it.  Pa le hazy rusty orange,very ripe madarine or tangerine aroma bit of spice mostly an overripe mandarin orange, heavy presence in taste also.Lots of orange mandarine/tangerine almost an alcohol mouth drying,pretty easy drinking and good tasting mild soft citrus finish with some alcohol.But its really mandarine/tangerine orange going overall.A bit of yeast funk & very mild sourness in aroma and taste. Hits of pepper or alcohol mouth tingling sensation.Probably pepper like peppermint but faint pepper in feel.
 The finish is kind of weird like flavor disappears from the alcohol or something,Not a alchohol taste just a coverd up vanishing taste.No maltiness or hops.Pretty good-considering its young i wonder what or how good it would be aged
 You do start to notice more complexity as you reach the later portion of the 22 oz bottle. with some rum like vanilla oakish notes/vomit.  At the very end there is a heavy hit of sweetness with a soft but strong sharp quick bitterness. Lingering orange and carmel sweetness.I would definatly try this one again sometime.
Poured dark orange with virtually no head. Smelled of orange and carrot juice. Tastes of oranges and has an herbal spiciness. It was the 2011 version, so it could probably use some aging.
Sweet fruit (citrus, orange, something even sweeter-- maybe caramel) and zesty spice is what this is all about. Probably my favorite of the Goose Island Belgian trio.

Bottle. Poured deep orange gold with an offwhite head. Caught a whiff of acidic tomato in the aroma. Slight bubblegum which moves to a medicinal, eucalyptusy tingle and finishes dry and hoppy. Very good.

Bottle, 
this ale had a hazy burnt orange-amber pour and made a one finger white head that deflated rather quickly, swirling brought the cover back but it fell quickly, the carbonation was medium in this drink, and left spots and fingers of lacing on the glass that rolled off, I found a thin film of brown sediment on the bottom of the bottle, 

there were aromas of sour, citrus grapefruit and berry with some fermented tropical orange and peach sweetness, bread, 
this ale had that sour tingling, vinegar like touch and faint floral notes, 

the flavors were orange, melon and berry fruit with a little sour, citrus, tart fruitiness, 
there was just a little spice after the finish, and some fruit sweetness trailing, 

this had a medium mouth feel, I think a little more carbonation would help, 

an interesting ale with the sour and sweet nose but the palate was a little bit of a let down after experiencing the aroma.

Draught pours a nice golden color with minimal white head.  The aromas are amazing, with bubble gum, banana, and some earthiness.  Taste is sweet, but balanced, with the banana notes taking the forefront from the yeasts.  Great balance and very drinkable.  The body is heavy, and the mouthfeel is full.  Overall, a great Belgian style ale that delivers everytime

(2010 Vintage) A Belgian yeast  strain having sex with an American pale ale...Great nose ,musty cellar stench..some sweet fruitness ..caramel and richness .  In the mouth its vibrant with a fruity character ..some funkiness and mildly sweet.   A  very textured and slick intertwining of vibes .
From a bottle at home in Skövde. Aroma: vinegar and it tastes a lot of vinegar too Amber with a a medium head.  I don´t like vinegar so this is not my favorite.

Bottle. Golden beer with a nice offwhite head. Some yeast in the liquid. Vinous sweetish aroma, vinegar, spicy, figs. Spicy, hoppy vinegar flavor, some spices, fruity, figs. Vinegar finish. Interesting but maybe a bit too much on the sourish side.

12oz bottle. 2010 Vintage. Pours a golden/light amber color with a big white thick head. Very nice and long lasting foam. Good lacing too. Aroma is remineshent of Orval, therefore delightful: strong yeasty spiciness, notes of black pepper, lemon peel and flowers. Some maltiness to smooth the aroma too. No alocholic presence until now. Taste is great too: nice bretty funkiness, lots  of spiceiness, agrumes and flowers. Very similar to the saison prototype to me. A little touch of malty bready notes in the middle, then a dry spicy, light hoppy, finish. Palate is full thanks to the 7% abv and carbonation is lively. Overall, a huge, tasty and easy drinkable brew!

Bebida en goodse island.
Notas a frutos secos,frutal,se nota la levadura.
color dorado anaranjado,el lúpulo no prevalece.

Very little head on this deep bright gold nearly clear beer. Fruity nose with a subtle yeastiness. Medium body and slightly creamy followed by a pleasant alcohol warming. Sweet malty flavors with a hint of caramel are cleaned up nicely with the noble hops in a somewhat dry finish.

Nice beer, but not that much going on for my palate. It was mostly sweet, malty, with some yeasty notes and just a touch of spice. This one could have benefitted from a little more alcohol kick, and maybe a touch more hops. That would have made it an outstanding beer. Overall a nice beer, though.

Pours a hazy copper with a dirty white head. Nice spicy/herbal aroma, some yeast and sweetness. Flavor is spicy, yeasty with a touch of honey sweetness. A nice kick of alcohol finishes it off. A very complex beer. Lots of different flavors. Every taste brings out a new flavor.
A nice Belgian ale. Great color and aroma, very appealing color especially. The flavor however, is a little too bready sweet malt for my tastes and not enough hop zest to counteract it.

On tap @ Yard House Costa Mesa.
Deep copper pour with some white head.  Nose is fruitty, spiced, and earthy - flavors of cinnamon and more spice which plays off the fruitiness very nicely.  Pretty interesting.

enticing aroma is citrus and caramel and hay and spice and stone fruit with a bit of horse. it pours golden amber with small yellowish head. it has a mild balanced flavor. chewy texture, very lightly carbonated, with a long mildly sweet fruity finish. very good.

Poured into my allagash tulip.

Poured some what trough, produced very little head. Was hoping for a bot more but the aroma made up for it. Lots of yeasty light fruit goodness coming through as I pour.

The taste is very subtle with a lot going on. Upfront I taste the yeast then it transfers into a mixture of light fruit and dark fruit. I get a little bit of pear then a bit of figs or prune. Finishes with a nice dry mildy bitter finish.

Excellent in my opinion. I think I will have to get several four packs to have around and to age a bit!
Nice golden color with mild spiciness. Flavor was bitter yeast and spice. Lingered a little too long on the palate.

[Draft] Solid reddish amber hue, good head formation. Yeasty, bready aroma, touch of spice. Sweet malty palate, fruity, bready, caramel, some dry spice in the finish. Not as good as I was expecting, a little overly sweet.

On tap; pour is murky golden with a very modest white head that ends up ringing the glass lightly. This brew is fruity,  peppery, spicy on the nose. The flavor profile is apricot, light, bitter hops, peppercorns, spices, and sweetness from the malt profile. This is a nice brew....overall.
Lovely and clear, amber/gold, thin white head. Some fruit but mainly caramel on the nose. Sweetness up front, plenty of candy flavours, perhaps a little sourness late and some warming alcohol.

From notes:

Pours a dark copper color with dark ruby edges when held to a light and a two finger frothy yellowish beige head. Good retention, slowly fading into a lasting ring that leaves sporadic spots of lace behind.

Spicy aroma with hints of pepper and cloves as well as some alcohol, bread/yeast, earthy hops and citrus rind.

Medium bodied that’s slightly creamy with a good balance f light fruit, pale malt, alcohol, spice, yeast and citrus fruit. Hints of pepper and clove up front countered by subtle earthy hops as well as some orange and lemon peel. Clean and crisp with a slight dry finish. Well balanced and easy to drink.
Pours amber gold with a light white head and good lacing. Fruity aroma with hints of spices and malts. Flavor is malts, spices with hints of sweet candy. Light bodied with medium carbonation.

Poured a amber orange color. Full head.  Big bottle 2011.  Flavors of spices, some candy sugar, and some hops.  Medium sweetness with lite bitterness.  Ave carbonation.  A well balanced belgium style.  A warming alcohol feeling at the end.  Enjoyable.
Tried this brew from draft at the Yard House and unfortunately... I lost my tasting notes. I guess I’ll have to try it again!

Poured from the 12oz bottle. Color is cloudy amber, with a decent white head, some lacing. Aroma is spicy, and delicious, no alcohol in the aroma like a lot of Belgiums have. Flavor is good. Just the right balance of spice, bitter, and malt, love it! Mouth feel is fill bodied, oily finish, lots of carbonation like a Belgium should have. Overall a very good Belgium that is worth the extra money, I’m just upset to find out Goose Island is InBev.
Pours a nice amber color with minimal head. Has a decent Belgian taste, but I would not drink a lot of them.
Matilda tastes a bit stronger than it is, but it is very satisfying.  Fruity aroma gives way to nice carbonation & a smooth aftertaste.  This beer can vary greatly depending on draught or bottle.

Bottle (33 cl) from Ölbutikken, Copenhagen, Denmark. Clear copper, tiny beige head. A bit sourish and vinuous sugary aroma with some acetic acid. Light to medium bodied, low carbonation. Medium dry, a bit acidic, low bitterness.

Aroma:  Wonderful aroma of the malt.  More than I expected.  Yeasty hay and a little bit of caramel with some refined brown spices.  Some band-aid as it warmed up.
Appearance:  Moderate orange color with a thinner off-white head.
Taste:  The yeast is present initially on the palate and is more of a brown, savory spice element.  Then there is a very nice caramel flavor accented by the funky yeast.  The malt character is much stronger than I initially expected, but should have been obvious given the color.  Finally the hops finish with a nice bitter lemon peel.
Palate:  This beer coats well but is perhaps a bit too hot for me.
Overall:  Wonderful beer which marries the slightly deeper malt character with the brown savory spices of the yeast strain.  Excellent pairing there.  Hops finish slightly bitter and don’t overpower, extremely well done.
nose is hay, apple, warm alcohol, feel and carb are medium, taste is sweet hops, barn yard, then vinegum

Crystal clear amber, very small head. Complex aroma of yeast, banana, band aids, cherries, and some brett - like funk. The body is light, with flavors of Belgian yeast, butterscotch, and crisp green apple. It is dry, refreshing, almost cider like on the finish and easy to drink, and it has layer upon layer of complexity. Very nicely done.

Pours clear amber with thing bone-white head. Aroma is quite sweet with notes of lighter fruits, caramel, and spices. Flavor is of sweet caramel with hints of toffee and fruit resin. Finish is dry and spicy. Light/Medium bodied.
Bottle, pours hazy yellow, smells of banana and yeasty notes. Taste is good, it is yeasty and banana like good smoothness in the finish, good tasting stuff

WOW!!! I’m really digging the aromas. I’m picking up lots of candied sugars, yeast, cherries, apples, pears. All of that can be found in the flavors as well; slightly malty and sweet. Everything seems to be on point. It reminds me of a tripel. The mouthfeel is great, almost perfect. It’s extremely smooth and creamy w/ little carbonation.. very enjoyable. I’m really liking this one! It’s very crisp, clean, and refreshing and it’s easy to drink.

Unfiltered, orange/amber goodness with a nice little white head that leaves a coating lace. Yeasty nose with slight banana. Taste is typical belgian with a light, slightly sour clove and hay thing going on. Good carbonation and sticky mouthfeel. Belgians are not my thing, but this one is decent. The nice appearance will leave a positive impression on me and bumps the rating slightly.

A fruit and banana aroma fill nose. Beautiful dark amber color. Thin white head in tulip glass after 12oz pour. First taste is full of complexity typical of a traditiona belgium style abbey. Sweetness from malt and sugar hit first, followed by a subtle spice. Body of the beer is like velvet. A hint of clove on the finish. I tried this beer 4 years ago and still frequently indulge in this beer. I have stored several bottles to develop over time, only to enjoy its evolving complexity. Have found that after 2 years it really grows into something completely unique with its sweet banana notes, after that its hard to tell.
Orange amber with a decent head and big lacing.  Taste of caramel malt and citrus, especially dried fruit.  Light bittering at the finish.  Very drinkable.

Thin white head. Deep amber color. Very sweet aroma—somewhat fruity. Mouth feel is quite carbonated, leading to an interesting palate experience. Taste is subtle yet complex. No sense of anything socking you in the face with power, but a very tasty beer nonetheless. Solid Belgian ale.

Bomber from BOTW (Rochester), served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. 



App.:  Clear amber with a so-so light tan head.
  
Aroma:  Bright and Saison-ish, lemon, a little funk, minerals, clean, crisp, some yeast and bread dough, a bit of biscuit, more lemon, green bitter herbs, faint esters, quite refreshing and nice.
  
Palate:  Medium+ body, restrained but uniform effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Earthy lemon, lots of yeast and bread dough character, some bitter herb and Saison, biscuit, fruitier than the nose, minerals, esters, light honey, much more malt character, still fairly refreshing, but definitely veering more towards a Belgian Ale with some faint grassy, peppery hop notes; off-dry with limited bitterness and a nice, slightly alcoholic malty finish. 



Matilda is a beautiful name for a woman, but this is an attractive Matilda.

Headless, Clear Amber with Slight Pink Hue. Aroma is very weak, but there is a very light sweet alcoholy apricot. The flavor is also very weak, icy apricot, more alcohol than anything, kind of bland. Balanced but uninspired. Bottle from Chuck’s Wine and Spirits in Bowling Green, KY

Goose crafted a top notch Belgian here.  This is extraordinary.  Aroma is potent with floral and fruits.  Pours a hazy amber with a fizzy white head.  Taste is rich and fruity, shades of banana and citrus.  Carbonated pop on the palate, but a very smooth finish.  This is a superb Belgian from Goose Island.  Two very large thumbs up to this local brewery.  Job well done.

great toasty malty flavor. finishes with a bready banana. figs and dates
linger at the end. pours a beautiful honey brown color.  has a nice bite of carbonation as well.

Just wanted to put my 2 cents in.  This beer is such an affordable luxury.  It is strong but goes down easily, sweet and malty (like an abbey ale), fairly dark but not black like a porter.  Of all the beers above 6%, girls seem to like this one the most, so keep that in mind gentlemen haha. I may have a bias since the place that brews this beer is practically in my backyard. But either way, one of my favorites

Both fresh from the brewery and an aged 22oz bottle. Rich, tasty american belgian. Hazed orange-gold pour with thin off-white head. Aroma rich with fruity yeast, sweetness and grains. Tart citrus, juicy body with drying finish. Carbonation is behind on this, but spicy-juicy yeast is wonderful up front. Wonderful aftertaste with citrus, crisp juice. Alc is perfectly balanced in. Very solid beer and aged a year or so very well.

Bottle at Goose Island. Pours a hazy dark brown with a small beige head. Not a great deal in the aroma, sweet candy sugar about all. Same sweetness comes through in the taste with some dark fruits and cloves. Not bad

Bottle at Dark Lord Day. Thanks for the share. Poured dark brown with small head that retained. Flavours and aroma of belgian candy sugar, cloves, some light roast with other dark fruits. Very well done. I enjoyed this a lot.

On draft at O’Hare Goose Island. Aroma of hay, grass and herbs. Very earthy. Beautiful cloudy amber color. Strong citrus tastes with heavy bitterness and slightly salty. Slightly oily but still crisp on the palate. One amazing beer!

On draft at GI Clybourn hazy golden yellow with a thin layer of head.  Smells of belgian candied sugar, spices, hops and hay.  Taste wonderful light citrus, light hop note and belgian yeast and earthiness.  Mouthfeel is medium and lively finish is light and some what dry.

Split with McBerko. Pours a cloudy amber with thin head. Aroma is dirty, funky hops, rotting leaves. Is this off? Taste is rotting fruit, slightly earthy manure yet perfumey. There are hops but I can’t get past the nasty taste to really describe them. Bizarre but not all together a disaster.

12 oz. bottle, split with manuchampions, pours hazy golden orange with a small white head. Aroma of tangerine, citrus, barnyard funk and some sour / tart fruits. Flavour is quite grassy, with citrus, sour fruits, barnyard funk, and a somewhat metallic finish. Sort of a rotten fruit / manure finish that detracts. Not bad.

Bottle dated 2010 from BoE. Orange colour with a large white head. Characteristically Belgian seaweedy yeast aroma. Sweet, spicy taste with a bit of leathery compost and dryness. Extremely drinkable: this went down very well after lawnmowing on a hot day.

(Draft @ Goose Island/O’Hare) Served in a shaker. Pours fairly cloudy orange/amber with a finger or so of off-white head. Aroma of spice, yeast, light banana, clove, lily. Medium-heft palate. Flavor carries most elements of aroma but comes off fairly dull, simple and subdued.
draft at Jacob Wirth in Boston. fruity aroma..cherries, banana, cloves.  spicy.  very complex and tasty.

3 Aug 2010, botle. light orange, slightly hazy. nose is tart fruit/bitter cherries. smells a lot like a belgian lambic. taste is b/w Liefman’s and Cantillon. a little sweet and a tart dry finish. This is one of the best american Lambics i’ve had.

Pours out a yellowish amber, with not much for head, or retention. Smells very interesting. I’m getting some cinnamon apple, tangerine, very gentle hop bitterness, and that good old fashioned funky Belgian yeast. Taste was spicy yet fruity, yet funky. Very interesting. I’m getting the cinnamon apple from the nose, with some other light fruity yeast esters, with a dry, toasty spicy finish. Very interesting and tasty brew.

12 ounce bottle purchased at Holiday Wine Cellar a year ago ($3.79).  Pours a deep orange-amber hue with lots of small floaties and almost two fingers of off-white head.  Aroma of fruit (pear and cherry amongst others), caramel, yeast, and toast.  Flavor of smoothly sweet caramel, bready malts, lots of (candied) fruit, spice, yeast, and a hint of booze.  Nice level of sweetness and lots of taste for the style.  Good carbonation.  Relatively full body for the style.  Quite good.  (1038, 503)

Pours a rusted gold with nice fluffy head that lingers. Very slight lacing. Massive esters from the yeast dominate the aroma. Yeast provides a very chewy and full mouthfeel. Bready flavor with the alcohol present. Finish coats the far reaches of the mouth and some fruit shows late. Malt is solid throughout.  Alcohol is a little too dominating.

sweet fruity belgian yeast aroma, the appearance is a darkergolden/orange, first taste is laden with sweet fruity flavors and those flavors stick around into the after taste, overall good beer, my favorite lighter belgian beer

Hazy copper body, white head. Aroma of raisins, apple & pear, subtle fruity notes. Alcohol, sweet malts. Flavour has lots of raisins and winelike taste. Some graps with lots of fruity yeast. Little watery and leaves somehow thin mouthfeel. Long sweet aftertaste.

On draft at Cafe Hollendar on Downer.  Pours a golden amber color with a thin whit head.  Aroma is yeasty, spicy.  Medium on the palate with fine carbonation.  Flavor is sweet and bitter, yeasty, with a nice clean finish.  Very nice.

WOW.  This beer pours an unassuming semi-clear amber.  Aroma is straight Belgian.  Lots of yeast, sweet malt, and berries.  Taste is IMMENSE.  Huge caramel malt base, ripe fruits, some citrus, and lots of estery yeast.  This beer is a monster, and it looks so innocent... I absolutely love this beer.  It’s amazing.
Pours deep amber with notes of clove and spices that the roll into a medium bodied beer that showcases the fruit and the spice of the hops.

355ml bottle. Ginger cake colour with lots of carbonation and a good head. The nose hsa initially a yeast and green herb note, then there is apple crumble. The taste seems to be initially of apples and grapes, but as the taste continues, the over-riding flavour is pineapple. The finish is pineapple sorbet in fact. The palate is very complex, it is multi-layered with great texture and a clean finish.
Sampler at the W&C in Ballwin, Mo. It poured a light amber with a white head. The aroma was yeast, spice, bread, and lots of each. The flavor was caramel malt. Not a bad brew.

On tap at The Daily Pint. Poured hazy pale gold with a nice two-finger head that left excellent, thick lace. Aroma was mostly tart citrus with clove and black pepper. Spices, tart fruit also were prominent flavors, and were accompanied by a rich malt character and a gently bittering hops. Medium body, soft and creamy mouthfeel, and a lingering tartness.

It pours a medium gold slight orange cloudy with a white head, below average lacings.

It smells predominantly hoppy, but not a good hops, a mildewish hops, slight citrus(grapefruit) and notes of spices.

This not a belgian strong pale ale, I’ll go with an American Pale Ale. Its a complete sessional, I could crush many of these. It tastes light hoppy and citrus, very ok, nothing special.
On tap at  Cregeen’s. Not much of a head, but aromas of hops with some banana notes. Initial taste was filled with malts. Bitter in the end. Memorable.
Dejlig syrlig som en rigtig flamsk ale, korn malt, halm, citron, lys rødlig, hvidt, tæt kort skum, sur/sød, let, tør og livlig.
a goose island red belgian...good; but watered down, over rated, and lacking interesting character or respectability.
On tap at the Kalamazoo Beer Exchange.  Waitress got it wrong with "little sour taste."  It had great smell and good intial taste of fruit (banana) but ended abruptly.

On draft served in a pint glass.  Pours a cloudy golden amber color.  Aromas of fruit.  Medium body.  Taste fruit and sweet malt with a warming effect of alcohol detectable.  There is enough hops to make this a nice well balanced beer.  The Belgian yeast finishes the taste.  An exceptional beer.

Sampled out of a bottle and paired with baked tilapia.  2010 bottle.  Pours a hazy golden color with orange highlights.  The appearance is strange, almost as if there’s some chill haze involved.  The head is thin, approximately 1/4", and bright white.  The aromas are typical for the style, fruity, candy sugars, and some cereals.  Onthe palate, the fruits are tart on the open, but spicy hope and sweeter malts come through by the finish.  A very solid Belgian-style strong ale.
Mild odor, but nothing special in the aroma category.  Deep rich brass/gold color.  Has the taste of a Belgian, but seems to have mix flavor of an IPA possibly?

Light golden amber color, decent sized white head, clear....Aroma, fruity, little tropical, light belgian yeast, noble hops, lightly spiced.. Flavor, lots of fruity, light belgian yeasty flavor, decent, doesnt wow, fair amount of spicing, lightly herbal... Lively, medium bodied, medium mouthfeel, a little dry...

The aroma is very strange, almost dingy.  The color is cloudy and straw colored.  The flavors are very complex.  Its very hard to describe.  I would say interesting and drinkable, but not my favorite.

(2008 Vintage) Bottle conditioned, 355ml from Bellingers Garage, Grove, Oxon. Hazed amber with white head. Initially dry spicy notes emerge, almost a hint of curry leaf, the sugary notes seemingly developed out in the intervening years. The lemony hop note that then comes is a little at odds with the underlying spicy flavour, bringing in a fruity note. There is a little confusion of the palate. Otherwise it is easily drinkable, hides its alcohol well. Reasonable enough.

(2010 Matilda)

Pours a dull and cloudy amber.  Not a lot of carbonation, head dissipates quickly.Smells fairly yeasty and fruity. Tastes very yeasty, with a spice like a hard cheese.  Definite fruity tang into the aftertaste. Reminds me of fall leaves or spring earth, but it’s got some liveliness to it, tastes fresh.

Finishes quickly with a slight astringent aftertaste.  Light body, leaves a little bit of spice behind.

2009 Vintage.

Pours a dense brown/honey color with orange hues and a large eggshell white head that recedes decently quickly leaving some lacing.

The smell is spicy and yeasty. The predominance being clove and a bit of fruitiness. There is a light bit of funkiness.

Taste follows, though there is a lot more malt in the flavor. THe malts are very bready underneath the yeast. The yeast is very tangy and the spices are there as well. The funk isn’t really carried over into the taste to me.

The mouthfeel is pretty good, there is a decent amount of carbonation but it is essential in making this a pretty drinkable brew.

Overall it is a good beer from Goose Island, where the regular lineup is a bit unspectacular but their limited release brews are really good.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-19-2010 00:17:04

Bat 17, Evanston tap ($7): Pours a pretty light, reddish brown color in a Goose Island wine glass. Aroma of YEAST, malts, fruits, and a wee bit of hops. So, I like my beers to be yeasty, funky and all that. This wasn’t the extreme end of what I like, but it certainly contained many of the elements that make for an interesting beer experience. A good amount of complexity that balanced the slightly sour and funky yeast strain against the fruit flavors, sweet malts, and mild hops. ’Twas an excellent beer that attempted to do something that not every other beer does.

22 oz. bottle from Woodman’s Market in Madison, WI (bottled April 16, 2010).  Pours dark orange with a white head similar to an IPA.  The aroma, however, lets you know this is certainly something different; light tart lemon rind is at the forefront with Belgian yeast and sweet caramel sharing the stage in the background.  The flavor brings the lemon to an unexpected tart level but is well balanced with the sweetness in the malt.  Honestly, it’s hard to tell if the tartness is intentional or not but it makes for a nice beer.

Copper color w/ white head.  Aroma is fruity and malty w/ grassy hops.  Complex taste....good balance of malt and hops; although leans a bit more towards the bitter side.  Some fruity and floral notes.  Maybe a touch of caramel. A bit of an upleasant soapy aftertaste.  Medium body, easy drinking.  Good, not great.
Yellow orange hue.  smells of banana, hops, slightly sweet.  Tastes of hops, wheat, and banana.  Typical Belgian strong ale.  Fruity and light spce flavor.  Probably would not have again.

Bottle.  Pours murky orange with decent white head.  The head leaves a lot of residue that stays on the glass throughout the session, but the liquid leaves no lacing at all.  Aroma of yeast, orange, spices, and more yeast.  Tastes about how you’d expect, but a bit sweet, and increasingly bitter the more you drink.  A bit sticky in the mouth with a lingering sourness.

I’ve had this both on tap and in a bottle.  Loved it in a bottle, just liked it on tap.
Aroma is fairly fruity, some yeastiness present. Notes of apples, oranges, clove, and bananas.

Appearance is a cloudy orange to amber color.  
Medium carbonation.


Full flavor and body.  Some alcohol flavor.  Very tasty.

This was one of the "funked" beers that made its way to the market. The wild yeast strain added a nice aroma and strong flavor. The sour yeast was very dominate at first, but as the beer started opening up the sour subsided and the ale tasted more like its predecessors.

Pours a vibrant orange/brown color. A shiny head small and uniform bubbles. Fades quick. Nice lacing on glass. Aroma is freaking wierd/crazy/interesting. Barnyard straight of the bat. Big body. That was unexpected. Yeasty. Strong malts and finishes dry. Fantastic brew. I pray to the god of all brews that inbev does not change a thing about this.

The taste is a little different than the aroma, some figs come out in the middle and push out a subtle malt flavor. The aroma seemed aggressive and now a bit quieter flavor comes in and steals the show away. Sugary flavor from the beginning to the middle is lined on either side by colliding fruit and malt flavor that is top notch. Some tartness toward the end holds some orange and banana flavor together and stays after this beer goes down.  EXCELLENT BEER
Amber-gold in appearance, the flavor is mint up front, with hints of vanilla and white bread.  A very solid Belgian Ale, a good interpretation.

Aroma: Green apples, grass, banana

Appearance: Beautiful copper orange, nice head that dissipates down to a ring

Taste:  Very sweet, caramel.  Hint of spicy belgian yeast character.  Not getting a strong brett taste, but it’s a fairly young bottle.

Mouthfeel:  Thick

A good beer, I bet with a little age on it it would get more interesting.
This beer had spicy yeast blend that balanced out nicely, but still had enough of a fruitiness to carry you though the bottle. I liked it.

16th March 2009 
 Hazy amber beer with a good white head. Soft palate. Sweet aromatic malty beer with a semi dry finish. Flavour is difficult to pin down. Reminded me a little of Deus but without the intense and off putting water chesnut flavours of that beer. Very drinkable.

Bottle 2007 ..... Cloudy deep amber pour off white head light lacing .... aroma of (figs, plums) dark fruity yeast and caramel hops little earthy hop .... taste is smooth and a little creamy with sweet overripe dark fruits (figs, plums), caramel malts and you can definitely taste the beet sugar ... the balance is good and the hop is just present in a slight bitter taste .... a very nice belgian abv hidden well

Clear amber with a small off-white head. Aroma is primarily fruity, spicy and yeasty, but surprisingly also slightly sour. Taste is moderate sweet and also slightly sour. Lightly bitter and dry spicy finish. Vintage 2009. 180111

Poured into a snifter. Bottled July 17th, 2009.

3.5 A: Slightly hazy light amber color. Small particulates throughout. Aggressive pour yielded only about one finger of off-white head that has decent retention and leaves plenty of lacing.

4.5 S: Lots of barnyard funkiness with a good deal of brett. Pear, overripe peach, and hay are th focus. Belgian spiciness gives a clove phenolic zing to it. Very nice.

3.5 T: Surprisingly sweet. I figured the brett would dry this out more. Peach and pear again along with a decent amount of brett funkiness. Grassy hops lend a subtle bitterness. Candied fruits are prevalent. Not as phenolic as the nose, but it still exists. This is good, but I’d like it more if it was less fruity and drier.

4.0 M: Lighter medium body. Good spritzy carbonation dances on the tongue. Creamy and smooth.

3.5 D: Not bad, but not the greatest as outlined in the taste. I wish I had another bottle so I could try it again with a couple years on it.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-02-2010 00:18:07
Bottle. Smells of honey, molasses and sugar. Tastes of syrup, pine and nuts with a nice boozy aftwrtaste. Very good
12 oz. bottle. Good balance of yeast and spice, also some underlying tangerine citrus, herbal hops, candy sugar (but overall not too sweet).  Finish is dry with light spices. Nicely balanced beer.
Hazy brown with minimal head in the glass. Fruit esters and spice from the characteristically Belgian yeast aroma. Some toast, caramel, and bread on the palate with a spicy kick. Quite pleasant.
Pours a maple color with a short lived head.  Great fruity aroma.  Taste of sugar, yeast, and fall spices.  Very tasty brew.

Pours an orange amber with a short-lived white head. Smells of fall fruit, funk from the yeast, and hops, overall a nice combination of aromas. Tastes of those along with some honey sweetness and a full grainish flavored body I wasn’t totally expecting. Feel on palate is average, and drinkability is pretty good, with not really any overpowering alcohol or tastes.

2010 bottle, bottled 09/10.  Brett and dark caramel nose, herbal nose, some canteloupe.  Orange/bronze, thin fizzy white head.  Sweet with the caramel, little brett on the edges and a bit more in this finish, wonder how the brett comes out over time.

0.355l bottle @ Henriks, Bergen. Pours a medium clear dark amber body with a big-bubbled thin and fading head and some heavy sediments. Aromas of green apple, plums, mild yeast, sugar and some honey. Quite on the bready side. Mild, well balanced and really nice. Can’t understand why I’ve never tried this before!
Pours an amber body with no head. Aroma is spicy, fruity and yeasty. Flavor is yeast, bread, spice and a little goodness. Finishes dry.

12oz bottle. Dark amber color with a very minimal head, very little retention. Looking in through the glass the carbonation seemed a little on the  light side. Aroma was a little fruity, spicy and yeasty. A lot of the aromas came through in the  flavor as well. Very well balanced.
Pours like syrup.  Smells like bananas.  Its dense.  The hops might have helped me taste my way further inside, but alas.  Will re rate someday.
Bottle from Beers of Europe. Honey malt phenol aroma. Amber orange colour. Sweet, malty, spicy & strong. Quite smooth.
Bottle: Nice a good session ale, could drink a few of these. Food Pairing: Camembert Cheese.

Aroma of caramelized apple, pear, and a bit of faint citrus.  Slightly musty, a bit sour, but really complex.  Appearance is a deep yellowish orange with a thick head.  Tastes lovely - nutmeg, caramel, roasted apples, some banana.  Really terrific.

Bottle 35,5 cl. Poured amber colour with white head. Aroma is butterscotch and sweet fruits. Flavour is spicy with some sweetness, very intriguing. The aroma is very overwhelming with each sip one takes. Delicious beer.
In the vain of Belgian Abby Ales, the Matilda was lighter and sweeter than most, but still offered plenty of flavor.  A wonderful appetizer beer.

12 oz bottle from Wegmans for $1.66. Pours totally clear amber, finger of white head. Not a whole lot of lacing. Aroma is spicy and sweet like melon. Flavor is a strange combination of more spice, melon, and a pretty prevalent alcohol burn. Even with a small cold, this beer has a lot of diversity. Medium body, creamy finish, moderate amount of carbonation, and a long sweeping finish with a little bitterness. 

Interesting beer, and with this asinine deal that Wegmans has going, I’ll get a couple more bottles of this to store and revisit when I don’t have a cold.

Matilda on hieman kuparin värinen ja punertava olut pienellä valkoisella  vaahdolla. Rouvan aromi on voinen, maltainen ja hedelmäisen marjaisuuteen vivahtava. Hedelmäisyys ja suklainen, karamellinen maltaisuus maussa on todella raikas ja jälkimakukin tuottaa miellytttävän kokemuksen. Yllättäen tästä löytyy suklaata ja kaneliakin.

33cl bottle from Cask & Kitchen. Pours hazy golden yellow with white head. Nose; cloves, apple crumble and cinnamon. Taste; not as anticpated!, sour apples (granny smiths), lemony sharpness, peach, tartness with refreshing smooth-sour finish.

Bottle. Maybe something wrong with the one I had, but I wasn’t very satisfied. It looks good, hazy orange color with a soft fingerthick head.
Fruits and caramel...just something that wasn’t quite right.
Will give it another chance at a later opportunity

Just ran from terminal to terminal after discovering the GI pub - I’m sweating and have 24 mins before my flight boards… can you say ’ball warmed beer’? I am the classiest guy ever - sitting on a bar stool with a wine glass snuggled up to my nuts. Clear amber no haze, creamy white cap, legged lacing. Very spicy topped up with balancing dark tropical fruits, plenty of biting pepper, slightly sour and tangy yeast, apricot and lemon and some malt or whatever. I’m watching hwtbamullionaire and I want to reach thru the screen and murder everyone. Mulled oranges, very nice fruity aroma that leans on the tropical side. Raisins, caramel. Good spice, very malty, nears medium bodied, sharp tang. Yum-o

Enjoyed from a 12oz bottle in wine glass.  The beer pours a fairly translucent brown color, with a mild off-white head.  The aroma is an interesting mix of earthy hop notes, a caramel-like note, and some interesting spicy/woody/vegetal seemingly yeast-derived character.  The latter borders on being cloying.  Together, these aren’t really all that appetizing.  The flavor profile favors malt, as the sample had been aged for over seven months.  Caramel notes, slight spice, and some residual earthy hop flavor toward the finish.  The finish leaves lingering caramel malt notes for several moments, yet remains crisp enough to allow the beer to be easily drinkable.  Overall, a slightly odd, very interesting conundrum of a beer.

Bottle @ Home. Pours golden orange with a small white head. Aroma of sweet fruit, peach, melon, white pepper, yeast. Taste is again sweet fruit with melon, peach, green apple sourness, spices, belgian yeast. Medium body, medium carbonation, long sour / bitter finish. Nice silky mouthfeel. Bottled 010609, tasted 191210

12 oz bottle poured into large pinot noir glass, has color of peach / orange gradient with minimal off white lace.  Interesting aroma - definitely some fruity notes, peach, melon, with a kind of sour yeast aspect almost like brett...I wonder if a tiny bit of brett is in here?  Flavor is highly spiced, which give the initial mouth feel a refreshing crispness, and it evolves into a long, fruity finish.  Melon / cantaloupe, sour banana, light toffee, peach / apricot. I think this is really quite nice.  This might be my favorite out of the goose island belgians, a little more complexity going on here than in pere jaques and sofie.  Also a really unique take on a belgian ale.
Bottle. Amber colour with a small off-white head. Fruity aroma with some spices and horse blanket. Flavour is a bit sour with some sweetness, spicy yeast and apricot.
Two bottles, one infected, the other not courtesy of drowland. Infected is sour, bitter, some metallic. Non-infected is sweet, some banana, apples, mild. Enjoyable.
We were divided on this one. It started off like a subtly sour Belgian, but as I drank it the taste grew less and less appealing. Had a 22-oz bottle at home.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a cloudy orange/amber color.  White head is medium and disappears quickly but with a fair amount of lacing.  Aroma is mostly fruity with some yeast.  A hint of apples and banana at the beginning.  The flavor is spicy with some cloves, bread, and orange peel.  A hint of malts but not much bitterness.  Medium to low carbonation.  A good beer but not a home run.  The taste of the alcohol isn’t masked well enough.
Nice Belgian strong from a local Chicago brewery. Pours a medium amber on tap with a mild head. Aroma of alcohol and spices. Flavor is a little mild, but follows the aroma well.
Pretty nice beer. Very simple flavor with a smooth mouth feel. Nothing special though.

Pours a deep gold with lovely, & it really smells like Orval, has that light orange peel, & bready belgian nose, with cloves sneaking up as well.  Its definitely richer & sweeter than orval but still very enjoyable.  Body is nice & fat, flavours of candy sugar, caramel & spices.  There’s the citrus peel again & cloves & a lovely fruityness.  the finish is long with a real pleasant spicy nip to interact with the sweetness.

caramel, resin, woody, orange, cloudy, white foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, medium body, slick feel, average carbonation, long finish, 

An Amazing beer. It is extremely well balanced and has two distinct flavors.
On tap O’Hare airport L concourse. Hazy copper pour nice tan head. Estery Belgian yeaast nose. Flavor is caramel malt, Belgian yeast, fruity notes with a gently hopped finish. Excellent.

Bottle. Hazy medium orange body, thin clumping off-white head. Nose of clove, caramel, and hints of candy corn and pineapple, in addition to modest leafy hops. Somewhat dry body, fruity and estery, with clove, pineapple, white grape, and hints of banana, finishing with grassy, herbal hops and toast. I had forgotten this was reputed to be an Orval clone until my first sip; Matilda seems a tad chewier and sweeter. Very good.

Bottled on 11.21.2008. Consumed on 01.21.2010.

Pours a pale, slightly hazy orange color with a good bit of lacing as it goes down, but the initial head wasn’t too tall, especially for the style. The aroma is of slight Belgian yeast in addition to some sweet, and partially caramelized, malt. Taste is similar with the malt coming out a bit more and the yeast moving to the background. The mouthfeel is slightly watery, and the carbonation is fairly low. Drinkability is good, especially for a BSPA, although the flavor isn’t particularly outstanding, so it’s hard to go through too much of this one.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-22-2010

12 oz bottle, 2009. Amber color, filmy white head. Sweet floral aroma with some alcohol. Sweet spicy flavor with a hoppy background. Full body, medium carbonation. The taste is complex, but overwhelmed by alcohol. This might be great a couple of years down the road, but it’s not that appealing right now.

22 oz. bottle. Pours a copper orange color. Head went away pretty quickly but there was a thin film on top that lasted down the glass. Very nice appearance. Had a fruity with a little yeast aroma. Sweet taste but there was a sour cherry note in the back. As it warms, a piney taste came to the forefront. Very clean finishing. A great beer, will look for this one.
Bottle pours hazy amber.  smells of dark cherries and pepper.  taste is of pepper, orange peel, pears, other tropical fruits, yeast, malt.  quite lively and delicious.

12 oz. bottle from Red House in Renton, WA. This beer has a hazy peach, copper color. It’s very nice looking, and has a thin, almost wispy, head. Seems to be lighter and more airy than more Belgian Ales. Nice fruit and yeast aroma; it’s quite pungent. Juicy pear and subtle peach aroma. There is a candy and sugar aroma that blend well with the aforementioned aromas. Lovely sugar, yeast, and pear aroma. Very sweet, and effervescent. This seems to have a nice peppery touch to it, as well. Very nice. Simple to drink, and not too thick.  I’m digging this one.
Bottle. Golden-orange colour with an off-white head. Aroma is dry, sugar, malt, hop, spices.flavour is sweet, dry, sugar, fruit, malt, hop, spices, yeast. Nice beer.
Bottle. Pours hazy brown color with a small off-white head. Aroma has notes of caramel, toffee and oranges. Taste is sweet with caramel, toffee and oranges.

Pours hazy gold with sufficient head. Smells appropriately fruity (i smell pears/apples and some citrus), sweet, with a little hint of spice tucked underneath. Taste is similarly sweet/fruity/lightly spicy, but with some yeast action. Very clean and crisp on the mouth.... (is that how it’s supposed to be? i have no idea). 

Very decent.
Bottled. Hazy brown color, short head. Aroma of caramel malt, some toffee, slight fruity, bit yeasty. Slight sweet taste, bit fruity. Ok stuff.

Sampled on tap at the brewpub, and from the bottle at several restaurants in Chicago. Orange amber colour. sweet fruity and spicy aroma. Flavours of apricots, spices, white grape juice, some bretty and yeasty nuances. Crazy drinkable for some reason! I really dug this one!

2009 bottle.  Pours a gradient yellow-orange, very fizzy with a white head.  Smells fruity....citrus fruits, sweet fruits...maybe some apple/pear.  Perhaps some flowers as well.  Taste is similar with some subtle spice.
Creamy, yeasty and mellow with a low fizz.  A bit tart and totally yummy!  Definately a do-over.

12 oz bottle into Trappist glass. 2010 vintage. Pours a slightly hazy orange hue with a small dissipating head. Leaves a collar and skiff of foam with some lace. Phenolic aroma; some clove, wet rock, cheese, bubblegum, banana. Not as assertive as the Leffe I just drank. Crisp and refreshing taste. All sweet with no bitterness; meaty. Full-bodied with medium to low carbonation. Amazingly, although both are great beers, I think I prefer the corporate giant-brewed Leffe. I thought it would be the other way around.
floral, cloudy, minimal head, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, medium body, thin feel, soft carbonation, long finish,
Got a lambic-feeling from the nose, with a sour fruitynes. Flavours same as aromas, but more malt and a richer taste then the nose.

2010 vintage. Bottled on: 09/30/10. Opened less than 1 month after bottling (10/23/10) – purchased at Super Jr. Market in San Diego, CA.  
355 mL poured into Duvel glass. 
Beautiful amber color. Translucent. Like an actual stone of amber, yet liquid. 
Head dissipates relatively quickly, although leaves few small clusters of light cream-colored retention in the center as well as all around the edge of the glass. 
Minimal Belgian lace, almost inexistent.  
Light yeasty aroma.  Subtle hints of vegetable-esque aromas as well as spice. Salad greens; maybe kale, spinach. 
Yeast aroma becomes more pronounced as ale warms up a bit. 
Mild mouth feel, perhaps subtle crispiness, yet leaves a very slight dry aftertaste. 
Yeast pronounced more in the taste than the aroma, nicely covers up portion of the hop taste. Much less hoppy than Ommegang’s Belgian Pale Ale (BPA) – a positive attribute, in my opinion. 
Somewhat lacking in robustness of flavor; expected little more character. 
Slight alcohol at back of palate. 
Taste like it could be a session ale, although at 7% would probably advise against this.

Bottled (2008). The aroma has caramel malts, toffee, oranges, little dusty yeast. Hazy, brown coloured beer with an off-white, lasting head. The taste is sweet, has caramel, toffee and oranges. Medium bodied. Quite full for its percentage.
Pours amber with no head or lacing.  Malt aromas similar to a marzen.  Taste is on the sweet side.

2009 bottle from Nelsons South Wim. Lush copper colour, sweet honeyed botanical yeast nose. Light prickly carbonation and not too sticky mouthfeel. Well balanced malty bisquity flavour with a fruity middle and botanical bitter finish. Pleasant.

Tasted from a 12 oz. bottle purchased at Wilbur’s Total Beverage in Fort Collins, Colorado.  Appearance is a little more amber that I would expect in a Belgian Ale and has a thin cream colored head.  Smooth beer, even at 7%, but the palate and flavor aren’t all that exciting.

Pours a light copper color with a thin bubbly head.  Rather lively in the glass.  Very nice on the nose with soft fruity flavors like an orange.  Also a bit of yeast and some spice in the nose as well.  The flavors are wonderully complex and a delight to enjoy.  Upfront are the softer fruit flavors of apples and oranges.  This then melds into sweet honey, grass, and bread grains.  Just before the finish, there’s a little bit of spice coming in.  The finish is touch tart, just enough to make you want to pucker a little, and dry.
Orange colored brew. Aroma is fruity, yeasty. Flavor has fruits, yeasty, some sweetness and floral hops.

A: The pour is an opaque copper color with a fluffy off-white head that settles down to a thin layer.

S: Sweet candi sugar (a theme with Goose Island’s Belgian styles), caramel, and bread in the grain/sugar department. Some subtle, but at the same time obviously present, spices. I seem to get some nutmeg and allspice, as well as some slightly grassy hops.

T: The spices are more noticeable on the front end of the palate than they were in the nose. Bready malts and some definite sugar notes, but not exactly cloying. A light caramel note and some hints of strawberry and sweet citrus.

M: The body is medium with a somewhat low carbonation for a Belgian style beer, but not dangerously so.

D: I was hoping for a bit more from this beer. It was good, certainly, but for a beer that is talked about so much, I found it to be a bit uninteresting.
Shared by SoLan. Pours orangish with a white head. Nose is yeasty, fruity, touch of clove. Flavor is same as the nose and has some sweetness in the finish. Nice mouth feel.
Luminous orange with a slight viscous head. Estery & zesty orange nose with piquant orange clove tea note. The bid is likewise estery and clovy with a lively feel to it.

Had this on tap last spring. Colour... apricot-orange with a thick off-white head that slowly dissipates. Nose... redolent of fruit, esp. stone fruits plus yeast and spice. Palate... vibrant bubbles, lively acidity. yeast, dried apricots, candi sugar, lightly cloying with a dusty earth finish.

copper pour with a thin layer of white foam. Sweet and fruity aroma with hints of apple and raisins. Some yeast and spice mix with a little bit of farmhouse funk. Flavor starts off with a lightly funky and tart note combining with some sweet malts and caramel near the middle. Dry and tart on the finish with a very pleasant funk that lasts on the palate for a while
Another nice product from Goose Island. Very nice Belgian Ale. Much more complex than I was expecting.  Serving: Tap and Bottle
ambrato scarico schium amedia media persitenza naso furtao leggera speziatura peapta un tocco etilico zucchero caramellato buona secchezza

Cloudy orange pour with a thin white head.  Fruity aroma with a hint of spices to go along.  Interesting flavor---mild spices, medium citrus and hops, but the palate is not dry or bitter like one may expect.

Bottle. Pours a hazy orange amber color with a nice and big fluffy white head. The aroma is a mixed between floral notes and some perfume. Can definitely pick out the brett notes in the nose. The taste is very similiar to the nose with the floral type tastes hitting me first that is balanced with some sweetness. Some spice as well. Ends rather crisply. A solid beer for me. Medium/light mouthfeel.

On tap @sleepydog. Nose has a slight spiciness, almost a dry musty aroma. Served in the right glass has a champagne like color. Sharp fruit flavors some honey notes. leads to a spicey body with a malty candy aftertaste.  Not an easy drinking beer, this one’s a sipper. A great afterdinner drink.
