12 oz bottle pour.  Body is light amber with a foamy white head.  Leaves the slightest bit of lacing.  Aroma is yeast, spice, and bread, and plenty of each.  The caramel malt comes through in the flavor, as does a little bitterness.  A very good Belgian, imo.

Clean, golden yellow pour with little white head. Full saison-esque aroma of spice, pear, and brown sugar. Flavor is brown sugar, spice, and pine. Sharp and bitter in the finish. I like getting these qualities without the bubblegum notes that often accompany something with this profile.

Dark amber and well carbonated - fruity , medium texture.  Possibly needed a bit more time in the bottle to finish it off. Mine was bottled on 2/10 and drank in 9/10. The strong Belgian body and texture I was expecting may have developed more had it been older. Good citrus and spice taste though.

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 12oz bottle into a tulip glass. The label has the year (2009) and a "Bottled On" date of 09/18/09. The ABV is listed as 7%. They mention "Belgian Style Ale" on the label but don’t say which Belgian style it is.

Appearance: The body has warm reddish orange amber color with a cloudy haze. A thick and tall off white head caps off the beer and makes some nice lacing on the glass.

Smell: In the nose I pick up lots of good things. There are notes of spicy and medicinal phenols with tropical fruit, yeast and sweet honey like malt. It also has a light touch of funky earthy hops.

Taste/Palate: On the tongue there is a tasty mix of all the spicy/medicinal and yeast notes with some tropical fruit and honey sweetness. The funky and sweet notes are tempered with a good balance of earthy dry hop spice and bitterness. With its medium to full body I get a slightly different mix of flavor notes each time. The texture is kind of smooth and dry with a nice level of carbonation. 

Notes: This is an absolutely wonderful and complex Belgian Style Ale.

Orangish in color; cloudy; short-lived porous head. Spicy fruit cake and cider aromas... dry, fruity. Interesting, not your typical abbey trippel and despite the homage to Orval doesnt really taste like Orval to me.

Bottle from Nelson Wines, Merton. Amber pour with an off-white head. Citrus nose which just oozes out. Very fruity indeed. Tangy citrus flavours too with a hint of caramel. Sweet, fruity finish. Competent brew, holds up well.

Tap at Beer, Bourbon and BBQ Festival in NYC. Pours a cloudy, amber-gold with a medium, off-white head. Aroma holds some Belgian yeast with light funk. Flavor is fairly sweet with caramel, along with yeast, alcohol and some spices. Medium in body wtih fine carbonation. Finishes with some Belgian funk and sugars. Good stuff.
Part of a mix a six from the local liquor store.  Pours a dark yellow.  Aroma is raison, clove, allspice, and bread.  Taste is much of the same.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a thin, off white head, over a clear, dark gold (SRM 6) body.....nose is spice, bit of clove, slight allspice, tiny bit of funk.....taste is light bubblegum/banana, bit of sweet malt, leading to a light gentle bitterness.....mouth feel is on the light side of medium, carbonation low. A nice example of a Golden Belgium. BJCP 6/3/13/4/6

Tasted a bit like a sour-ale to me. Aroma is fruity with cherries, lime and a bit of malt and yeast. Taste is very sour and sharp with spices and fruits in it. Not what I expected - but nice indeed (:
A must for whenever traveling through Chicago.  Unfortunately they don’t distribute to Atlanta yet.

(355 ml bottle from Alko. Rated @ 18.8.2010.)

Pours a hazy amber colour without a head. Fruits, malts and spices on the aroma. A bit of caramel too. Cherries, raisin, dark chocolate and yeast on the taste. Mild bitter finish. Pretty good for a US Belgian Ale.

Serving: 22 oz. bottle (no, not the infected one... unfortunately) from Julio’s Liquors. 

Aroma: The nose is yeast with a bit of overripe fruit.  A bit musty and dirty.  Perhaps a touch of barnyard.  

Appearance: It pours a slightly hazy deep amber color with a small, foamy, off-white head.  The head fades fairly quickly. 

Taste: Fruity and slightly sweet with a unique funky note.  Not sour, but odd.  There is some peach and apricot jam, a bit of fruit past it’s prime, and a hint of yeast.  I can see the Belgian influences but this one lacks depth and refinement. 

Palate: Medium in body with softer than average carbonation leading to a sweet, fruity finish. 

Overall: Let this one age.  It just hasn’t developed enough character when young.  Glad I have a 12 oz. bottle as well.  I will see how it is doing in another three years or so.

On tap at Rockit Grill, Chicago.  Pours a hazy gold-orange color. Thin white head that doesn’t fully dissipate and moderate lacing. Light aroma of lemon zest and yeast. Flavor is much stronger, with lots of yeast, clove and a hint of candi sugar. Medium mouthfeel and nice clean finish.

12 oz. from Woodstock Wine & Deli.  Pours a hazy orange/amber with thin white head which disappeared quickly. Malty aromas with some floral notes.  Medium mouthfeel.  Flavor is sweet and yeasty with some fruit and spice.  Nice balance from the abundant hops.  Pleasant dry finish.  Very drinkable...good beer.
Hazy orangecolour with no head. Slight soap aroma. Yeasty flavour, hint of corriander. Spicey finish, short dry end.

12oz bottle of the 2010.  Malty aroma with just a little wild tang to it, light notes of stone fruits.  Flavor is exceedingly refined, not ultra complex, but it does have a couple of layers to it.  Just a whisper of malty sweetness, light caramel, dried fruits, not super hoppy, no hint of any rough edges.  This would be a very interesting one for cellaring 2-3 years - see if it develops another dimension.

Bottle. Dark, amber colored pour, no head. Aroma is quite wild, funky, barnyard and the likes. Smells quite like Orval, so far the copy is accurate. Taste is sour, lots of doughy-wheaty-yeasty flavors, wet grain with a bit of hop bite in the end. This one loses it’s points to orval in the palate, which was almost completely flat. The beer still tasted fine but was really let down by the weak palate.

355ml bottle. Bottled 18/9/2009. Poured hazy, orange color. White thin head. Aroma is yeast, fruit and spices. Flavor is very interesting, if one can use such a word; spices, raisin, hops and yeast, in a nice combination. Slightly bitter finish. Sure will try this one again.

again thx to those 3 friendly american guys @ kulminator !! 


head: white , small 

colour: orange amber , clear 

smell: alcohol, watery, sugar, malts, little metallic, marsipan, bit of pilsner like, overall sweet and fruity , nice! 

taste: bitter, malts, alcohol, hint of caramel, bit of bubblgum, fruity, bit of yeast, peach , deffinitly some sugar , texture is oily, mouthfeel in the end is uite dry , after taste is burny , and mostly alcohol,also something that reminds me of carrots, i kinda like it altough more body would’ve been great

12oz Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy light golden amber with a nice head that  is quite lacy and lasting. The aroma consists of hay, floral, and slightly spicy. Taste moderately sweet with low bitterness.

On tap pre-GTMW


After eating several plates of free appetizers compliments of Goose Island i tried my last sample. A generous pour of Matilda took some time to work through. Fortunately it was pouring outside so there was little motivation to hurry. This is a solid Belgian but I think I like the Sofie slightly better in a head to head comparison.



Aroma / Appearance - Caramel brown and a bit heavy in appearance this looks like the muddy water of a river at flood stage run through a filter to remove all the big particles. Wood, earth, hay, caramel, and onion rings interplay with the rosy background to create a warm impression.



Flavor / Palate - Chocolate brownie mix, oak, dark cherries, and a creamy mouthfeel make this taste a bit like a toned down sherry. Because I was so full I could hardly finish more than half the pint but at least it was no charge. This alone was almost worth the crowds at all the bars.
Gosh, are Goose Island beers all good? I haven’t had a bad one yet. This one is not my favorite but it is still good. I like more body and flavor. This is a bit too metallic.

2010 Brew. Poured from the bottle into a Samuel Adams glass.  Pour produced a hazy, golden body, topped by a thin head of white foam.  The aroma of this ale is thick and rich, denoting a slight spiciness.  Other notes that I have picked up from this brew are citrus, and a balanced malt and yeast scent.  The flavor is layered, edging to a tart and sweet edge at the end of the tasting.  I picked up  suggestions of grapefruit and slight autumnal spices, like nutmeg and clove. Palate-wise, Matilda has a medium body, with a creamy texture and moderate carbonation.  This tasting ended on a short finish with minimal aftertaste.

Picked this up at Ledgers/ Berkeley, won of the better beer stores in the Bay Area. Always stayed away from Goose Island, based on the partnership with Bud, stupid me. This is a very drinkable, nice bready malto-meal beer that goes down way to easy at 7%. Unique yeast adds to the flavor?? Good beer, will drink again.

12 oz bottle - 



Aroma - starts off incredibly soapy.  After some time to breath a bit, some some toast and herbal/floral hops come out.  Not enough though to overcome the soap.



Appearance - semi-hazy, golden yellow body, HUGE, HUGE eruptive head.



Taste - apple juice, lightly metallic but lots of sweetness.  Seemed a bit underattenuated maybe?



Palate - over-carbonated, spritzy...took awhile to calm this one down.



Overall - not a favorite
On tap at Mahars. Had high hopes for this one, and it wasn’t a home run. Good but nothing great. Mellow and balanced, left me wanting more...

A light amber color that’s "glowing" when poured, but becomes clear after warming a bit. Sweet bready aroma. Well balanced with the hops. Complex yeast flavors are evident. Sweet, but clean finish. Overall, a very good offering from Goose Island.

pours clear amber with a thin white head and no lacing.  Aroms is sweet and yeasty.  taste is bitter orange with some hints of other fruit (cherry, peach and apricot are all possibilities).  there’s a honey like quality as well. Finish is hoppy balanced nicely against the yeast.  Lovely.

On tap at the Happy Gnome in St. Paul, MN. Pours a light orange color, almost amber...but not. Aroma is sweet with several spices and a bit of hops. Flavor is quite sweet and a bit malty. Moderate mouthfeel. A tad bit to sweet for my taste, but very interesting nonetheless.

Orangey-amber under a blotchy head of pithy hues, a few vigorous swirls release a brilliant nose marked by patchwork lace. Yeasty and doughy; I am immediately transported to the local baker’s shop, a fresh batch of dough is out being kneaded and the oven glows life-breathing shades of ruby, amber, orange, and white. Banana and banana pudding are already baking in the oven while in the back, an orchard of tangerines and tangelos are ready for picking. Bees buzz as I grab a chunk of fresh honeycomb to sink my lips and teeth into, but first I dip my nose into her sweet delights. Underneath lurks Brett, bringing me to a breath-taking conclusion of sawdust and leather. One final solo of citrus pith and skin, hold the wax please, and I am off to quaff my pleasures away. Full-bodied and rightfully sweet, I am at first taken aback by the intensity of her sweetness. Honey exudes while her comb offers crunch and earthy dryness. Tangerines and tangelos protest as I take fingers to their skin, digging nails deep into their sticky resins rich with citric esters before breaking through into the sweet meats inside. The pith and skin adds bitterness in the back while the meats inside are ripe for suckling and savoring. Dried grass and flower petals lead into the Brett delights previously promised in her nose, and I revel in the soothing presence of sawdust and worn leather supple to the touch. As she sticks to my lips, tongue, and all inner surfaces of my mouth, I revel in her playful banter of fruity and dry, sweet and bitter, grassy and leathery, all culminating in gentle warmth. The only surprise that awaits me is her lack of a finish, but otherwise, a grand performance with a satisfactory conclusion: my empty glass.




I really can’t find anything to complain about with my lady, Matilda. She wooed me in all the proper ways a lady should, and so I shall simply sit back in sincere appreciation for all the gifts she has blessed me with.

Bottle (infected!) - Cloudy amber with a foamy off-white head. Real light spicing and decent amount of fruitiness on the nose. A bit of spice, dried out fruit, and slightly sweet malt. Light sour notes, yeast, and faint grassy hops on the finish. The infection doesn’t seem to have done too much to this, but it’s pleasant and drinkable.

Happy father’s day to me.  I have to be honest, I didn’t take good notes so here’s the memory.  Taste was a bit more in your face than Sofie.  There was a bit more Orangish look when poured with no real head to speak of...unless you count the pour job by my wife.

355ml bottle, 2010.  Pours a hazy orange with a small head.  Aroma is cloves, banana and yeast.  Taste is quite sharp, lots of lemon to start, then some yeast and a tart, bitter finish.  Lots of carbonation.  Different, am definitely enjoying this one.

Sour malty aroma. Beautiful lacing. Fruity belgian yeast flavor.
Medium body, a little milky. Lingering sour finish.

Bottle.  Pours a deep golden brown with a thick, foamy head, and plenty of yeast sediment.  Yeast and spices dominate the aroma, which is quite pleasant.  The flavor starts out spice-heavy, with notes of cinnamon and cardamom.  This is followed by a bracing sourness, and a doughy finish, with spice and yeast on the aftertaste.  The flavor profile doesn’t go together quite right, and the mouthfeel isn’t up there with most real Belgians.  Still, not a bad offering.

2009 vintage...

Pours a pleasant amber color.  Nice fluffy head that dissipates for the most part but leave behind some spotty lacing.  Aroma is made up of doughy/bready yeast and some slight fruity and caramel notes.  Flavor has that typical Belgian yeasty profile to it along with some sweetness from the malts and a ever so slight intermingling of bitterness & sourness in the finish.

Lovely beer and something I drink quite regularly.
pours hazy golden light brown with thin off white head, some lacing.  A barnyard yeasty aroma.  Taste is light, chewy citrus.

2007 Edition. Bottled on 11/26/07.

Poured into a tulip glass.

Color is a golden orange. Head is a light white that leaves little lacing.

Smell is of a hefeweizen. Banana, fruites, and cloves. Slight hints of floral hops. Taste is of strong bananas and cloves. This beer is not very strong on the malts.

Mouthfeel is amazing. Very smooth and clean. Carbonation level is low, and leaves a slight dry aftertaste.

Overall, this is an amazing beer. I am sad that this is my last one. I would recommend this to anyone.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-29-2008 01:45:15
what a delicious brew. full of flavor. heavenly fresh. piece of art. Would certainly repeat.
Good body, little head. Coriander, clove, malt.  Balanced bitterness, long sweet and spiced. A solid Belgian, but nothing distinct.

Location: Bomber purchased at the Gristedes on 1st Ave, 7/17/10




Aroma: The nose has a decent amount of spice to it, some Belgian yeast, caramel, light fruit, and mild funk


Appearance: This beer pours into the glass a clear orange-amber color with a kind of big, somewhat bubbly, white head that leaves some lace on the glass.


Flavor: Flavor is similar to the nose, spicy yeast, decent amount malts, some sweetness, light hops, light funk


Palate: It has a medium body, average carbonation, and a decent mouthfeel


Overall Impression: 

This is solid stuff, a well-made Belgian style beer.

{thoughts} Malty and elegant Belgian-style ale; becomes cloying quickly, seemingly the antithesis of Orval. Enjoyable for what it is but frustrating for what it isn’t. Carbonation and dryness are severely lacking.



{elements} Deep amber hue, clear; thin, ivory head. Malt-forward aroma of biscuits/cookies with toasty accents, sweet ricewine vinegar notes, substantial caramel, hints of oranges and a growing thyme-like herbal quality. Moderately sweet, moderate-high acidity, medium bitterness; warming with a tangy vinegar element, cloying sweetness evolves with a peach/apricot baby food aftertaste. Medium body, creamy but soft carbonation, creamy texture.12 oz bottle, bottled on 9.18.2009.

Bottled 9.8.09.  Pours deep coppery orange with a small white head.  Aromas of plum, generic bar soap, lots of raisin and caramel, and molasses.  Nice and malty.  This comes through in the flavor with molasses and sugar cane, Belgian yeast, spices, lots of dried fruit, and some dark fruit notes.  Creamy and smooth, with low carbonation.  A nice, mild Belgian.

Bottle.  Reddish amber pour with a small white head.   Fruit and brown sugar aroma on it, slightly tart tangerine and berryish notes.  Fairly light body, pie crust and brown sugar malt flavors, more of that tart tangerine and berry hit, some clove and spice notes.  Very peculiar flavor combination.

On tap at Battleship Brewhouse.  Pours a clear deep amber color.  Aroma is of malts, brown sugar, black licorice, pine, and coriander.  Flavor has malts and big time coriander.  Has a very malty finish.

Came in a flight along with 4 other brews, and this one became my favorite quickly. Good aromas along with color and of course taste. I really enjoyed the balance of hops, could not have been better. Just plain tasty

2008 vintage.  beautiful amber and clear until I filled the glass with yeast.  high carbonation and a rocky head that stays with it. nice, classic, brett aroma-funk, barnyard, possibly some sour cherry type tartness, and maybe some other sweet fruit aromas coming through.  Initially, the taste is amazing with brett then some malt sweetness come through and takes away the goodness that i’m loving but it gets better as you finish the glass.  Very dry in the finish and very little bitterness.  great!

Draft.   A dark brown body with an off white head.  Some retention.  Aroma was a mix of fruity malt notes wheat, yeasty goodness. and a subtle sweetness.  Sweetness was a little more prevalent in the taste but it was not cloying in anyway.    Flavor also had a unique fruit note to it which was probably from the yeast strain. Good bread notes through out.  Palate was full.  A good beer.

22 oz bottle.  Caramel amber pour with the thin off white head.  Aroma of brown sugar, dark fruit and yeast.  Thin mouthfeel, with a great taste of caramel, brown sugar and molasses with a slight bite in the finish.

[2871-20100516] Bottle. Fruity pineapple and cooked ham steaks aroma. Slightly hazy, dark orange amber body with a quick foamy white head. Pineapple apple fruit flavour. Medium body. Drinkable, great for a patio, nicely blended alcohol.

(w/ jerc)

The pour was orange with a frothy little head and a bit of lacing.  A stream of bubbles make their way upwards refueling the head.  The aroma was a bit funky as was the flavor.  Tart orange flavor with apples and other fruit.  A bit of a leathery feel.  The sourness was there, but not overpowering.  I kept going back and forth wondering if it needed a bit more sweetness and concluding, "Nah, it’s fine."  A pretty good beer...worth seeking out.

Bottle dated: 030206

Appearance- This beer was a gusher! I lost 1/4 of the beer upon opening. I was warned ahead of time so thankfully I was prepared. The beer poured a nice hazy orange with a huge, cloud like fluffy off white head. Lacing was present throughout the short life of the beer.

Smell- Wow. Nice hints of cherries,apples, citrus and barnyard mustiness.

Taste- The smell and taste are almost identical. It has a nice malty sweetness with again hints of cherry, apples and citrus. The beer also has a nice sour quality to it as well. The hops add a nice spicy pepper quality and give it some bitterness.

Mouthfeel- Nice medium body with lots of carbonation.

Overall- An incredible beer that I wish we could get ahold of down here in Louisiana. My former boss at Southern Eagle who gave me this beer can help with that! (Hint, hint Trey!) Goose Island did a great job recreating a Belgian beer.

Bottle from BOLTZ7555.  Thanks Jason!  12oz bottle.  Amber color and pours with a pencil thin head.  Very little head retention.  Grassy and malty in the aroma along with hay notes, orange peel and lemon zest.  Flavor shows sweet bready malt, tart citrus fruit (no, not infected), corn syrup, grass, and light spice notes in the finish.  Too much corn syrup sweetness and not enough spice, funk or whatever else to balance it out.  Not bad but not nearly as good as Sofie or Juliet.

Sampled at SIBF 2010. Pours orange. Lots of sweet caramel and overripe fruit in here, as well as some stale hops - this is something like a super-hopped helles. Maybe even a bit of oakiness. Certainly flavorful - but unbalanced - it needs more counter to the sweetness.
Bottle.Pours ambeer orange whit an off-white head.Aroma of peachy american hops and malt.Flavour is spicy yeast ,malt , alcohol and bitter hops.Medium body . Very nice ale.

12 ounce bottle courtesy of DeadGirl. Thanks! Opened on 6/10/10, 2010 vintage. Pours a hazy golden color with a thin head. Fair head retention and not much lacing to speak of. Aroma is toasty and caramelly with a candi sugar vibe. The taste is caramel, candi sugar, toastiness, apples and other fruity notes and a faintly floral hop finish. Medium bodied. Decent beer.

12oz bottle. 2009 vintage. Brown pour with small particles hanging out.Small white quickly receding head. Aroma is fruity and estery, with some peppery notes. flavor is fruity, strawberry, pine, banana. Very tasty! Dry mouthfeel.

This has a sweet & sour aroma but the flavor is more sweet. Hay, Honey, cereal, dough, barnyard, butterscotch,  Tastes like a Belgium Trippel. Not bad but pretty sweet. The alcohol is warming nicely. Classy beer.  Overall decent beer, kind of wine like.

(12 oz bottle into Orval glass).  Pours a dark orange with white head.  Brett is noticeable with basement aromas.  Taste is sour with some sweetness following.  Slightly puckering in a sour apple jolly rancher kind of way.  Medium bodied yet still somewhat thin.  Finish is a pleasing sourness.  Caveat:  I don’t generally like sours.  I find this one to have a muted sourness that I find quite nice. Even though I no longer live in Chicago, I spent many, many evenings in the Clybourn pub so I’m probably giving it a couple extra points because of my homerism. Nevertheless, I do genuinely like it.  When it first came out I didn’t care for it.  Perhaps I’m starting to finally ’get’ the whole sour beer thing now??
Bottle thanks to Rando7. Pours orange amber with white head. Little lacing. Nose is Belgian yeast, coriander and spice. Taste is sour mash, Belgian yeast, coriander and ripe orange peel.
Bottle 33 cl. Orange, hazy with a offwhite shortlived head. Aroma; Hoppy with some sence of spices. Flavor; Spices, some malt and fruit sence with spicy enidng. ok

Poured hazy gold with think dense white head.  Estery notes, malty sweet nose, midly spicy.  Flavor was spicy, well balanced b/w malt and spiciness, finished very clean and left me wanting more.  Palate was wonderful on the tongue, full and creamy.   A great surprise.
Well balanced with some hop and really interesting malt.  If you let it age a little the brett really comes though and it starts to get a little funky.  I love that!
Nice deep golden pour with a thin head. Citrus pine hops with an ununapealing after taste. Try it. You’ll like it.

20 oz bottle at RedBud in Theater district; Chicago, with Marty and Tristan.  Good nose / aroma. Hazy, amber color; medium to heavy taste with a touch of bitter....nice tan head...definitely one of Goose Island’s better beers...will try again some night.

12 oz Pours a hazed amber with medium head.  Nose of raisins, almost funky, hops, yeasty, spicy and bread maybe?   Taste is decently bitter with a nice spicy yeast character rounded out by a mild sourness.  Palate is surprising smooth and extremely well balanced for a medium bodied beer.  I like it a lot would get again.

Sampled at American Craft Beer Fest 2010. Pours golden amber with a thick off-white head.  Aroma and flavor of malt with the spicy Belgian yeast.  A corn component to the finish.  Not as good as the Goose Island Fleur, but alright.vanilla, 
Edit: Poured from a 2012 bottle in a cup.  Aroma of floral hops and spicy yeast.  Flavor has hints of bretty sourness.   A pretty good beer.
Reddish copper with thin white head. Slight bready aroma. Up front Belgian flavor from the yeast and a nice sweetness without being too much. Yeasty ester on the finish. Nice beer.
From Rodman’s in DC.  Nice belgian ale, malty taste, sweet nose, somewhat sour - I dunno if that is because my bottles are a month or so old.  Interesting.
Bottle. Murky amber color, little head. Aroma is fruity with raisins and nuts in it. Later on, the flavor is rather spicy and has a bit of yeast in it. Very enjoyable!

Bottle. Moderate cookie note for the malt, light perfume and flowers for the hops, light broth for the yeast with toffee, honey, sweet German wine and ripe pear in the background. Head is small, wispy, white with fair lacing and is almost fully diminishing. Color is slightly hazy amber/orange. Flavor starts moderately sweet and lightly acidic, and the finish is lightly acidic and slightly bitter. This is an excellent Belgian Ale. There is no doubting the quality that went into making this beer.

Batch 2010. Pours a clear orange amber with a thin head and moderate retention and laceing. It has a spicy and floral smell, full of burnt orange peel and hints of candy. the flavor is tangy with orange and caramel malt. You can taste some hints of nuts and funky yeast, all cheese and leather. Overall it has a good balance of malt and carbonation.

Wonderfully fruity and spicy yeasty notes with caramel malty sweetness  over hops. Nice golden color, little to no head retention, no lacing but legs. Delicious sweetness with some bitterness to balance and some sourness from Brett. Medium body, creamy texture with active carbonation and some warmth from alcohol. Nice long finish. First bottle of this but certainly not the last! This is an earlier bottling than the recalled batches, but I’d be curious just to taste what the brewmaster considers as out of spec sourness on the infected batches. What a fine beer this is! Much different than the Orval that inspired it but it rightfully stands right up there beside it as far as wonderfully crafted Belgian Specialty ales (with Brett added) go.
@CBC–12oz bottle-pours a white head and gold color.  Aroma is pepper/spice, light malt.  Taste is pepper/spice, sweet light malt-bready/caramel, yeast.  Drying finish.
Tap at Churchkey,  Bright golden color, white head, solid lacing.  Aroma of PB&J sandwich on rye bread.  Taste is very malty, but good balance.  Nice stuff.
A golden color with foam off-white head.  A very fruity aroma indeed with plenty of spice.  The body is much the same, with a dry yeasty finish.

I had this on tap during a rough day, so maybe I should try this one again on a better day.  This is actually the "gateway" beer that truly had me paying attention to other limited edition brews from craft brewers, I’ve had on and off over the past 3 years but haven’t had it in over a year.  This is somewhere between an Amber Ale and a Belgian Ale, definitely a caramel characteristic in both aroma and taste.

This is a big time malt bomb with heavy brett funk in both the nose and flavor. Taste is massive, sharp, sort of fruity but pretty simple. Wild nuclear orange color with major sediment. Awesome mouth, thick and lingering with heavy carbonation. Great brew.
Pours orange brown color with a very thin white foam head.   Has an aroma of caramel and yeast.  Has a caramel syrup taste.   Yeasty.   Subtle bitterness.   Not enough carbonation.   Not balanced.
Had this on tap, little head, clear golden with no lacing. Heavy yeast taste, with lots of banana and bubblegum. Alcohol comes through too much.

Sampled in a 12oz bottle. Pours light brown. A little cloudy but it clears up nicely. A really malty brew. Drinks really nice and smooth. Aroma is nice and sweet. A really nice overall brew and good quality alcohol strength.

pour is light amber pour, slight fizzy white head.  Aroma is candi sugar, huge caramel malt aroma, Flavor is a ridiculous amount of caramel malt, super sweet and complex malt\.  Incredibly yeasty, silky smooth in the mouth.  Yum

A nice clear golden damber pour with a lively thin white head;. The aroma is massively biscuity and bready with huge toffee and caramel notes. The flavor comes in with a nice note of caramel- massive amounts actually. Toffee and biscuit come in later with lots of belgian dough and spice. Really incredible example of the style. The palate is smooth, slippery, and supple with a clean sweet finish.

12oz Bottle – Gravity Beer Market – Olympia, WA

Dark golden in color, clear with a thin head.  Lots of Belgian yeast aroma and flavor.  Good malt backing with a spice this was a decent Belgian ale .

Pours a nice dark golden color with an egg shell white head. Head fades dues the 7% ABV. Smell has a nice yeasty/malty smell with a bit of alcohol present. The beer is nicely carbonated with a mild malty flavor with a hint of spice. A well balanced beer that doesn’t get too sour or too sweet. Refreshing enough for a hot day but could do equally well on a colder day.

bottle. Pours slightly hazy amber with thin white head.  Tastes sour and it hits you if you’re not expecting and I wasn’t expecting it.  medium sourness.  Aroma is yellow apple and something close to currant.  medium body.  Aftertaste is not so bad.  Not of fan of sour; hence, will not rate it highly, but once I get pass the sour, I can picture some foods that would go well with this beer, like pie with fresh cherries...  Again, not at all what I was expecting, but it does go down smooth and leaves an enjoyable aftertaste.

purchased this bottle at bevmo in santa clarita as it comes in a four pack. gave away 2 bottles to great friends and poped open this one for myself. Pours a cludy orange with a short lived head. the lacing from the head is sucked back down gracefully. aromas  start off with bannana and clove. small hint of alcohol but the yeasty bread nose are lingering. Starts off quite alcoholic but follows with a classic lingering of clove. this beer i could say is way to young to enjoy now. i would like to see this one 3 years from now. must save the other bottle.

12 oz. bottle- Pours reddish copper with little to no head, aroma is cigar smoke (weird), and not really anything else. The flavor is fruity and floral, yet very light and drinkable. The hops come out more than your average belgian beer, which is interesting, could use more carbonation. Not bad.

Cloudy light brown, head settles to a thin film. Aroma of bretts, cherries and slight vinous quality. Low carbonation medium bodied. Sour tasting with fruit stale hops and yeast. I don’t know if this is a bad bottle or not but I do not like it at all.
I like the flavor but not much on this style.  I liked Sofia much better as a session style dinner beer.  This just a bit too Belgian for my taste.

Bottled. Pours nearly clear, orange, with quickly dissappearing medium head. Has a very loose, fine grained sediment. Taste is lightly sweet. Palate has medium body, lively carbonation. Aromas have yeastyness, dough, clove, herbs, spices.

A pretty solid ale here. Color was a clear orange with lots of fast rising bubbles.  The aroma was a bit sweet with some different fruits mixed in such as banana and kiwi. Some yeast aromas as well. The taste was a bit of spice with some grain. There was a slight fruit finish like pears. Thin mouth feel

Pours hazy, nearly orange with a brown tinge. Small head fades quickly to minimal lacing. The nose is mildly sweet, with a slight banana note, along with some other fruits and a yeasty, bready component. Sweet, malty, not very hoppy, with a hint of sour. Touch of spice on the finish. Very thin mouthfeel with not much body. Very tasty, but lacks depth.

Bottle.   Nice Orange colour with thin white head.  Pleasant spicy aroma with a yeasty note and a malty note.  Spicy flavour with a citrus tinge and a bit of biscuit. Lasting spiced fruit  finish.  Also I would swear I taste a bit of curry.

Appearance: Nice golden dirty orange blossom with a 2 finger white crown that exhibits medium retention and some lacing.

Smell: Brett, a touch of honey type sweetness, slight fruit quality.

Taste: Brett up front, fruit center, terribly disjointed finish. I can taste iron in the finish and it doesn’t work.

Mouthfeel: thin bodied with some carbonation.

Drinkability: thin enough to go down quickly.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 06-27-2009

355 ml bottle. Hazy orange colour, thin but persistent white head. Verry pleasant aroma of tropical fruits, spices and nuts, with a whiff of floral hops. The flavour is a lot like the aroma, with plenty of exotic fruits, some spices and yeast, and a nice finish of alcohol warmth and moderate, aromatic hops. An excellent beer, the only thing that bugs me is that I was not smart enough to buy more than this one single bottle...

Simple, classic label.  Lightly floral and yeast aroma.  Dark orange pour.  Sweet, fruity Belgian - pretty close to a dubbel in flavor.  Nuts, raisins, lemongrass - pretty complex.  Lightly bittered with notes of herbs, pineapple, and other tropical fruit.  Very nice.

2010 bottle (3/17/10 bottling date) poured into a tulip glass.  Light copper color with almost no head.  Very fine and sparse carbonation.  Very strong aroma that is noticeable from a couple of feet away.  A sweet and yeasty nose.  Aromas of light caramel, dried apricots, and floral hops.  Flavor resembles the nose; sweet and yeasty trailing off with some nice bittering hops.  There’s a light peat flavor intertwined with the yeast.  Excellent mouthfeel.  Silky smooth and full from beginning to end.  The yeast leaves a subtle numbness on the tongue.  Some alcohol warmth on the gums after a minute.

[’09 Bottle] Pours hazy reddish-orange with a medium sized off-white head that lingers well. Aroma is vitamin C tablets, tropical fruit, lemon zest, and a faint nuttiness. Taste is balanced between some grain, subdued tropical fruity sweetness, light grains, and hop bitterness. Medium-thin mouthfeel, slightly above average length finish.  Overall, a really nice beer that is a little reminiscent of Orval, while still staying markedly different.

2010-05-16. Lightly hazy orange body looks lovely in the light. Good sized beige head fades relatively quickly but leaves a good amount of lace. 3+ Aroma is rather spicy, mostly coriander I think, which dominates over the rest. Flavour is similarly spicy, lots of coriander, hints at dandelions, very light biscuity malts below, very light bitterness, touches of pineapple or tropical fruit meander beneath the spice? Average to medium bodied palate is modestly cabonated. A touch more weight or carbonation would serve it well I think. Well made, but not entirely to my tastes. 2009 Vintage Bottle from Liquor Stop, Indiana

12 oz bottle that looks little like the picture shown.  Orange amber with white head.  Nose is orange-citrus Belgian yeast and clove.  It’s a fine beer, but I just don’t like the whole orange-citrus and clove Belgian yeast thing.  Whatevah.

Pours hazy orange with white head, aroma is some fruity and funky character with a slight bread malt.  Taste is some esters with some biscuity sweet malt, going a bit of barnyard that fades fast.  Not bad, wish they would accent the flavors a bit more cause it is a nice idea.

Bottle at Lobby Bar in Ace Hotel. Cloudy amber brown with nice white head. Aroma is sweet yeasty wheat with some light barnyard/farm type smells in background. Taste is Belgian yeasty with dull sweeter malts. My sister says its a glorified blue moon, but it’s probably a little better than that. I dig the farmhouse/light funk going on but i wish it would come out in flavor a little more. Taste is pretty boring.

Starts off with a nice, Belgianesque aroma with barnyard notes and a beautiful orangy-tan color with a white billowy head.  A bit thin in body with a good, solid but not overbearing Belgian ale flavor.   Slight black pepper spice and a light sour yeastiness.  Easy drinking and good with food, a nice addition to the American Belgian beer movement.

Bottle.  Pours medium amber with an off-white head.  Nose has lots of spice and fruit, some grassy malt and piney hops.  Medium-bodied with average carbonation, fairly dry, spice and fruit dominate with hops coming through after.  Finish is medium, more spice.  A nice Belgian.

12 oz bottle w/ a twist of cap-2008 vintage poured into my Chimay chalice.

A- Body is a translucent bright amber hue. Pours with about a 1 finger white, soapy head that slowly fades to a thick collar. A volcano of bubbles can be seen steadily rising to the top. A lot of sediment suspended throughout the body.

S-Nose is of moderate strength but is quite soft. A touch of floral hops, and a yeasty presence that is slightly spicy, slightly bready, and slightly musty. Exotic fruits are also in the nose, but quite mild.

T-Taste is similar to the nose. Upfront exotic fruits such as mango, papaya, and pineapple are dominant with a healthy slightly spicy, slightly musty yeast background. A touch of floral hops is added to the finish and is a nice touch to the spicy yeast; which becomes more dominant in the finish. A slight alcohol heat lingers as well as a touch of floral hop bitterness and spicy yeast.

P- Medium carbonation and a nice smooth, yeasty body.

O-Overall this is a nice Belgian amber ale (I prefer my pales blonde as opposed to amber-but that’s not the beers fault). I’d like to try it fresh so I can pick up the "profuse amount of hops" stated on the label. It has a nice soft character and good balance to it as is.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-03-2010 18:14:38

pours a semi-hazy orange with a thin beige head that dissipates rapidly, and some lacing.

smell is of fruit, some hops, a little spice, and malt.

taste is thick, sweet fruit, some spice, and a little pepper, ends a little bit on the sweet side, and somewhat bitter.

12 ounce bottle poured into a Rochefort goblet. Pours a nice shimmering tangerine color with a creamy khaki head that leaves some filmy lacing and retains well. Aroma isn’t really anything special. I’m just getting some typical light fruit salad ester notes atop a grainy, yeasty background. Malty yeasty flavor up front that quickly morphs into a banana pith note. Finish is noticeably hoppy and dry, with a solid pepper note. There’s a mild astringency and the finish is rather short, but otherwise the palate is decent. Maybe a little thin for 7%.

351 mL bottle.  (Label doesn’t have writing all over it like the one pictured.)  Hazy orange with a thin ring of head and lots of suspended sediment.  Strong malty aroma has lots of (dark and candied) fruit and even a little booze.  As the commercial description suggests, the yeast adds a distinctive spicy note to the flavour.  It shows up early, along with come bready caramel and some fruit, especially peach.  Nice hoppiness arrives late and lingers on the tongue.  Medium-low carbonation.  Not outstanding in any particular way, but no holes in it either.

Had from 12oz. bottle from Hi Time Wines.  Pours golden with very slight head that dissipates quickly.  Lacing is minimal.  Aroma of sugar, candi, malt, and touch of hops.  Taste is similar with lots of malts, sugars, a hint of spice, and hint of hop citrus.  Finishes smooth, pairs nicely with umami.  Good, not great.

(bottle - 22 oz) Copper pour with a thin layer of white foam. Sweet and fruity aroma with hints of apple and raisins. Some yeast and spice mix with a little bit of farmhouse funk. Flavor starts off with a lightly funky and tart note combining with some sweet malts and caramel near the middle. Dry and tart on the finish with a very pleasant funk that lasts on the palate for a while.

Light amber with off white head - aroma of malt and hop, some fruity yeast - tastes the same of malt and nice hop bitterness, with hints of yeast in the background that continues into the finish - very good
Burnt yellow gold in color. Notes of appercot and apple on the nose. Spicy taste. Deep and earthy. With a slight sour finish. Yummy.

Matilda Belgian Style Ale--2010 12 oz. Bottle.  7.00% 32 IBU’s.  (3.75 / 5.0)  Belgian Ale--Golden.  Head starts thin and builds up to nice rich lacy white.  Clear bright bottle conditioned fizzy amber color.  No sediment.  Very aromatic Belgian banana caramel fruit ester hop front.  Cloying sweet spicy malty Belgian candy caramel fruit ester body.Rich with thick texture.  Dry spicy hop yeast hot malt end."WILD",but too sweet.  Sampled 5/7/2010.  4-Pack $12.99.
Drank from a 12 oz. It is smooth tasting with a tiny hint of caramel taste to it.

From a 12 fl oz,cereal, caramel, sticky, fizzy, bready.I notice that the notes reminded me of The Bruery’s Autmun Maple but i thought might be brown sugar but i guess it’s the granulated beet sugar.One of the better Belgians style ales I have had.
its that malt liquory, sweet alcohol aroma. in flavor we get the candi sugar, honey, almost orange. quick warming. not quite cloying. looks good.

Beer tasting at Milwaukee ale house.  Pale to orange in color.  Aroma is spice, fruit, bubblegum, mild floral hop, mild alcohol.  A little sweet in taste for my liking, but true to form.  Taste was much the same as aroma.  Good finish, well balanced, but not my thing.  May be worth a larger serving at a later date.

This is a flavorful Belgian ale, however, it has a sharp ending that comes with a young beer. I could see Matilda being a very good Belgian beer, but it would need to be aged for a few months/years before that young sharpness will settle down.

Sampled on 5/1/2010. This Belgian Ale pours a medium copper brown color from a 12oz bottle. Small to medium sized white foamy head, with nice lacing and decent retention. The aroma is 
Fruity and sweet, touch of yeast and some orange. Medium bodied Belgian Ale. The malts are fruity and sweet with some nice orange, peach and apricot aspects. The hops are grapefruity. Nice lively carbonation. Fruity yet not too sweet, nice balance between the hops,  malts and yeast. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. The aftertaste is slightly sweet with a slightly touch of alcohol.
lovely lovely beer, great smell and super taste. don’t know why it’s so expensive, but definitely worth a taste.

Beautiful orange peel aroma; citron. Fleeting but pleasant. 

Appears glassy orange with a ton of carbonation. Looks sweet. No head, though.

Flavor is orange and fizzy Belgian champagne. Feels like bubbly champagne. A little alcohol burn on the way down. Dry dry dry; tastes very good though; a helluva nice Belgian ale.

Bottle from Vinmonopolet.  A firm sand-colored head, upon a clear, deep golden brown colored body. Initial aroma is sharply spiced and quite phenolic . Then some rounded caramelly malts and yeast for softening. Also a hoppy scent of citrus zest. Fairly dry malt body. Spiced, yeasty, with a distinct hop bitter edge. Some fruity, or berry-ish tartness underneath. Mid-bodied. Light astringent mouthfeel. Spiced, dryish fruit finish.  An exciting one, challenging and highly drinkable.

style lesson 1: belgian golden ales (lucifer, pranqster, matilda, inferno)  
transparent dark amber, larger head.  darker than expected for the style.
nose: iron, orange-clove balls, coriander, orange juice, pal gum, the slimy part of a rotten cantaloupe that the seeds are stuck in, dirty toilet.  bigger nose.  mouth:  not as sweet as expected from the nose, cinnamon, clove, caramel, less gum flavor, thinner body, darker malty finish, a slight bitterness that’s a nice counterpoint.  this doesn’t develop in gross ways, so i enjoyed it more than the lucifer.

Draft at Toad in the Hole.  Foggy red-orange with low but lasting head.  Brash pumpkin-pie-spice aroma.  Intesnse, cartoonish root beer flavor.  Zippy spices on a surprisingly dry, acute finish.  I must say that Goose Island’s "Belgian" yeast makes some really cool phenolics!

Hazy dark orange color with a perfect fluffy white head. Aroma is mostly lemon and orange, with a hint of spice coming through. Flavor is balanced, not too bitter, a bit of sweetness, a hint of sour. Lots of spices come through when you take a sip. Cloves, cinnamon, cardamom. This is almost average all around. It strives for greatness, and just barely misses. I think perhaps it would be good aged.
A dark golden reddish color with a whit head.  A sweet candied sugar Belgian aroma with light citrus and spice.  Smooth, dry, and lightly spiced with coriander.

22oz bottle from Julio’s

Appearance : Amber with a small head.


Aroma : Earthy and a bit metallic. Some spices with light hints of brett. 


Taste : A bit metallic and a bit spicy. 


Overall : A bit too spicy. The metallic taste and aroma bothered me a bit. Maybe this was a bit too old I don’t know.

slightly hazy amber, small quickly disappearing white head, lacy.  nose of sweet malt, floral hops, spices.  florally hoppy flavor with some kind of tartness.  medium bodied, floral hoppy finish.  not bad, but not a favorite styule, either.  on tap at brickstone brewpub.
Translucent dark amber body. No head. Aroma of banana, bread, candied sugar, clove and soap. Taste of stone, yeast, peppermint, anise, clove and nutmeg.

12 oz.  Pours a golden amber, lots and lots of fizz riding up the sides of the glass to the 1 finger of tissue paper thin white fizzy head. I give this beer full points for appearance because it just seems to be screaming "DRINK ME!" Aroma is sweet citrus, barnyard funk, sourness, spice and lemon zest.  Taste is a lovely match to the nose.  Well-balanced, truly lovely brew.  Thank goodness for goodness.

Nice big fluffy white head over top a hazy golden colored beer. Aroma is a little sweet spicy and fruity. Flavor is considerably less sweet and more complex than the aroma. Flavors start off with a little sweetness and some fruity flavors that predominantly feature pear. Slightly spicy and a little hoppy with a bit of alcohol. Sample from Distributor beer show

Bottle (2015 vintage).

Head is initially small, frothy/fizzy, off-white, mostly diminishing.
Body is light amber.

Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (toasted grain), lightly to moderately yeasty (dough), with notes of grains of paradise, gum.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, moderately to heavily bitter.

Medium body, watery/syrupy texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic, slightly metallic.

Clunky, unbalanced, metallic. Drain pour.

aged 2.5 years.

hazy copper, thick dense beige head (much creamier than most belgian beer), med-body, high co2.



aroma: metallic, belgian yeast funkiness.



taste:

T1= sweet malt, fruity.

T2= funky, metallic, co2.

T3= lots of stale hop, belgian funk.



the metallic foam element starts to fade as soon as i swallow, and then there’s a rush of strong cheesy stale hops that carries into the finish and lingers a bit.  i wonder how the beat sugar plays into the flavor profile, and if it contributes to the metallic notes.

rerate up against Lucifer, Pranqster and Inferno Ale.  surprisingly dark copper/orange color for the strong belgian pale ale style that this is attempting.  husky grain nose stands out amongst the others, but still has the expected honey malt and light belgian candy sugar.  body is a little too thick and syrupy, but the finish redeems the beer as a whole: silky, a little chewy, a little crusty, lightly warming.  thought I wouldn’t enjoy it as much as I did.  still had to lower the score from 3.6 (rated in 2005) to 3.3.

Pours orangish brown with small brown head; sweet citrus fruity aroma with notes of orange and mango, also slight hints of spices and caramel, but on top of that - especially as it warms up - quite funky and earthy with horse blanket notes; flavor is quite sweet, exotic fruity with touch of caramel and spices that, together with hops, have almost grassy feeling to them; finish has a touch of toffee, but it is also quite dryish spicy and bitter. Warming up, skunky earthiness becomes dominant in flavor too; body is medium with high carbonation.
12oz bottle. 2010 edition. Pours golden with a thin white head and lots of lacing. Good carbonation. Nice taste of fruit and spice without being too sweet.

Bottle. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Orange-amber colour. Mpderate malty and hoppy very acetic aroma. Moderate bitter very sour flavor. Average moderate bitter very ugly finish. Oily palate. Rubbish.

From the bottle pour was golden copper. Thin white head. Aromas of yeasty dough, sugar, and orange. Medium body in your mouth. Nice balance of sweet fruity flavor; malt, spice, and subtle bitter hops. Finish is on the dry side. Tasty beer.

Bottled on 03/03/10; poured into a tulip glass. 2 words = SO Good! Nice crisp and floral aroma; awesome fresh flavor with that Belgian yeasty goodness. Very easy on the palate and just an overall delicious offering. I hope Goose Island expands their distribution with more product into So Cal.

Bottle from SL, 2010 edition.... Ballin! Small head... boo! Red in color. Nice aroma of some apples, sugar, and some spices. Taste is a nice sipping beer.. Spicy, apple, sugar, but not over kill sweet. Nothing special about it, just a nice belgian.
Cloudy dark orange pour with a small white head.  Nose of hops and oranges.  Sour taste strong in hops with a fruity finish.  Light bodied with a medium amount of carbonation.

2010 Bottle
Appearance: Pours a beautiful orange amber with a white pin stripe.



Aroma: Fruity spicy yeast.



Taste: Apple juice, clove and bitter spicy hops and yeast.



Mouthfeel: Thick, syrupy and fizzy.



Overall:  A pretty mellow beer. I’ve had this on tap at a Chicago airport and remember it being more vibrant.

Another cool bottle thanks to Eric. Pours a copper color with a medium white head. The aroma is sweet and rich fruits, yeast and spices. The flavor is well-balanced, smooth, not overly complex or messy; rich fruits, between watermelon and apricot, champagne, lots of spices, dry.  A really nice Belgian Ale.
Pours amber with a decent, fading head. Aroma-sweet malt. Berries, fruit, bready. Taste- mild sweet malt, yeasty. Overall sweet and not bad, but not great. Aroma better than the taste.

From the bottle pours a hazy deep golden color.  Head is relatively small, but the carbonation is wonderfully unrestrained.  Fine breadiness from the malt is coupled well the the slight sour and fruit character.  Finishes dry, yet not watery.  A soft bitterness makes the beer delightfully refreshing.   Finishing with a lingering alcohol and mild alpha acid bitterness is quite remarkable.  This is a very well made beer that brings a warm contentment to my senses.

2010 12 oz bottle.  Pours copper with no retaining head into a tulip; even the lacing fades leaving it somewhat lifeless looking.  One hell of a lovely fruit aroma: raspberries, white grapes, peaches, orange, Belgian style yeast, bread malts.  Equally fruity in the flavor with white grape and peach taking the forefront.  The yest and bready malts come in and compromise much of the body.  The finish is dry and much of the same with raspberries, strawberries, and figs.  The booze creeps in slight as it warms.  Medium bodied with a velvety mouthfeel and a low level of carbonation.  Very drinkable, sweet, fruity brew.
Poured  orange amber, apricot, candied sugars, citrus hop, spice, little bannana, little bubble gum.

Pours a hazy, orange-brown body with a thin white top. Smells delicious; fruity hops, vanilla and light candy sugar. Taste is sweet and a bit intense; tones of plumes and Belgian candy sugar, wild strawberries and fruity American hops. A mildly bitter and very comfortable finish. This is an interesting marriage of American Pale Ale and Belgian Ale; it has elegantly interwoven combinations of both. The palate is smooth with just enough fizz, making the overall mouthfeel very balanced. Highly drinkable and original.

On tap at "Brewforia".
Hazy golden pour and a modest, coarse off-white head.
Nice light apple and pear aroma with soft mild Belgian yeast notes.
Light bodied and fairly dry with more standard Belgian ale flavors.  Some honey and light malts and a squeaky dry finish. Very nice and glad to see some of tuis make it all the way out here.

Bottle 4/9/10.



Deep copper orange pour with good head and retention. Strange, extremely doughy aroma with some banana and some citrus. Flavor is heavy on the malt side, again doughy, some caramel alt sweetness, bitterness driven by the spicy years. It’s alright, but not one that I’m going to get excited about having access to. I’d had slightly higher hopes.

Beautiful deep orange body with a lasting tan head.  The inviting aroma reminds me of spicy banana bread.  I can sense cloves, cinnamon, and of course banana.  Medium-full mouthfeel, very smooth.  The flavor is sweet and spicy and warming.  The malt and banana notes supply the sweetness while the cloves and cinnamon add the spice.  Finally, there’s a nice alcohol warming.  Very good beer!

12 oz. bottle of the new 2010 batch; pours clear and dark gold with frothy white head; lovely aromas mix of bready malt, creamy spice, yeast, lemons and banana; I just dig beers that smell like this; thin texture with a touch of harshness in the finish; surprised by that a little; dry spice, banana, dough, white sugar and light wheat; don’t get much yeast complexity in the flavors; love the nose but drinking it’s quite sweet and a little one dimensional to me

Very trappisty nose with sweet vineous figs underpinned with cinnamon and cloves.   Pours slightly cloudy orange with an incredibly lively head (must be that rare yeast).  Flavour is again trappisty, with plenty of the detailed character one usually associates with a life of asceticism where the only vice allowed is beer.  Considering this one was brewed by folks who - presumably - ARE allowed other distractions it’s a damn fine effort.
Bottle. Perfumy, fruity sweet and yeasty aroma. Orange color and effervescent.  The yeast brings alot to the flavor. Fantastic and complex flavor. Not too sweet. Clean finish. Nice interpretation.
Decent Belgian ale. Nose of banana, spice, Belgian yeast, bubblegum, and clove. Taste is similar, but mainly bubblegum and banana. The palate was creamy and smooth. No lace in the glass.

The pour is a clear, coppery-amber color with a fairly small, off-white, pillowy head which is quickly and mostly diminishing and the lace is minimal.  The nose is offputting with creamed corn notes hiding the nice notes of cinnamon and nutmeg, spicy hops, fresh herbs, graham cracker, and some toast.  The flavor is better only because the corn notes are less; spicy cinnamon and nutmeg are more prominent and a little pie crust-like, brown sugar, spicy hops, and bread toast.  The palate is lively, medium, and velvety; oddly fitting for the beer.  The finish is spicy from the hops and the cinnamon notes, some herbs, and light bread crust.  The only thing about this one that I did not like was the corn notes which killed the otherwise nice beer.  This brewery does some great things but their Belgian beers are lacking.

12oz bottle.   Weird ripe fruit in the aroma with a touch of spice.   Sweet flavor with mild hops and a odd fruity character.   It’s hard to pin down the yeast character in this one, and it’s not particularly pleasing, more just odd.   Not really a fan.

Bottle, home.  2010.  Fantastic beer.  I’m a huge fan of Goose Island’s Belgian style ales. The fruity yeast flavors are wonderful.  It gets a bit phenolic and the hops are a tad sharp and grassy right now, but it all sorta works, though I can imagine enjoying an aged bottle.  The mouthfeel is wonderfully creamy, particularly for the style.  My pour had very little head and a liquid the color of honey.  The flavors are a mix of fruits, apricots, pears and tart pineapple, clean grain, and light funk.  Very easy beer to drink but also complex.  One of the better American-made Belgian style ales that I’ve had.

2010. After putting one or two aside for the basement, I’m trying this one in its youth. Dusty orange poured gently into a tulip with a slightly fizzy, light carbonation. Its green aroma lifts quickly from the glass with apricots, brandy, and unripened bananas. Sweet and salty on the palate. Apricots, oat bran, and soy. Spicy and hoppy with a hint of warm, sugary alcohol in the finish.

Pour is golden amber in color with a white head tha dissipates quickly to a ring around glass. Scents of bubblegum and malt and yeast. Taste is citrus spice and fruit, with malt. Feel is sticky cabonation and a dry finish. Overall a solid tasting brew with good after thoughts.

Sampled at a tasting at Pacific Park Market, thanks Ken!

a touch of malt, a hint of hops, it’s an easy drinking beer

2010 Bottle - Pours clear and orange with a medium beige head that quickly dissipates...aroma is fruity and spicy, apple, pear and orange, cinnamon?...flavour is full of rich malt, sweet cider, spice...still manages to finish dry and with a nice bitterness...

Bottle from South Bay Drugs: Poured a golden honey color with plenty of sediment floating in equilibrium while a tiny layer of head was created on top. In the nose, there is a hearty serving of zesty yeast with dashes of spice that smell incredibly authentic by Belgian standards. The flavor is just the same with plenty of lemon zest and spicy yeast true to Belgian roots, but there is an ever pleasant refined palate about this particular ale that is granted extra points for being so smooth and balanced.

Pours a hazy golden orange with small sediment, and a large off-white head that lasts forever. Smells pretty bretty and soapy, with candied sugar and a little bit of caramel. The flavor is sweet with apple juice at first, then malty, and finishes with unmistakable Saaz hops. The brettanomyces is present all the way throughout the flavor and evolves accordingly. The brett is also not as overpowering in this compared to most brett infused ales I’ve had. Nice light, smooth mouthfeel, with soft carbonation and great balance and flavors.
Pours orange amber with very little head. Spicy, yeast and and sugar aroma. Dark fruits, clove, spice in the taste. Quite enjoyable.
355 ml bottle. Orange/brown body with off-white head. Flavour is malt, caramel, fruit and spices.

This was a very pleasing Belgian ale.  The nose was sorta funky and the taste was buttery smooth.  As with all these Goose Island ales, it’s a little steep for a 4-pack, but I’m not at ratebeerprices.com, so it doesn’t matter.

I’d drink this again.  Delicious.
12oz bottle into goblet. Pours a deep hazy orange with minimal white head. Sweet fruity aroma. Flavor is heavily dependent on yeast, with tones of sweet malts. Great beer.

Pours a luminous golden color that reminds me of Macallan Single Malt.  Nose has a whiff of brett, but overall I’m drawn to the candied qualities, almost something like a rich liquer-drenched dried fruit at the holidays.  On the palate the dried fruit comes through again, with candy sugar sweetness, and some pleasant black tea flavors.  Finish is warm, sweet, and again with more tea.
The aroma is spicy, pepper, orange peel.  The appearance is a slightly hazy gold/orange.  The flavor is peppery, fruity, spicy.  The finish is spicy.  The mouthfeel is medium.  Decent Belgian.
Deep orange, small white head. Fresh citrus aroma, lovely bitterness at the front with a strong, sweet, malty finish. Full mouthfeel without being overbearing.
2010 bottle. Dark orange-red with small white head. Big banana in the aroma. Flavor is missing something I can’t describe. Just seems weak, thin. Same with feel. Disappointment.

Bottle served in a tulip. 2010 vintage that was just bottled. Pours clear golden-amber with a large off-white head. Mediocre lacing and retention. Aromatic nose of coriander, belgian yeasts, freshly carved pumpkin, and spices. Flavor is sweet belgian goodness, followed by a hint of pencil eraser. Medium-light body. good carbonation, and a dry, yet sticky finish. Nice brew. Could use some time to develop.

Pours a brownish hazed color with a white head. Aroma is spices, coriander,  yeast, bananas, belgian yeasts. Flavor is yeasty coriander belgian goodness with a nice esthery banana taste with the beet sugar giving it a bit of sweetness. Good dose of hops in the finish to compete with the sweetness. Tasty brew.

Hazy golden pour. Aroma of pungent hops and some really nice light fruitiness like pineapples and peaches with some slight brown sugar and yeast. Crisp lightly bittr finish, and excellent well balanced ale.

Cloudy brilliant orange pour with a decent size white head.  Aroma of barnyard, bubblegum, light and red fruit, slight spice.  Nice tingling carbonation on the front palate with an intense burst of sweetness that slowly diminishes to a clean, dry finish.  A nice belgian style ale overall.

12 oz bottle. cloudy copper pour with a medium off-white head that has good retention. The aroma is distinct with wheat, rock candy and Belgian yeasts. The taste is more of the same with the yeast dominating and the sweet spiced wheat filling in the sides. The palate is full and malty. The finish is long and dry. Overall: All right brew, but it really didn’t grab me.

355ml screw top bottle bought at Vinmonopolet, Langnes. Frothy, diminishing, beige head. First pour reveals a clear, golden brown body. Slightly hazy content after the second pour. Malts and herbal fruits to the nose. Yeasty fruitiness in flavour mixed with spices, candy sweetness and apricots. Masked alcohol. Easy to drink. Half-way pleasing (Tromsø, 13.03.2010).

Bottled, 2009. Pours slightly hazy, pale amber with a large, foamy off-white head. Fair lacings. Friuty nose with light malt and notes of yeast. Sweet flavour with caramel malt, spices and fruit. Medium bodied. More dry finish. Nice.

Amber golden with decent head. Full nectar with good carbonation. This reminds me of Pitaat in a way yet finishing with some spicy sweetness. I would’ve thought this was the real deal. An excellent American specimen.

Bottle pours dark copper with a healthy sized off white head.  Aroma is big spicy yeast, with banana bread, and juicy fruit undertones. Flavor shows the same with caramel, orange, peach, apricot, lemongrass, and a little brett funk.  Overall body is moderate, creamy and finishes dry with a slight bit of warming alc.  I’m  curious to see how this one is drinking sometime down the road.

The foamyest beer ever, but damn tasty.  I finishes clean great teaste and the foam didn’t bother me. - Moto
I can’t even drink it! (Foam Issues) It’s like a dirty whore it never stops cumin in my mouth. - Wiggles
I can’t believe it’s a Goose Island… - Mustache
I don’t like it but it’s better than some of the other ones. - Drex
Tastes like a chick drink - Kool-Aid
Very nice flavor, slightly musty, a hint of sourness, sweet, banana, candy, pours dark copper with a nice thin white head that is gone almost immediately. Faint candy smell. Nice long aftertaste.
Pours golden with an off-white head. Aroma is caramel, fruit, medium grass hop. Flavour is caramel, fruity notes, grass hop and alcohol.
Pours a vibrant orange with very little head. Smells like it is going to be cloying. coriander, bread, caramel and fruit. Maybe a little beet.

12 oz bottle.. Hazy medium amber pour , small wispy off white head , some lace . Sweet malt aroma and spicy , peppery yeast . Flavor is caramel sweetness with notes of fruit and brett . Finish is dry with a lingering bitter finish and a touch of funk . Mild alcohol burn , medium bodied .carbonation is soft . Very interesting .
Bottle from a trade with RCL. Pours light amber color with off white head. Doughy and fruity aroma. Sweet fruity flavor with bread dough and spices. Medium body with lively carbonation. Thanks Ray.

Bottle, 12oz. It pours a dark orange body, unclear, and is topped by a finger-thick beige head soon turning into a thin layer of bubbles. Very fruity, sugary nose with hints of banana. A whiff of alcohol and spices steps forward when swirling the beer. Some yeasty notes too. Dry, warming and full-bodied, with a pleasant bitterness in the end. White sugar, frehs fruits, dried apricots, a little spiced note and a pleasant bitterness in the flavor. It’s a fine beer, but I’m not really sure about the score. It feels like there’s something unclean aroma and flavor, but I’m not sure if it’s part of the intended profile. I think I’ll focus on other beers when buying. 100228

22 oz. bottle.  2009.  Aroma is fruity and spicy with some banana bread.  Appearance is translucent reddish with a thin, wispy head.  Mild flavors with an alcohol warming in the finish.No one strong flavor.  Interesting.  Certainly is some fruit  taste fruit and some earth.

Had on draft at bar in Chicago. Very full of flavor yet very drinkable. Fairly high alcohol without tasting like a liqueur or barley wine. Fruity, but not in a way that makes it seem too sweet or bitter, rather, it’s fairly spicy.

This is a 2008 Goose Island Matilda from Nelsons Wines in South Wimbledon. I opened the bottle which then exploded into a massive foam bath. The bottle was poured too quickly for my liking for spillage reasons. Looks like a heffe-wiessbier and tastes very similar to German styles but with more amber texture; more fruitier and a tad more caramel. A very good beer but there is no aroma due to I suspect the aging. I want to rate it higher than a 3.1 but due to the aroma issue this is very difficult to do so. It is exceptionally cloudy however this too represents a German style. On the taste this is one of the best wiessbiers I’ve had for a long time. It also reminds me that I haven’t bought Goose Island for sometime and I need to change that.
12 oz bottle from Happy Harry’s.  Cloudy orange pour, minimal head.  Fruity, yeasty aroma and flavor with a sweet & chewy mouthfeel and a great finish.

Bottle. Pours hazy golden with a creamy steady off white head. The aroma is caramel, light spices, some hops and barley. Malty and caramel like flavour with light spice and hops. Light alcoholic finish. Creamy texture.

A really nice, refreshing, citrusy Belgian with a bit of spice; clove maybe. Pretty classic stuff here, and I’d emphasize that I really did think it was refreshing, though part of that observation may have been attributed to the fact that I drank it right after a few pints of stout. I’d recommend this one.  I’ll be looking for this again.

Bomber. Pours hazy orange gold with bubbles, off white head. Aroma is funky, musty, dried fruit. Flavor is yeasty and spicy: citrus, coriander, nutmeg. The body is a bit on the thin side and a tad too yeasty for me. Can’t say I care for this one much.

Bottle 2009  Pours a hazy copper with a thin off white head.  The head dissipates rapidly.  Fine rings of lacing.  Aroma is of sweet fruits. A touch of hops but mostly sweetness.  Has a good carbonation.  The flavor is good.  Nice mix of malts and hops.  Blended real well.  This taste like the fine Belgians.  Has a great mouthfeel.  The texture is oily and a touch dry.  Has a medium body.  The finish is awesome.  I love the aftertaste.  This is a good beer.  I like it a lot.  Wish I had more of this.

Bottle into a Chimay glass. Pours a remarkably clear copper color, with a very enticing head which dissipates quickly. Minimal lacing. Aroma was not intense, and pleasing. The taste more than makes up for that, though - a great whoosh of saltiness, bitterness and spice all mixed up in one ball, but overall very balanced. My initial impression was that this would be an average to good beer, but the taste really sent this one skyward. Very enjoyable, will likely buy again.
355 ml bottle. Pours golden with a inch off-white head . Aroma is malty with a spicy hop touch and belgian yeast. Taste is medium sweet and hoppy, fruity, yeast and spices as well .

Bottle, 355ml, from Vinmonopolet, Oslo. Bottled 21.10.2009. Clear amber colour. Off-white inch-thick head slowly settling into a thin lacing. Excellent nose of ripe fruit, hops, yeast, caramel. Slick mouthfeel, medium body. Well balanced. Nice fruity bitterness in the finish.

355 ml bottle. Golden body with a big, off-white head. Aroma is mild malty, spicy and yeast, very typical Belgium ale. Flavor is sweet, smooth malty, fruity, moderate hoppy with spices and yeast. No particular flavors are dominating; this has just a mild and incredible balanced Belgium flavor. Very nice.

Amber colored pour with a thick off white head.  Aroma is pepper, spice, and farmhouse funk.  Flavors are sweet fruits, Belgian yeast and spices.  Bubbly carbonated palate.  Both a slightly dry and slightly sour finish.

12 oz bottle from six pack. 2009 version.Pours a nice copper to amber color with substantial frother off white head. Complex malty sweet aroma. Taste is fruity and somewhat spicy sweet, balanced by only a slight hop bitter. Smooth, slight alcohol finish. Aging would likely aid the overall taste of this Belgian Ale.

12oz bottle. Pours copper with off-white head. Aromas of yeast, sweet fruits, and sweet malts. Flavors of yeast, some sweet fruits, malts and some spices. Has nice balance between fruit and malt with yeast rounding out belgian flavors. Pretty good beer.

355 ml bottle, courtesy of Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. Also available in Norway at Vinmonopolet. ABV is 7%. Deep golden to amber colour, big white (or slightly off-white) head. Strong fruity and spicy aroma, notes of cloves, Belgian ale yeast and alcohol. Fairly rich mouthfeel. Drank it a bit too warm, but the flavour has a decent fruity and malty sweetness with some notes of mild spices and moderate hops in the finish. Pretty good stuff.

Bottle from Vinmonopolet.
Lovely copper beer, Belgian aroma.
Lots of fruit and berries, Apricots, redcurrants. Sweet and sour. Lovely beer!
Golden clear with white film. Aroma of honey cereals, light malts - spicy yeast like a belgian blonde. Taste is sweet and mild alcohol. Texture is watery and a bit sticky. Bottle@Cardinal 20.1.2010.
Bottle from The Cave. Dark orange, red colour, off-white head. Aroma is yeasty, spicy and fruity. Some orange zest. Flavour is sweet malty, yeasty. Slightly bitter. Well crafted.
beautiful and refreshing. There’s a caramely, but melony thing going on. I really like the fizzy mouth-feel.

22 oz. bottle.  Bottled:  11/16/09.  Pours a hazy rust color with a thick antique white head.  A strange aroma of fresh french fries and vegetable oil, caramel, soy sauce, and some mushrooms.  The flavor starts with caramel, some plums, wet cardboard, and a hint of soy sauce.  A bit of earthiness in the middle.  A semi-drying biscuity finish.  Some warming alcohol is noticeable.  Strange.

Had a four pack 12oz. bottles and enjoyed every one!
 Nose is a pleasant doughy malt with fruit backgrounds, maybe peach... not much hoppiness in the aroma.
 Pours golden/orange with a slight haze.  Head is medium large and off white but falls a bit quickly leaving some broken lacing. 
 Taste and palate are enjoyable... medium body and slightly sweet throughout with a malted and slight alcoholic finish that sits on the tongue then fades pleasantly.
  Another wonderful beer put out by Goose Island... they have been impressing me as of late.

Pours an amber orange with little head.   Haystack aroma, a slight bubblegum nose as well.  Lively CO2 burst of banaona and bubblegum, brettanomyces yeast, and a lingering creamy feel.  Overall, a good Belgian Ale from a great brewery in an unhappy city.

Appearance: hints of amber, copper, red and orange; good clarity; creamy off-white head fades quickly

Aroma:  typical toast, biscuit malt with fruity support; pear-like fruitiness; very little pepper and spice; low hop presence

Taste: well-rounded; mild fruit; smooth malt character; good toast and nut component as well; no hop flavor; light bitterness; lightly sweet on the finish

Mouthfeel: typical of style; medium body; 7% alcohol is difficult to detect

Overall: hard not to like this Belgian; smooth; easy-drinking despite ABV; clean and prototypical of style; well-done

Flaske 0,355l kjøpt på Vinmonopolet i Tromsø. Gyldenbrun på farge. Lavt kremaktig skum. Svakt krydret aroma. Litt frukt. Søt fruktig smak. Plommer. Svakt krydret ettersmak. Litt tørr bitterhet etterhvert.

15.01.2010, 0,355l Bottle. Vintage 2009. Pale brown colour with white head. Aroma dominated by malt and spicy hops. Nece pleasant flavours. The hops gives the beer a very nice flavour with smooth bitterness and aftertaste.

Bottle. Pours a clear, reddish orange with a white head that quickly recedes to a ring. After that, even swirling the glass produces little head. Aroma is sweet, dominated by yeast, with some spice and herbal notes, sweet and tart fruity, as if from berries, plus some funk and alcohol. Fairly sweet on the tongue, it finishes with a solid hop bite. Carbonation is sparkly, but not overly so. Medium to light body yet full of flavour makes this both easily drinkable and suitable for sipping. Goose Island pulled this off pretty well, I’d say.

355 ml bottle at home. (Bottled on 21/10/2009). Clear amber color, nice off-white head. Aroma is fruit, spices, Belgian yeast, caramel malt. Flavor is medium sweet, fine hops, fruit, spices. The aftertaste is spicy with some bitterness. Medium body, fine carbonation. Balanced and nice. Will put some bottles in the cellar for ageing.

Bottle of the 2009.  Pours a ruby tangerine brown with a touch of haze and a medium sized white head.  Touch of orange, caramel, and spicy malt. Medium bodied, light hop presence, malt and caramel.  Finishes with a touch of warming alcohol, and a light bitterness.  Seems a little unimpressive.  I had a 2006 bottle of it as well, guess I should have drank that one and let this age a bit.

22oz bottle. Pours a transparent orange color with a big white foamy head. Head recedes leaving scattered lacing and a few heavy islands on the surface. Nose is light apricots and dried fruits with a nice biscuity malt note. Palate is medium with a nice toasted malt finish. Biscuity and sweet caramel malts, stings on the tongue and leaves a nice film on the molars.
Funky tart aroma with some wood flavor.  Glorious golden in color with a fluffy head.  Very tasty, lots of sour flavor, very light in flavor, with a delicious balance of zesty hops.  Delicious.
Sampled on BQ2010. Bottle. Pours a dark brown body. The nose is yeast and malts. The flavor is some alcohol, yeast, floral, and wood!

Tried on Beer Quest 2010 with all the guys. This was number 11. Pour was not amazing but went up from there. The aroma of yeast and malts. The flavor is complex. Hard to distinguish. Some yeasts, flowers, and woody.

33cl bottle into trappist glass, aroma is sweet and yeasty, a little spice.  Taste is belgian yeast, sweetness and fruit, apples, a little malt in the background and a pleasant bitter fruity finish.  Very nice.
Have a scant old rating note for this from the brewpub in Chicago:  spice, malt, yeast aroma.  lemon and bread taste.  dry fruit aroma.  That’s all I’ve got other than a score.
Hazy orange, whitish head.  Yeasty, estery, floral aroma.  Taste is fruity, esters, floral, light alcohol.

08 bottle pours orange with haze and globules. Aroma is sweet lemon and lime, other fruit, white wine, honey, light herb. Taste is mild sweetness with some bitterness as well. Soft texture, smooth carbonation, short bitter finish. Very fruity with some roasted malt and hop noticeable. Yeast gives some good flavor also.
12 oz bottle Pours a nice orange with a small off white head.  Taste is close to an abby style with hint of citrus a bit heavy on the spices for my taste.

Lovely beer. Tasty too. Poured with a grand foamy, frothy off white head and great lace. Color is a medium amber. Aroma is very yeasty, malty, a little hop, and a bit vineous. Flav’s the same but more full. Very good body and carbonation. Satisfying. Don’t pick up much on the alcohol. Nicely balanced. Finish is good. Kind of on the border between a drinkable beer and a special. I’d imagine that would be ideal from the brewer’s perspective. Whatever.

Bottle. Pours a clear golden/orange beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is sweet, fruit with orange and notes of yeast. The flavor is sweet, malt with caramel, fruit and yeast. The palate is dry and spicey. Overall a good beer.

Nice golden orange pour with beautiful off white head. Complex aroma and flavor of tropical fruits and spice with a bit of wild flower honey. Was put off a bit by a rather distinct flavor of burnt transmission fluid. Need to try again in another setting.

12oz bottle. Pours a light amber colour with a big, dense off-white head, leaving a thick, soapy lacing. Yeasty aromas with some clove, orange and biscuity malts. Lots of initial sweetness, caramel and fruit with yeastiness and a dry spicy finish with some light herby bitterness. Medium body, mildly warming on the tongue, soft carbonation and a lasting bready aftertaste. Bottled on: 08/09/08

2009 Bottle (22.April.2209/14h10 Batch):

Nice golden coloured body with a copper tint, orange highlights and almost no head at all. Aroma of honey, yeast, curacao, resin, pine and a touch of hops. Full-bodied; Strong chewy body of yeast, curacao and a good set of spices, including coriander seed and maybe a touch of acetone - odd. Aftertaste is a bit refined, only spruce and yeast coming through with a touch of honey and a light sweetness. Overall, a pretty decent beer - but nothing amazing. Shows well, but I prefer many more belgies to this one - a ton from Belgium and a bunch from the States too. I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Chevy Chase Wine & Spirits in Washington, DC on 25-July-2009 sampled at home in Washington on 10-December-2009.
Pours golden, good head with some lacing. Tastes like lots of sugar, caramel with subtle bite at the end. Lots of carbonation. Very good.
Bottle. Clear honey colored body, with a medium white head. Aroma is sweet honey, yeast, light hops and caramel. Flavor is caramel, yeast, hops and malt. An okay beer.

Aroma of molasses, brown sugar and chocolate. Appearance was red gold with creamy head. Flavor of burnt toffee, caramel, malted chocolate and cinnamon. Palate was bubbly. Interesting beer for the style.

Goose Island Matilda
Cloudy ochre colour with tall foamy head; spicy sweet malt aroma; full flavoured slightly sweet, spicy flavour, nice lingering aftertaste

12oz marked as bottled on 09-08-08 from theisti. Light gushing out of the bottle when opened. Pours into a HUGE rocky head that’s slow to settle. Awesome - looks like ’the real thing’. Nose is barnyard brett funk, some orange peel and a touch of sweetness.
